Nikolai Chepelev
Nikolai Chepelev has recently completed post-doctoral training under the leadership of Dr. Carole Yauk at the Genomics Laboratory, Healthy Environments and Consumer Safety Branch, Health Canada. For his research in toxicogenomics, he has received two awards from the Risk Assessment Specialty Section of the Society of Toxicology, including an award for the Best Published Paper Advancing the Science of Risk Assessment. Nikolai is a post-doctoral fellow with Integrated Laboratory Systems, where he is currently applying toxicogenomics in the re-assessment of the adverse effects of acrylamide. His long-term goal is to develop a research program that leverages toxicogenomics and other powerful high-throughput technologies to improve toxicity testing, and continue the momentum towards improved 21st century approaches in toxicology.


                    Publications in PubMed
                








Bret Freudenthal
Dr. Freudenthal recently completed his postdoctoral work with Dr. Samuel Wilson at the National Institutes of Environmental Health and has transitioned to an independent Assistant Professor position at the University of Kansas Medical Center. The overarching goal of his research is to understand how environmental hazards that damage the DNA lead to deleterious human health outcomes. He utilizes a reductionist approach consisting of structural, biochemical, and molecular biology assays to investigate complex biological questions. By combining this multi-disciplinary approach with cellular collaborations he hopes to make better therapeutic treatments for human diseases.


                    Publications in PubMed
    




The rules
Contestants are screened by EMGS and invited to participate. All are just finishing their education and training or within 3 years of establishing an independent scientific career.
Anyone making a tax-deductible donation of any amount gets a vote (you may donate/vote as many times as you'd like). The candidate with the most votes wins.
Up to $2,500 will go toward hosting the award winner's attendance at the meeting and a small honorarium. Additional contributions will support the travel of more young scientists to Kansas City.
The 47th Annual Meeting of the EMGS

Enabling technologies have driven our knowledge of the structure and content of the human genome and epigenome to dizzying heights and are empowering large scale toxicological assessments. Our challenge is rapidly changing from simply obtaining genomic, epigenomic, and toxicological data to interpreting and using that data to improve human health. We will examine how exposures and the environment continue to shape the genome of individuals and populations. We will further learn how measuring or imputing the response of the genome and epigenome to environmental agents is providing powerful new approaches for understanding the genetic impacts of human exposures.
EMGS 2016 focus topics:

Mechanisms of DNA damage and repair, somatic and germline mutagenesis, and their genomic signatures in health and disease.
Ways in which the environment modifies the epigenome and thus gene expression.
Next-generation methods in applied genetic toxicology; how technology and innovation are changing our approach to risk assessment.

story:
Great photo,eh? I just love that shot of a coal barge moving up river through the morning mist.

Well friends, we find ourselves in the final 20 days of our campaign with only a handfull of supporters. We aren't certain why this important project has gained little interest. The Peoria Journal Star published an informative column about our efforts and one of the local tv stations aired us as well, perhaps we set the goal too high? Or maybe it's the flexible funding format we chose? Rest assured, every penny collected will go toward purchasing the equipment we need to make this venture progress.

Most of the commercial fishing men and women in this area have been unemployed since this spring when the last fish meal contract at Big River Fisherie ran out. We just want to get back to work! So, what if we ask you for no interest loans instead of donations? At the donors request, we will gladly return your donation as soon as we are working again and showing a profit so you can reuse your funds to help another project. Our convictions are solid and we are motivated to make this project a success. Together we can do this and in the end it will be no expense to you.

Below you will find our original campaign post. Contact us at iracapinfo@gmail.com and we will answer any questions or comments you may have. Thank you for taking the time to view our campaign, we are looking forward to hearing from you, Gene.

 

My name is Gene Sperry Jr., a licensed commercial fisherman (#1138) from Peoria County, Peoria, Illinois soliciting your interest in helping us save the Illinois River ecosystem and helping feed thousands of people around the planet.

If you are from the Midwest, or anywhere for that matter, you are probably aware of issues we are having with Asian Carp in our rivers and lakes.  The Asian Carp is an invasive species that escaped from fish farms and water purification systems in the southern U.S. in the 1980s and these fish have been migrating north via the Mississippi River ever since.  They are now well established here in Peoria, IL and have been for quite some time.  Asian Carp are not bottom feeders; they grow very quickly by filter-feeding on green/brown algae and plankton.  Their feeding habits and rapid growth make them low in contaminants, and high in nutrition and Omega 3 oils.  The downside of their type of feeding is that they eat their own body weight in less than a week, disrupting the river’s ecosystem by over-consuming on the diet of the river’s native species.

Photo courtesy of the Asian Carp Regional Coordinating Committee, some rights reserved.

Brian Ickes, of the United States Geological Survey (USGS) in a May 18th 2012 report, states:  “As far as wild populations go, the greatest density of Asian Carp on the planet now likely exists in Illinois waters of the Illinois and Mississippi Rivers." 

Josephine Marcotty of StarTribune adds:  "The Mississippi and Illinois Rivers have more Asian Carp than anywhere else on the planet.  Even more than China where they came from.” 

The Canadian and U.S. fisheries on the Great Lakes are scared.  If the Asian Carp population enters the Great Lakes, it may choke out the salmon and destroy the charter fishing industry.  So what is being done to prevent this potential attack on the Great Lakes?  Electrified barriers have been placed across waterways leading to the Great Lakes.  Meanwhile, the Asian Carp population south of those barriers is growing at an alarming rate. 

Currently, the Illinois Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) has hired teams of commercial fishermen to harvest Asian Carp from the waterways between Spring Valley and Morris, in an effort to reduce the number of Asian Carp reaching the electrified barriers, at a cost to the taxpayers of well over $40,000 per week.  The harvested fish are then donated to be processed into organic fertilizer.  In our estimation, this is a waste of this resource.  So what else is being done to reduce the population of Asian Carp in the Illinois River to slow their migration toward Chicago and the Great Lakes? 

Multimillion dollar Asian Carp processing plants have been proposed for years and yet, to date, none have been built in Illinois.  When they are constructed, they will most likely process the harvested Asian Carp into fertilizer or fish meal to be used in animal feed.  This is not utilizing the Asian Carp to their full potential.  The harvested fish should be used to feed people. 

That being said, there are two small, private Illinois companies that market Asian Carp for human consumption:  Schafer Fisheries located in Thompson, Illinois and Big River Fish located in Pearl, Illinois.  Both companies have facilities that process fresh iced fish and frozen fillets for sale in markets and restaurants across the U.S. and also ship small amounts to foreign countries to be served in high-end restaurants.  Both of these facilities are relatively small and only employ a handful of fishermen, creating little impact on the Asian Carp population. 

At its average water level, the Illinois River pool at Peoria, Illinois covers 352 square miles of water in which the Asian carp spawn, live, thrive, and migrate towards the Chicago waterways and the Great Lakes. This is 352 square miles of water holding hundreds of thousands of pounds of Asian Carp that are not being harvested because there is no local facility to process the fish. 

We, the fishermen of the Peoria area, believe multimillion dollar plants harvesting Asian Carp to make fertilizer and animal feed or dump them in landfills is not the answer.  Throughout the world there is a market for frozen, whole fish to help feed the masses which utilizes the whole fish and wastes nothing.  Flash freezing the whole fish as soon as it comes out of the water and shipping them in large freezer containers will make freshly frozen fish affordable for everyone.  With our proposed facility, there is no processing, very little overhead, and no waste.  We just catch them, freeze them, ship them and feed people.  Our goal is to develop a pilot program that involves a spiral flash freezer facility on the river where the Asian Carp are harvested.  The spiral flash freezer facility can be constructed for 1/10th of the cost of building a full-scale processing plant.  Simple successful operations on the river’s edge could create jobs and opportunities for many communities on the Illinois River. 

We are seeking funding/sponsors/donations so that we can acquire the rest of the equipment that we need to make this project a reality.  Please find it in your heart to help.  This project will have a positive impact on the lives of many people.  We already have property with river access, two plate boats, gear, trained fishermen, buildings to house the spiral freezer, and storage containers.  We need some aircraft/marine-grade aluminum to construct more plate boats (we have a professional boat builder on site), outboard motors, more gear, and a spiral flash freezer.  By purchasing a used and reconditioned spiral flash freezer and building our own boats with donated aluminum and outboard motors, we can begin the "Illinois River Asian Carp Abatement Project" for around $350,000. 

It’s a pretty hefty goal that will take many donations from concerned people to reach, but it's also a far cry from the millions it will cost the government and its taxpayers to construct a plant to process fertilizer and fish meal.  With your help, in a few months we can be up 'n' running, feeding people and taking some of the pressure off of the Chicago waterways.  With your donations to the "Illinois River Asian Carp Abatement Project," we can demonstrate better solutions.  Let’s feed people and stop spending taxpayer dollars. 

Well friends, that's Plan A and if we can't reach the goal of $200,000 then we'll go to Plan B. Plan B is a goal of $100,000 so we can acquire boats for two more crews and purchase a refrigerated semi trailer so we can haul our harvest to an existing plant in Iowa, then maybe next year we can afford to purchase the much needed spiral freezer. If we cannot reach the goal of $100,000 for Plan B then we'll be looking at Plan C, which is a goal of $30,000  for boats and gear for one more crew and put a box cooler and a refrigerator unit on a truck we already have.

Please help us with this project before everything gets out of control and big brother shows up and thinks the only solution is to come in and poison the river and start over! The poisons are already being stockpiled.

If you have any questions or comments, contact us at iracapinfo@gmail.com and we will answer as quickly as possible. 

To learn more about Asian Carp in Illinois, read the Watershed Council’s article. 

"Catch 'em"..."Freeze 'em"..."Ship 'em"...Feed people. 

Sincerely, 

Gene Sperry Jr. 

iracapinfo@gmail.com

 

Sources

Asian Carp Regional Coordinating Committee:  http://www.asiancarp.us

Brian S. Ickes, USGS, 5/18/2012:  http://www.nps.gov/miss/naturescience/upload/IckesPresent-051812.pdf

Josephine Marcotty, StarTribune, 6/6/2012:  http://www.startribune.com/sports/outdoors/157525545.html

story:
The Basics:

  • My name is Justin Boivin. I currently am making a living as an Artist in Sudbury, Ontario Canada. I am really passionate about getting this world back to where in needs to be, helping us get back into balance with mother earth.
  • I am wanting to learn permaculture, sustainable agriculture, and sustainable building techniques at a school based in Kathmandu Nepal. 
  • Eventually I will be able to teach these skills and knowledge to others. By helping me, you are ensuring the growth of this knowledge and investing in the future of the planet, and planting seeds for creating sustainable communities.
  • Wanna get to know me better? Check me and my art out on facebook. You can even get some of it mailed to you as a perk. Here's the link:  https://www.facebook.com/justin.boivin.5/media_set?set=a.454333844624515.105878.100001437092674&type=3

What I need:

  • I need $2000 to attend a 5 month course at the "Permaform Institute for Sustainability Arts" based in Kathmandu Nepal. Food and lodging are provided by the school. Here's a link for more information: http://permaforminstitute.weebly.com/
  • I truly feel a sense of purpose in learning this work, and am really excited about it! On top of that Nepal is a beautiful country with a warm hearted people.
  • If funding falls short of the goal, I may be able to top it up if I sell a few paintings this month. If funding exceeds the goal, it will help me have a bit of a buffer for basic travel expenses, or something to use in case of emergency.  

A bit about Permaculture:

  • Permaculture can be understood as "Permanent Landscaping." In a nutshell is creating a food production system that closely mimics natural ecosystems. Permaculture involves growing food using a variety of plants that compliment each other, ward off pests/weeds and create a self-sustaining food production system.
  • Where traditional agriculture depletes soil nutrients, requires much energy/work, permaculture uses biodynamic principles to let nature do the work. It produces more per square foot than traditional agriculture, it enriches the soil, and requires less energy/work to get the same results as traditional agriculture. It is also more resilient to environmental changes like drought or climate shifts because of the diversity of plants grown.
  • Permaculture is community based. It can help any community become independent from industrial agriculture. It creates food security without having to "toil in the fields." If we can establish permaculture in community, we can make that community self sufficient. It is a great solution to many of the worlds economic and environmental issues. 
  • Here's a wikipedia article about permaculture: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permaculture

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't make a financial contribution, you can:

  • Share this campaign with others
  • Research permaculture, sustainable building, and share the knowledge
  • Learn permaculture too!

story:
A coast-to-coast walk to talk about climate change

climate-walker.org

Hello,

My name is David Henry. I'm a husband and father of two, an information technology professional, a musician, and a walking advocate. I'm very concerned about climate change – concerned about what we are leaving future generations – concerned about how we will adapt – concerned that not enough people are concerned.  It's very frustrating that the national conversation about climate change is still focused on whether or not it is a problem - or that it is someone else's problem.  I'm concerned enough that I can no longer continue with business as usual. So, I'm taking a career sabbatical to walk from Boston to Los Angeles – 3,500 miles – to start new conversations about climate change. 

 

Starting a new conversation

My goal is to have at least 100 good conversations with people from all walks of life.  A good conversation is one where I listen to you and you listen to me.  I'm not aiming to convince you to do something specific - instead I think our conversation would be successful if you take ownership of the climate change problem in your own way and continue the conversation with others.

I’m not trying to make anyone feel guilty.  It does no good to spread guilt. Instead I’d like to spread hope – hope that we can meet the coming challenges – hope that we can turn those challenges into opportunities – hope that we can all work together.

 

How you can help me

I will be walking over 3,500 miles from Boston to Los Angeles.  Based on my research, I expect this will take somewhere between 6 and 7 months.  I'm asking for your support.  First and forenost is moral support - I'd love to hear from others who have the same sense of urgency about climate change.  I'd also love to hear your suggestions to make this journey more successful.  On a practical level, any monetary donations you provide will help me with equipment, provisions, occasional lodging etc.  My estimate of the equipment, provisions, and occasional lodging is about $5,000.  Any donations would be apopreciated and I will thank you personally at some levels.  At higher donation levels you can sponsor a specific city-to-city segment of my walk - you can even specify which cities (by refering to my route at http://climate-walker.org).  At the $1000 level you can sponsor my walk across an entire state.

story:
About the Trip (And Me!)

I discovered my passion for the outdoors through wilderness travel in the BWCA and Canada with YMCA Camp Menogyn. In 2011, I was one of the first two women to paddle 2,000 miles from Minneapolis to Hudson Bay, recreating Eric Sevareid's route from Canoeing With the Cree. That trip inspiring me to start a non-profit called Wild River Academy. Wild River Academy provides canoe expeditions along the Minnesota River. Trips stop along the route to interact with environmental organizations, community members, Dakota people, farmers, and State Park Rangers. This experiential learning opportunity not only enhances outdoor skills, it exposes participants to the social and natural environment in the Minnesota River watershed, encouraging a sense of peace and place.

I am gearing up for my next big adventure, but I need your help!

In the fall of 2013, I, along with eight other people, will embark on and film a three month long canoe journey down the Mississippi River from the headwaters in Lake Itasca, Minnesota, to New Orleans. As we paddle, we will engage communities in an ongoing dialogue about their relationships to and interactions with this watertrail to give voice to the Mississippi River, its inhabitants, and the many perspectives we encounter along the way. Upon completion of the trip, we will produce a documentary of this journey so that these vital conversations can continue with others beyond the flow of the river.

Why Paddle the Mississippi? 

As the climate debate comes to a head in the United States, it’s easy to get caught up in abstract political jargon and lose sight of the everyday people whose lives revolve around the health of a natural resource. I love paddling rivers that encompass an array of social and environmental issues because they tell a great story. One that needs to be heard.

What I Need:

So the breakdown is pretty simple.  First and foremost, I need to eat.  I’m asking $720 for all of my food expenses.

Food for one day:

$11

Food for one week:

$77

Food for one month:

$308

Food for the whole trip:

$924

While it would be nice if there were no other expenses, there are.  Both myself and my canoe need to come back to Minneapolis in one piece.  The breakdown is as such:

Ship a canoe to Minneapolis

$226

Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities

$350

                                                                         Total Trip Cost:         $1,500

 

What Do You Get If You Help Fund My Campaign?

$25 – a really, REALLY, really big hug, and lots of karma points!

$50 – A personalized postcard from a town along the way, plus hugs and karma points! 

$100 – Your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, a hug, and karma points!

$500 – A shout-out to you or your organization on our twitter and facebook with a picture of me featuring your name or company, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, hug, and karma points!

$1,000 – A Paddle For Change T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, a hug, untold amounts of karma points, and my eternal gratitude. 

$1,500 - A Paddle For Change T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, a hug, untold amounts of karma points, my eternal gratitude, and my first born child. 

 The Impact

Without your support, this trip is not possible.  Not only will I personally grow from this challenging and unique experience, but I will connect with new people to develop a constructive dialogue about our lives in the United States and the world.

Upon returning, we will have the incredible opportunity to construct a national dialogue about the Mississippi by creating a documentary of our experiences.  This documentary will spark conversations about our national resources, water usage, the meaning of community, and the very nature (pun!) of what it means to be "in nature."  We believe strongly that these are dialogues that our nation must be having more often with one another, and I would be proud to be a part of this legacy.  Besides, everyone likes a good documentary!

This trip will also be a great way to scope out other watershed communities that could benefit from Wild River Academy's programming in the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean I can’t use your help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on facebook, twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. 

Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us.  Though our group has varying degrees of paddling experience we can always use community support.  We welcome your insights. 

 

www.paddle4ward.com

https://www.facebook.com/WildRiverAcademy

 

Thank You!
story_txt:
About the Trip (And Me!)
I discovered my passion for the outdoors through wilderness travel in the BWCA and Canada with YMCA Camp Menogyn. In 2011, I was one of the first two women to paddle 2,000 miles from Minneapolis to Hudson Bay, recreating Eric Sevareid's route from Canoeing With the Cree. That trip inspiring me to start a non-profit called Wild River Academy. Wild River Academy provides canoe expeditions along the Minnesota River. Trips stop along the route to interact with environmental organizations, community members, Dakota people, farmers, and State Park Rangers. This experiential learning opportunity not only enhances outdoor skills, it exposes participants to the social and natural environment in the Minnesota River watershed, encouraging a sense of peace and place.
I am gearing up for my next big adventure, but I need your help!
In the fall of 2013, I, along with eight other people, will embark on and film a three month long canoe journey down the Mississippi River from the headwaters in Lake Itasca, Minnesota, to New Orleans. As we paddle, we will engage communities in an ongoing dialogue about their relationships to and interactions with this watertrail to give voice to the Mississippi River, its inhabitants, and the many perspectives we encounter along the way. Upon completion of the trip, we will produce a documentary of this journey so that these vital conversations can continue with others beyond the flow of the river.

Why Paddle the Mississippi? 
As the climate debate comes to a head in the United States, it’s easy to get caught up in abstract political jargon and lose sight of the everyday people whose lives revolve around the health of a natural resource. I love paddling rivers that encompass an array of social and environmental issues because they tell a great story. One that needs to be heard.
What I Need:
So the breakdown is pretty simple.  First and foremost, I need to eat.  I’m asking $720 for all of my food expenses.



Food for one day:


$11




Food for one week:


$77




Food for one month:


$308




Food for the whole trip:


$924



While it would be nice if there were no other expenses, there are.  Both myself and my canoe need to come back to Minneapolis in one piece.  The breakdown is as such:



Ship a canoe to Minneapolis


$226




Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities


$350



                                                                         Total Trip Cost:         $1,500
 
What Do You Get If You Help Fund My Campaign?
$25 – a really, REALLY, really big hug, and lots of karma points!
$50 – A personalized postcard from a town along the way, plus hugs and karma points! 
$100 – Your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, a hug, and karma points!
$500 – A shout-out to you or your organization on our twitter and facebook with a picture of me featuring your name or company, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, hug, and karma points!
$1,000 – A Paddle For Change T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, a hug, untold amounts of karma points, and my eternal gratitude. 
$1,500 - A Paddle For Change T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, a hug, untold amounts of karma points, my eternal gratitude, and my first born child. 

 The Impact

Without your support, this trip is not possible.  Not only will I personally grow from this challenging and unique experience, but I will connect with new people to develop a constructive dialogue about our lives in the United States and the world.
Upon returning, we will have the incredible opportunity to construct a national dialogue about the Mississippi by creating a documentary of our experiences.  This documentary will spark conversations about our national resources, water usage, the meaning of community, and the very nature (pun!) of what it means to be "in nature."  We believe strongly that these are dialogues that our nation must be having more often with one another, and I would be proud to be a part of this legacy.  Besides, everyone likes a good documentary!

Other Ways You Can Help
You might not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean I can’t use your help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on facebook, twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. 
Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us.  Though our group has varying degrees of paddling experience we can always use community support.  We welcome your insights.

story:
Short Summary

I am a single mom with three children currently going to nursing school.  My family is in crisis.  We are being bullied by a big Oil company that had an oil spill on our property.  The Oil company is forcing my family to get out of our home and be out on the streets.  We are having trouble fighting them alone.  We have untill the 17th to come up with the money to save our home from being taken from us. 

This fight is very important to me and my family.  We are being bullied and will be homeless soon.  We would like to help the other families that are also being bullied by this company.  We feel this company should be responsible for the mistakes they make.  Your help will give us a fighting chance to save our home and family.  Please help us we have searched every where for help with this issue and no one or no orginization will help us.  We need your help very much.  Please help us you are our last hope.

If you would like more information on this please find me on facebook Art Ginny Lei  ( Artbyginnylei@yahoo.com ) or feel free to email me for more information.

 

What We Need & What the Community needs

 

We need atleast $6000.00 to keep our family from getting a forclosure on our home. 

If we get enough help we will be able to fight the Oil company and save other families effected by this.

$3500.00 of these funds will go to keeping my family out of forclosure, We must be current through the court system in order for our family to get out from under the grasp of the Oil company.  $2500.00 of the funds will go to helping my family fight the Oil company.

The Impact

The Impact of your help will keep My family off the streets and help fight the big companies that bully families.

There are millions of families effected by bulling every year your contributions will help to stop that.

If you would like to see the progress and follow our family you can watch what happens to us at Art Ginny Lei on facebook.com or find us by searching Artbyginnylei@yahoo.com  on facebook or email me and I will send you updates.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help stop big companies from bulling families out of their properties.  You can help by sending an email to me so I can collect enough statements to fight the Oil company.  I feel the company should either relocate the people effected by this or pay for the clean up. Artbyginnylei@yahoo.com You can also help by supporting Art By Ginny Lei

story:
In just 10 years, half of Paraguay’s pristine natural habitats have been lost. The country’s agricultural output has been booming, but at a massive environmental cost. Too many habitats are being destroyed all over the world, particularly in developing countries.

We want to reverse the trend in Paraguay, and we need your help.

 

Reversing the Trend

Para La Tierra (PLT) is a small not-for-profit conservation organization dedicated to protecting threatened ecosystems throughout Paraguay.

Since 2010, we’ve been stationed at Reserva Natural Laguna Blanca (RNLB), a beautiful nature reserve located at the meeting point of two of Paraguay’s threatened habitats: the Cerrado and the Atlantic Forest. Both of these habitats have suffered dreadfully over the past two decades. Through the development of large scale agriculture, these once lush habitats have been converted into open fields for cattle pasture. Today, only fragments remain untouched but thanks to government regulations and projects like ours the majority of these fragments are now protected. Sadly, it’s too little too late. The large businesses have already staked their claim in these two habitats and are looking for a new habitat to exploit. The Gran Chaco is their next target.

Chaco, in the indigenous language of Quechua, can be translated to mean, ‘the Land of Great Hunting’ and contains a huge biodiversity. It is South America’s largest dry forest and is home to the largest mammal on the continent – the Guanaco. While the indigenous tribes call the land ‘el Gran Chaco,’ the conquistadors called it ‘El Verde Infierno’ or The Green Hell. Boasting the continent’s highest temperature and a myriad of thorny plants, the early settlers disregarded it as useless land. Unfortunately, this view has recently changed. Through developments in technology, agriculture in the Chaco has not only become feasible but it has become profitable. This has led to rapid development of the area and massive destruction of the habitat in the past few years. 10% of the Paraguayan Chaco wilderness was converted to cattle land in 2012 alone, displacing countless indigenous tribes that call the forest home. But, with your help, we can help put a stop to this movement.

 

What We Do

According to National Geographic, Para La Tierra has created a new model for conservation organizations. We understand that there is no ‘silver bullet’ solution to the worldwide destruction of habitats, but we firmly believe that this is a battle worth fighting. PLT is committed to the protection of threatened habitats through scientific research, community outreach and environmental education. 

 


Global Awareness

 

Through our work at RNLB, we have discovered over 50 new species for Paraguay. We have created the largest single-site reference collection in the country. We have published 19 scientific papers in international peer-reviewed journals. And our museum attracts over 1,000 visitors a year. In addition to publishing scientific papers, we promote conservation issues through public and social media, inclusion on Eco-Index, and news articles posted in large worldwide newspapers including Geo Mundo, Business India, The Times and The Daily Mail in addition to the IUCN and National Geographic websites. Our blogs receive over 500 hits a month. Our scientific papers have led to improved conservation plans and our media influence has helped raise the status of Paraguayan conservation issues to a global level.

 

Community Support

Para La Tierra’s main focus in fostering change, encouraging conservation and protecting habitats has been to educate young people who live around the reserve. We’ve designed and implemented a customized environmental education curriculum for elementary and high school students. We’ve hosted on-site workshops for local community leaders designed to impart a new appreciation for their country’s amazing biodiversity. After PLT’s founder, Karina Atkinson, won the Rolex Award for Enterprise, PLT was able to build three chicken coops in the surrounding communities. This project has provided families close to the reserve a source of protein and income so they don’t need to enter the reserve to hunt for food.

 

The Next Generation

Students, graduates and professionals from all over the world have come to PLT’s ecological research center at RNLB for the chance to study the local biodiversity. These visitors are inspired by the beautiful wildlife they see. We have trained students from over 60 universities in a variety of field sampling techniques, preparing them for a future career in conservation biology.

Each year, we have grown to train more and more interns. The majority of former PLT interns continue to post-graduate education but others have found jobs at zoos, rehabilitation centers, and other conservation organizations using PLT as a stepping stone towards a career in conservation. Be a part of the next generation by clicking here – www.paralatierra.org/intern.html

 

 

Why We NEED You

This successful new approach to conservation has given PLT the drive to do more. Our mission is to protect ALL of Paraguay’s habitats by transplanting our model conservation organization to each environment in the country. Before the year is out, we plan to expand to a second field site located on a massive reserve in Paraguay’s fastest disappearing habitat: the Gran Chaco. As you read this, more of its vast landscapes are being burned down and converted into cattle ranches.

This expansion will create a huge variety of opportunities for PLT and ensure the conservation of the Chaco. With your help, PLT will:

  • Run the first ever year-round research station in the Paraguayan Chaco, providing the scientific justification for the protection of the Chaco.
  • Demonstrate the beauty and importance of this little-known habitat to a wider audience.
  • Install a training centre for a new generation of young Paraguayan and international scientists.
  • Conduct a scientific inventory of the Chaco’s flora and fauna leading to new discoveries for the region and the development of an informed conservation plan.
  • Welcome interns who will carry out pioneering investigations into how life survives in this hostile habitat.
  • Give tourists the unique opportunity to actively participate in nature conservation where they contribute positively to environmental issues.
  • Promote Chaco conservation issues in the media, sparking further interest in its protection.
  • Invite university biology classes to learn skills and gain experience that can’t be taught in a classroom.
  • Engage with the local indigenous tribes, providing environmental education to their children and ensuring the survival of their culture.

 

 

The Rewards

A drop in the bucket:

For a £5 donation:

We will post a personalized thank you on Facebook or send you a printable PDF thank you to your email address.

 

A wildlife enthusiast:

For a £10 donation:

We will email you a high res photo of your choice (from UntamedPhotography.net) taken by a PLT staff member that you can print or set as your computer’s background.

 

A true supporter:

For a £30 donation:

In addition to the awards above, we will send you a Reserva Natural Laguna Blanca Bumper Sticker. See above.

 

A die-hard fan:

For a £70 donation:

In addition to the awards above, we will send you a PLT baseball hat.

 

A part of the team:

For a £125 donation:

In addition to the awards above, we will send you a PLT T-shirt.

 

A friend for life:

For a £350 donation:

In addition to the awards above, we will personally acknowledge you in our next scientific publication.

 

An honored guest:

For a £1,000 donation:

In addition to the awards above, we will give you a free five day stay at Para La Tierra (flights not included) to show you what your contribution has meant to us.

 

Our hero:

For a £5,000 donation:

In addition to the awards above, you’ll have PLT’s next new species for science named after you and we will give you and a guest a free five day stay at Para La Tierra (flights not included) to show you what your contribution has meant to us.

 

 

What We Can Do with Your Help

With £5000:

                We would open a field site in the Gran Chaco, installing electricity, plumbing, and internet. We would stock the house with necessary amenities such as beds, a cooker, a fridge, and showers. This would provide us the bare essentials we need to begin welcoming students and professionals to conduct research in the Chaco.

With £10,000:

                We would be able to do all of the above as well as renovate a second building to open the first-ever natural history museum in the Chaco. It would be fitted with an air conditioning unit, dehumidifier and custom-made display units. An on-site museum would provide us with a place to store our scientific collection as well as a place to host educational workshops. Our museum at RNLB has been incredibly successful both as a scientific asset as well as an educational tool.

With £20,000:

                We would be able to buy specialist scientific equipment which would allow us to do more in-depth study on the local flora and fauna. This would include microscopes, radio collars, GPS trackers, GPS units, camera traps etc. This equipment would take our projects to the next level and advance our knowledge of Paraguayan flora and fauna.

With £500,000:

                We would be able to afford the purchase of a plot of threatened habitat to convert into a reserve. This would give us the freedom to manage a reserve with the sole purpose of conservation and investigation. Our first choice would be the land on which our flagship species – the White-winged Nightjar – lives and breeds. It is an endangered species with an estimated population size under 2,500. The land is currently owned by AgroForestal Rio Verde S.A. and they are using it for Eucalyptus plantations. With such a large sum of money, PLT would be able to provide protection for habitats in need of conservation.

 

 

Who We Are

Karina Atkinson – Karina graduated from an honors degree in Genetics from the University of Glasgow in 2007. After discovering the world outside of a laboratory, she committed herself to conservation biology in 2008 when she moved to Paraguay. Two years later set up the first Para La Tierra scientific research station in 2010. She is PLT's Executive Director and is currently studying for an MA in Zoology from Miami University, Ohio. In 2012, she was announced a Rolex Awards for Enterprise Young Laureate.

Paul Smith – Paul graduated with an honors degree in Zoology and has a MRes in Osteoarcheology. He moved to Paraguay in 2005 where he fell in love with the country’s diverse wildlife. He is the founder of Fauna Paraguay, Paraguay’s largest online photo database. He is widely considered one of the country’s leading authorities on Paraguayan habitats and fauna. He is now Scientific Director of Para La Tierra, and has written more than 20 scientific papers on the wildlife of Laguna Blanca.

Joseph Sarvary – Joseph came to Paraguay in 2010 to work with PLT as our first intern. He conducted an ecological study on a population of Broad-headed Spiny Rat, a Cerrado keystone species. He returned three more times before being hired as Intern Supervisor in 2012. He graduated from Tufts University with a bachelor’s degree in Biology and is currently designing a scientific study to investigate the breeding behavior of the White-winged Nightjar.

Jean-Paul Brouard – JP is the latest addition to the PLT team. He has been hired as Museum Curator and Volunteer Coordinator. He has spent countless hours in the field in Southern Africa doing extensive field surveys on the Lepidoptera and Herpetofauna of the region. He has published numerous articles and contributed photographs into field guides in South Africa. He did a BSC in environmental management through UNISA. He volunteered at PLT in 2012 conducting an inventory on the butterflies of the reserve.

Rebecca Smith – Becca was first introduced to primates in 2008 as a volunteer in Namibia. She returned again to Africa twice more, eventually securing a position as Volunteer Coordinator after graduating from an honors degree in Zoology from the University of Edinburgh. Upon leaving Africa, she completed an MRes in Primate Biology, completing a thesis on rhesus macaques in Puerto Rico. After graduating in 2012 she took an internship in Panama with mantled howler monkeys and red-backed squirrel monkeys, before joining the PLT team as the Primate Project Leader.

 

 

 

 

WE ARE A REGISTERED UK SMALL CHARITY

After discovering the world outside of a laboratory, she committed herself to conservation biology in 2008 when she moved to Paraguay. Two years later set up the first Para La Tierra scientific research station in 2010. She is PLT's Executive Director and is currently studying for an MA in Zoology from Miami University, Ohio. In 2012, she was announced a Rolex Awards for Enterprise Young Laureate.
Paul Smith – Paul graduated with an honors degree in Zoology and has a MRes in Osteoarcheology. He moved to Paraguay in 2005 where he fell in love with the country’s diverse wildlife. He is the founder of Fauna Paraguay, Paraguay’s largest online photo database. He is widely considered one of the country’s leading authorities on Paraguayan habitats and fauna. He is now Scientific Director of Para La Tierra, and has written more than 20 scientific papers on the wildlife of Laguna Blanca.
Joseph Sarvary – Joseph came to Paraguay in 2010 to work with PLT as our first intern. He conducted an ecological study on a population of Broad-headed Spiny Rat, a Cerrado keystone species. He returned three more times before being hired as Intern Supervisor in 2012. He graduated from Tufts University with a bachelor’s degree in Biology and is currently designing a scientific study to investigate the breeding behavior of the White-winged Nightjar.
Jean-Paul Brouard – JP is the latest addition to the PLT team. He has been hired as Museum Curator and Volunteer Coordinator. He has spent countless hours in the field in Southern Africa doing extensive field surveys on the Lepidoptera and Herpetofauna of the region. He has published numerous articles and contributed photographs into field guides in South Africa. He did a BSC in environmental management through UNISA. He volunteered at PLT in 2012 conducting an inventory on the butterflies of the reserve.
Rebecca Smith – Becca was first introduced to primates in 2008 as a volunteer in Namibia. She returned again to Africa twice more, eventually securing a position as Volunteer Coordinator after graduating from an honors degree in Zoology from the University of Edinburgh. Upon leaving Africa, she completed an MRes in Primate Biology, completing a thesis on rhesus macaques in Puerto Rico. After graduating in 2012 she took an internship in Panama with mantled howler monkeys and red-backed squirrel monkeys, before joining the PLT team as the Primate Project Leader.
 
 
 
 
WE ARE A REGISTERED UK SMALL CHARITY

story:
Building a Better Future Together

S.D.E Ltd. was founded in 1996 and is the only wave energy company operating in Israel. Our technologies have been reviewed by independent examiners to be among the best in the world, but we need your help to make wave energy a reality!

Our goal is to build the first fully functional wave energy power-station in Israel and help green-up the beautiful City of Tel-Aviv. If this project proves to be successful we can be eligible to get the additional funding necessary to undertake projects that could provide up 12% of Israel’s entire energy supply. Our models have been approved by the Chief Scientist of the Israeli Government (certificate No. 23425)

The installations we use are extremely safe and we conduct strict environmental impact assessments (EIA’s) to make sure our technologies do not cause harm to the ecosystems and wildlife we share the planet with.

Israel has over 110km of wave breakers, seaports and marinas that if used more efficiently could relive a great portion of the country’s ecological footprint and greenhouse emissions. This project is set to be located in the port of Jaffa on the wave breaker located in “no-swimming”, “no-fishing”, “no-boating” area and does not affect the usage of the marine resource to the public.

Overcoming the Challenge

This project is currently competing in the Toradex Challenge:

https://challenge.toradex.com/projects/building-a-wave-energy-power-plant

It is also competing in the James Dyson Awards:

http://www.jamesdysonaward.org/Projects/Project.aspx?ID=3944&RegionId=1&Winindex=0

We already have past permits and plans approved by the city council from our previous operations in the port, but raising funds has proved to be a formidable challenge to overcome. If you search us on Google you will see that this plant was set to be built three years ago!

We require $1.5 million (USD) to insure that we can successfully build this station from A-Z. Any contribution helps because this project has potential to become the changing point for renewable energies in Israel.

By supporting this project on any level you can help offset your carbon footprint and get a bunch of unique thank you notes, pictures and certificates of appreciation from our team.

Anyone funding 25$ or more will get payed back and with 5.5% simple interest on their contribution per year. We will guarantee to repay the principal within five years or less. **If the project does not reach its funding goal the principal will be returned within 4 years or less with a 3% simple interest per year. 

   

The Impact

$1.5 million is not a lot of money in terms of what power-stations cost.

The goal might seem ambitious but is set-up like a Kiva “micro investment”. 6,000 people investing a mere $250 can make it happen.

With this one project we can provide enough clean electricity for over 3,000 people.

This is planed to be a 1 MW plant - around 3,000 homes.

It produces electricity at around $0.05 (five cents per KW/h). That is better than solar or wind.

The price of electricity in Israel  is fixed at $0.18 per KW/h. Revenue would be around $80K USD per month recovering the project in two to three years.  

This project is also the first of its kind in this region and can mark the beginning of a clean and low-cost renewable energy initiative. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything helps and every person can make an impact!

If you can, please share our campaign on social networks and feel free to mention us in your blog.

If you know any news editors or organizations that can help, please pass our information on.

Join Us on Facebook and Twitter 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/SDE-Sea-Waves-Energy/114225898721468

https://twitter.com/SDEenergyLTD


Thank You,

 

The S.D.E Team


SDE LTD
Lubetkin 15A
Tel-Aviv, Israel

story:
Hello! 

My name is Sinéad Reynolds and I am a 23 year old Masters by Research student at the University of Glasgow, studying Ecology and Environmental Biology.
I have been award an Amazon Scholarship by the Crees foundation am heading out to the Manu Biosphere in South-Eastern Peru to conduct research into the use of rainforest clay licks by large mammals - notably the fascinating South American Tapir and Red Brocket deer. 


Threatened by habitat loss, these animals are important species to focus on. The South American Tapir is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN red list, whilst the conservation status of Red Brocket remains undetermined due to lack of research. 

Whilst previous research has focused on avian use of clay licks, the importance of these sites to rainforest mammals has not been addressed. 

Using non-toxic paint marking, to help identify individuals, I aim to safely monitor how often these animals are returning to drink from the clay licks which will ultimately give insight into the importance of these areas to rainforest ecology.

What We Need

  • At around £200 for 1 camera trap, this is not a cheap venture! 
  • Ideally, we would like to raise enough for 6 camera traps - 3 at each clay lick site - however if we can raise for 3 or 4 this may also be possible or the study will be focused at a single site. 
  • All funds raised will go to camera trap equipment for the crees foundation.


The Impact

  • My project will contribute to the overall research being conducted by the Crees foundation. Based at the Manu Learning Centre in the Manu Biosphere Reserve, Crees strive towards a sustainable future for the Amazon. By working closely with local communities as well as researchers from all over the world, conservation issues can be tackled efficiently.
  • With little currently known about the use of clay licks by mammals, particularly in rain-forests, donations towards camera traps will allow us to begin to fill this gap in knowledge and potentially allow for a new method of large mammal population monitoring in rainforest ecosystems!
              
               Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, please share this campaign and help us reach our goal, enabling important conservation research. 

Thank you all for your interest in this exciting research and for any donations, in advance - check out the rewards at the right hand side of this page!

story:
WE REACHED OUR GOAL!

Thank You to everyone that contributed.  Thank You to all the chapters that met the Lori Lennox and Grays Harbor Chapter Challenge.  Thank You to all the state presidents that encouraged their members to spread the word.  And a special Thank You to the Foundation, a longtime supporter of the BCHA, that posted the $25,000 Challenge Grant – a Challenge that was met by the members and friends of the Back Country Horsemen of America. 

Beyond Grateful!

WE'RE ONLY HOURS AWAY FROM THE END! CAN WE PUSH TO REACH A STRETCH GOAL OF $65,000? 

All monies received over the $50,000 goal will be split 50/50 with BCH state organizations and chapters via the BCHA Education Foundation.

Let's keep pushing and sharing the incredible mission of BCHA through this campaign to see how far we can go!!!

Why the Campaign?

Because our trails on public lands need you. 

Like you, the men and women of Back Country Horsemen of America (BCHA) care about protecting and sustaining a safe and accessible outdoor experience for our families and future generations. But we can't do it alone. We count on our partners and you to help us preserve access to public lands. In 2012, only 37% of the 158,000 miles of National Forest Service trails received basic maintenance. Only one-quarter of these trails meet standard regulation for public use. 

Gaps of investment, oversight, and maintenance point to a future with fewer sustainable trails in our 144 National Forests. 

The funds from this campaign will increase BCHA's capacity to drive a national campaign to address the growing trail maintenance backlog on our public lands. BCHA, along with partner The Wilderness Society, have become the catalyst of a national discussion with Congress, agency leaders and the nation's recreation community regarding solutions for keeping trails open and enjoyable for everyone--hikers, hunters, anglers, bird-watchers, bicyclists and horsemen alike! With our decades-long track record of volunteerism and "sweat equity" in keeping America's trails open for you, BCHA's crowdfunding effort will secure our role in the campaign to secure sustainable solutions to the Nation's trail maintenance crisis.

Please take a few minutes to support and share our campaign! Trails may be owned by government entities, but volunteers are needed to keep them open and maintained. 

Who are the Back Country Horsemen?

BCHA are men and women who belong to a national non-profit organization. We are a 501(c)(3) serving 174 local and state chapters across the country. Our grassroots members—responsible leaders who help to carry forward our organization’s mission and values—lead BCHA organizations throughout the United States. BCHA chapters are active in 27 states consisting of over 13,000 members who are dedicated to keeping trails open for everyone on our public lands. Our chapters work closely with trail partners and local land management agencies to clear and maintain those trails. 


Are you a hiker, biker, or horseback rider who gets out and enjoys trails? We do much of the work that goes unseen to clear trails and preserve the safety and continued enjoyment of your outdoor experience. Yes, much of our work does in fact involve "horsepower" as well as human power. The majority of our pack trips with horses and mules are to assist trail crews get food, camping gear, and trail maintenance equipment into areas where four-wheeled vehicles cannot go.

Campaign Partners:

Our campaign partners below are equally committed to seeing that your trails remain accessible. Please take a minute to visit their websites to learn more about our partner's important work to keep trails open for you.



What Does BCHA Do?

In 2012, Back Country Horsemen of America volunteers spent 372,000 hours working to maintain trails on public lands.  That equates to a value of $12.5 million dollars in trail work donated to local and federal land managing agencies. Since 1995, BCHA members contributed a value equal to $86.66 million in volunteer hours. 


We invest in active participation by young leaders in the wise and sustainable use of wilderness and back country resources. We coordinate with conservation corps and youth groups, United States Forest Service, National Park Service, and Bureau of Land Management to ensure tomorrow's leaders have outdoor and wilderness experiences. As youth groups work with us and our partners, they learn about themselves and about stewardship of our most treasured resources. BCHA, its youth partners, and other volunteers leverage funds many times over in delivering projects to clear and maintain trails.

The costs to clear, maintain, work, and log trails are substantial. Responsible stewardship of the land means more than just doing good work—it means making the most out of every donation we receive.


The Crisis for America's Trails—And Our Solution

Trails serve as arteries for adventure throughout America’s system of public lands. Benefits provided to society from a robust system of publicly-accessible trails include improved fitness and well-being, opportunities to connect families and children with nature, tourism and economic growth related to outdoor recreation. The public loves and wants to stay connected with its national parks, national forests and public lands.

The U.S. Forest Service alone is responsible for over 158,000 miles of trails throughout 155 national forests and grasslands. Yet in 2012, the Forest Service was able to maintain only 37 percent of its trails. Only one-quarter of its trail miles meet agency standards for public use. Government resources to maintain trails have shrunk while public demand for trails in our national parks and forests continues to climb. The “backlog” in trail maintenance only grows worse each year. Despite increased volunteer efforts by Back Country Horsemen and others, our nation’s public lands are becoming increasingly inaccessible. 

The Crisis:

  • Deteriorating and often impassible trail conditions across the country
  • Backlog in trail maintenance and resultant trail closures
  • Lack of awareness among elected officials about the benefits of public trails
  • Diminishing agency budgets for outdoor recreation
  • Increasing demand for volunteer organizations like BCHA to maintain more trail miles each year

In 2013, the Government Accountability Office estimated that nearly a quarter of Forest Service trail maintenance comes from state funding, other federal and non-federal sources, and volunteers and partners like BCHA. This need is expected to grow as Congress continues to place low priority on public lands funding.

Our Solutions:

  • Strengthening BCHA’s capacity as a leading voice among public land and trail stewardship organizations
  • Demonstrating the wide range of institutions and organizations who care about, and depend upon, trail systems that course throughout our public lands
  • Amplifying the message and collaboration of Back Country Horsemen across the country to support increasing demand for volunteers on the ground maintaining our trails
  • Sustaining volunteerism by engaging today’s youth as the next generation of public land stewards
  • Advancing solutions to remove current barriers that prevent qualified volunteers from maintaining trails
  • Demonstrating the need for Congress to augment and support trail programs of our federal agency partners

How You Can Be Part of the Solution

Currently, nearly 100% of BCHA's funding is derived from two sources—from membership dues of and the generous contributions of our volunteer members. We have reached a tipping point when we can ask only so much more from our volunteers, who consistently donate more time and energy year after year. 

We are now asking for you to partner with us and our amazing volunteer members. We seek assistance from corporate sponsors, philanthropic foundations, and you through crowd-sourcing to share the responsibility for keeping trails open for everyone. Whether or not you've ever set foot on a trail, we know you want to ensure your kids or grandkids will have the opportunity. Please browse our incentives below and consider contributing today. These items will only be available throughout the 45 day life of this campaign. 

Press & Media:

Your Public Trails Need You | TheHorse.com | Ami McBride
Keeping Our Trails Open - BCHA | Horse-Journal.com
Back County Horsemen of America Needs Our Help | Idaho Horse Council
Keeping Trails Open for You campaign NOW LIVE | The NW Horse Source

The Perks:

$25 // Branded 
BCHA Limited Edition Stickers, BCHA Patch, and Key Tag

$50 // Wilderness 50th Anniversary Rustic Tea Lights 
Handmade Wooden Tea Light Holders (set of 3) | by JBcreationsNJ

$75 // Pioneer Sippin
BCHA Limited Edition handmade Pioneer Mug and BCHA Key Tag

$100 // Cookin' for Campin' w/BCHW

Long time BCHW member Susie Drougas was tired of the same old recipes and wanted to create a cook book with real, creative, and do-able recipes for camping and potlucks. She started organizing other BCHW members. Susie approached the BCHW board about turning this into a state fund raiser and offering to chair the committee; it was fully supported. Ninety-six members submitted over 250 recipes with everything from Dutch oven main dishes to saddlebag snacks to after the ride libations! The book is broken into 6 chapters with each divider having a different color photo taken from Susie's trail riding and camping trips. She dedicated the book to Ken & Carol Wilcox, BCHW founders, and to all the Back Country Horsemen members who help keep trails open to stock users.

$150 // Leather Lover
"BCHA and Keeping Trails Open for You" branded all-leather drink coozie, hair pin, and luggage tag.

$200 // Wyoming Cowboy Horseshoe Knife
One of a kind handmade knife made in a dim smoky shop from used horseshoe. Hours of heating, shaping, and coating to create this beautiful tool for the ranch. It comes with a hand sewn leather sheath that rides high without digging into the hip.  

$250 // Wilderness Survival 
"Surviving a Wilderness Emergency Kit" (1 emergency shelter, 1 metal match, 2 match cases, 1 whistle, 1 signal mirror, 1 first aid/survival manual, 6 ft of orange signaling tape, 1 Cordura pouch by Outdoor Safe, inc) and BCHA bandanna

$365 // Steward of The Land 
A steward is someone who willingly and sacrificially gives to another without any consideration of their worthiness to receive the gift or someone that gladly manages for the good of others. If you know of someone who exemplifies this person, this Steward of The Land, contribute at this level today and we will hand make a leather bracelet w copper snap to remind them that you believe they made this gift of sacrifice of time, energy, and efforts to help preserve our areas of great heritage, our trails and our land.

$1000 // Committed Rider
This incentive is for the passionate riders who align their love for riding horses alongside their support towards keeping our trails open and accessible in our public lands. The 5 individuals that choose this incentive will get limited edition handmade all-leather saddle bags made by saddle maker, Chris Tornow, a pair of all-leather BCHA branded spur straps, an all-leather BCHA branded hair-pin, and a BCHA bandanna. 

$1000 // South Dakota Heart | Mt. Rushmore Quilt
"Seeing Mt. Rushmore last year while at our BCHA National Board Meeting in Rapid City, was such a moving experience. And, wonder of wonders, while checking out a Rapid City fabric store, there was the panel of Mt. Rushmore! Being a long time quilter, I had to have the panel to create a quilt. And what better way for the quilt to find a good home is through the Back Country Horsemen of America. Included on the red, white and blue panel is a quote from each of the four presidents. There is a sleeve for hanging the quilt or you can use it for lap quilt.  May you enjoy “Heart of South Dakota” as much as I have in the process of creating it." Peg Greiwe Executive Secretary, Back Country Horsemen of America

$1750 // Ride with Chairman | Chickamauga Civil War Battlefield & Chattahoochee National Forest
Ride for two with BCHA Chairman Jim McGarvey and his wife Cindy.  Day One will be an historian guided tour of the famous Chickamauga Civil War battlefield.  Day Two will be a ride in the Cohutta Wilderness within the Chattahoochee National Forest. Trip includes three nights lodging, food, and travel arrangements from airport. This trip does not include airfare.

$2000 // Ride with Chairman | Great Smoky National Park (SOLD OUT)
Ride for two with BCHA Chairman Jim McGarvey and his wife Cindy at Great Smoky National Park.  Two full days of riding at the Park. Meals and Transportation included. Airfare not included.  Three nights of accommodations at the Lazy Horse Retreat near Townsend, TN. www.lazyhorseretreat.com.” Late Summer/Fall of 2014.

$2000 // Ride the Buffalo National River | NW Arkansas (SOLD OUT)
A ride for two with Buffalo River Back Country Horsemen on a 3 day 2 night riding trip along America's first National River! This unique riding experience includes 2 nights accommodation at the Arkansas Buffalo River Cabin, all meals, and transportation to and from airport if needed. You can bring your own horses or horses can be provided. For Spring or Summer 2015.

$3500 // Emigrant Wilderness Pack Trip

This pack trip will consist of 4 days and 3 nights in the heart of the Emigrant Wilderness near the Central Sierra Nevada mountains just 50 miles East of Oakdale, CA. This trip is for 2 people and will involve wilderness tent camping and dutch oven cooking. The offered times are for August of 2014 or August of 2015. This trip involves a 7 hour ride into the Buck Lakes located at 8,000 ft. This trip is for experienced riders and is offered by the Mid Valley Unit in California. 

$5000 // Back Country Immersion (SOLD OUT)

The pack trip will be conducted in the Three Sisters Wilderness sometime in the last two weeks in August of 2015.  The trip will be for a total of four (4) days for two (2) people riding the high mountain trails located on the west side of the Cascade range.  Whoever is awarded the trip must be very experience riders,  most of the trip is above timberline.  Riders will be treated to Dutch oven cooking, fishing and excellent photo ops.  This trip normally has a $ 8,000 price tag attached.

BCHA Chapter Challenge!

A special thank you to Back Country Horsemen of California for their $3,000 contribution!

Get your chapter's name on the list by supporting our campaign! To get your chapter's name recognized as a campaign supporter, follow these instructions: 1.) Click 'sign-up' in the upper right hand corner of our campaign page (actually sign-up, not log-in)  2.) Add the name of organization or chapter in the "First Name" section. There is no need to add a Last Name. 3.) Add the email address they want to have the account under. 4.) Proceed with all the correct payment information (name, numbers, etc.) 

Campaign Sponsors:

Other Ways to Support Our Campaign:

Be a campaign sharing champion! We need ALL of your help to share this campaign with all of your friends, colleagues, family, and networks.  Please consider doing one or all of the following throughout our 45 day campaign:

Share the campaign link by using the share features directly under the video above:

- On Facebook / with a photo of the work we do and trails we work hard to keep open
- On Twitter / use #bcha & include @BCHofAmerica
- In emails to your friends and family
- In emails to any trail users, hikers, writers, bloggers, outdoor magazines & publications

You can also organize a small pot-luck style event at home inviting your friends and setting up a computer to show them the campaign and explain BCHA's mission!

Become a Member of Back Country Horsemen! 
Contact: Peg Greiwe at peg@backcountryhorse.com
www.backcountryhorse.com
