story:
Short Summary

The Gene Memorial Tree Fund has been established by Marian, current tenant, who has had the pleasure of knowing Gene for more than 7 years. Along with the Cobble Hill Tree Association, we will plant a flowering pear tree with fencing and a memorial plaque in front of his house in Brooklyn. Please help us plant a fitting memorial to Gene's wit, sense of humour, and a life well lived.

What We Need & What You Get

The Cobble Hill Tree Association will cover 50% of the tree's cost. Our goal is to raise $400 towards the tree, $300 for fencing and $200 for the plaque. Donor's names will be shared with the family and contribution amounts will remain anonymous to all. Any additional raised funds will be donated to the family for the use of additional plantings in the tree bed and maintenance.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help by spreading the word and making some noise about the fund by using the Indiegogo share tools.

Also, we need ideas for what the plaque should say. Such as, "original founder of the Gowanus Yacht Club" suggested by Bill K!! The family will make the final choice for the inscription.

Thanks for your contribution!

Please note, the last name of the family has not been used in order to protect their privacy.

Please help us plant a fitting memorial to Gene's wit, sense of humour, and a life well lived.


What We Need & What You Get
The Cobble Hill Tree Association will cover 50% of the tree's cost. Our goal is to raise $400 towards the tree, $300 for fencing and $200 for the plaque. Donor's names will be shared with the family and contribution amounts will remain anonymous to all. Any additional raised funds will be donated to the family for the use of additional plantings in the tree bed and maintenance.
Other Ways You Can Help

Please help by spreading the word and making some noise about the fund by using the Indiegogo share tools.
Also, we need ideas for what the plaque should say. Such as, "original founder of the Gowanus Yacht Club" suggested by Bill K!! The family will make the final choice for the inscription.
Thanks for your contribution!
Please note, the last name of the family has not been used in order to protect their privacy.

story:
While researching to write an article onRecycling Plastic Bag Facts, I discovered numerous articles online about creative ways to reuse plastic bags. Even though there are some good ideas out there, most focus on reusing the plastic bag only once or several times.

For example, a website suggests wrapping a plastic bag â€œaround paintbrushes if you stop mid-project to prevent the paint from drying out.â€ You may think this is an excellent idea, however, what will happen to the plastic bag now that it is contaminated with paint? It is no longer suitable for recycling.

To be sustainable, we need to think of creative ways to reuse plastic bags as many times as possible making sure it stays contaminant free, that is, away from glues, paints, and other chemicals. When the plastic bag is no longer usable, recycle it at a facility suitable for plastic bags. This way, the plastic bag can be remade into something useful.

**Most curbside recycling programs actually do not accept plastic bags, do your research before putting plastic bags in the recycling bin.


Here my top 5 ways of reusing and recycling plastic bags:

  1. Always keep plastic bags (including grocery bags and bags from department stores) in your car. Reusing grocery bags is actually much more eco-friendly than using thicker tote bags made from cotton or non-woven fabric (lower carbon emissions).
  2. Bring used plastic bags to the supermarket. After unloading the purchased items at home, I always tie each bag in knots and bring them immediately back to the car. I find that if I leave them on my kitchen top, I tend to forget.
  3. Use DIY checkout counters so you can fill each bag with more items. You also have better control over how to load each bag. For bags that are about to break, I like to fill it with lighter items.
  4. Use plastic bags as trashcan liners for paper or dry items only. When emptying the wastebasket, do not throw out the plastic bag. Pour the contents into a larger trash bag for disposal.
  5. Store products using plastic bags at home. Theyâ€™re great for keeping dust away. You can also use plastic bags to sort items in your freezer. Bring plastic bags in your luggage case when traveling to store dirty clothing.

The key is to reuse AND recycle plastic bags. Every time you reuse a plastic bag, you`re lowering your carbon footprint and saving the environment for future generations to come.


Led by the government, or small independent art groups, cities everywhere are bursting with an array of ideas on how to decrease waste and make recycling initiatives more appealing to local residents. We've searched across the globe and found 6 brilliant recycling projects that have been making quite an impact since their inception. From a recycling awareness art project Warsaw tomandatory composting in San Francisco, jump ahead for our top 6 favorite recycling and reuse projects!

Read more: Top 6 Recycling and Reuse Initiatives from Around the Globe Olipot for Cooking Oil Recyling - Gallery Page 2 – Inhabitat - Sustainable Design Innovation, Eco Architecture, Green Building 


Recycle Everything in your Life! Start Recycling Everything If You Can't Reuse It!

You've heard of people recycling everything from printer paper to your old jeans, but you can recycle nearly everything in your life. If it can't be reused, then it most likely can be recycled instead. Car batteries and tires? Yes, those can be recycled. Can you recycle your old roof shingles? Yes! How about your shower curtain? Yes again! Find some creative ways to reduce the amount of stuff that you throw away in your life and be a little greener with the following list of 50 earth friendly tips.

Reduce your Carbon Footprint and Start Recycling Everything in your Life!

Here's a list of things that you can start recycling today...

1. Old bricks, worthless? No, those bricks can be recycled, and are very valuable to some people!


2. Use reclaimed wood for your next project at home. Use your own, or find some on freecycle, Craigslist, at your local transfer station, or recycle.net.

3. There are many places you can exchange or recycle your old electronics.

4. Sell off or post an ad for free metal scrap to be recycled.

5. If you have enough, your old VHS tapes can be recycled

6. Packing tape and stickers cannot be recycled, so use these sparingly in the first place.

7. Tools are very valuable items on eBay. Try selling them in lots to save time, shipping waste, and energy.

8. Empty propane tanks may be able to be taken as scrap metal, or properly disposed of at hazardous waste facilities. Reuse these whenever you can!

9. Even large items like BBQ grills can be recycled as scrap metal once the propane tank has been removed.

10. Kids toys have a new life when they're donated to thrift stores like Salvation Army or local churches.

11. Recycle your old prescription bottles, they have a million uses.

12. After they've been used up, recycle your old batteries.

13. How about other plastic numbers, what do those mean? You may be able to recycle some of them.

14. Flip flops can be recycled and repurposed a number of creative and unique ways.

15. Can't figure out what to do with your old lamps, wall decor, or knick knacks? If you can't eBay them, donate them to a thrift store for charity purposes. Craigslist and Kijiji are good alternatives, too.

16. Recycle your shipping styrofoam or reuse it.

17. Window treatments have the chance to live again as you recycle your curtains into pillows.

18. Carpet can be recycled if it is clean and usable.

19. Donate it, sell it, or recycle your television.

20. Stop by an Aveda location to recycle your bottle caps.

21. The rumor has been floating around that aluminum can't be recycled. While the rules may differ per town, you can still reuse it a few times by giving it a cleaning.

22. Reuse your old jeans in these 25 ingenious methods.

23. Why trash it? Your shower curtain is a great drop cloth or apron.

24. Your ink cartridges are accepted at many different locations online and in person, like Staples.

25. You might be able to trade in your old printer for a credit on a new one. They'll recycle it for you. There's always earth911, too.

26. Tires are a must to be recycled, and it's very easy.

27. Learn how you can recycle your roof shingles to become part of our roads.

28. Make sure when installing a new car battery that the mechanic will recycle it.

29. Cardboard boxes can be taken at your local recycling station, or sent curbside if they're small enough in most instances.

30. Save your old packing peanuts and recycle them by giving them to your local shipping company. They will gladly take them off your hands.

31. Your gently used clothing can be resold on eBay, or donated.

32. Good news! #5 plastics can be recycled at many Whole Foods locations.

33. Potato chip bags and those other foil packaging that often are used to wrap up junk food can be recycled at Terracycle.net.

34. Used (many times) ziploc containers and similar disposable plasticware can be recycled usually as #1 plastics.

35. Shaving cream metal cans are accepted in most recycling facilities with other metal cans.

36. Can tabs can be recycled with your cans. Don't pull them off, that kidney dialysis machine time rumor is false.

37. You couldn't have enough options to recycle your cellphone

38. Blankets can be recycled by donating them to animal shelters (if clean).

39. Recycle your own scrap wood and furniture by reusing it, or donate it.

40. Save that box and make some Pizza box art, or maybe just recycle it if you follow theseinstructions.

41. Mattresses, aerosol cans, even washing machines can be recycled.

42. Bread twist ties will be your new best friend after you read these creative uses.

43. Reading glasses can be recycled and donated, and are always in demand.

44. Old books can be sold on Amazon, donated to thrift stores, donated to schools, and to hospitals. There's always the yard sale option, too.

45. Freecycle your old sports equipment.

46. Did you know your old aluminum siding could be worth a lot of money?

47. Your old greeting cards can even be recycled creatively.

48. Wrapping paper is just paper and has many ways to be reused or recycled.

49. Don't forget all types of glass bottles can be recycled -- wine bottles, jelly jars, colored glass... these are all accepted at most recycling facilities.

50. Your old screened doors have many ways that they can be recycled.

story:
Short Summary

MuseArt is a company set up by 3 young women, our aim is to mobilise society and the youth in particular to pay attention to the global issues that impact their lives and inspire them to use their skills and passions in film, art, music, sport or science to better themselves and the world they live in.

The Plastic Oceans Exhibition focuses on the grave problem of plastic pollution. The planet is quickly becoming a tidal wave of plastic waste. Over half of the plastic we use is used only once and then thrown away.  the problem is that there is no “away”.  The impact on wildlife, the environment and the potential harm to human health are only now becoming clear.  The facts are that we have to do something and do it now. Brandon Boyd created a series of art to raise awareness about the islands of plastic floating about in the world's seas. We aim to showcase this artwork in South Africa to start a movement aimed at combating this problem because despite our vast shoreline (South Africa has impacts on both the Atlantic and Indian Oceans) , the issue has not been adequately raised amongst young people. We hope that through art we can inspire action to protect our seas.

What We Need & What You Get

MuseArt needs a total of $3 000 to make this awareness initative a reality and we're hoping to get some of that right here! The money raised will go towards hiring our exhibition space and shipping of the inspiring artwork half way across the world to do it's job in motivating young people to care for the ocean. Even if we don't reach our goal, every cent raised will go towards the exhibition, which we are adamant about going ahead with.

We have some great perks for donors, from little gifts of plush sea creatures, your name on our wall of heroes at the exhibition, to entry tickets to the actual exhibition (transport not included) as well as VIP tickets to our launch night.

 The Impact

Your contributions will help MuseArt take its first step on the issue of ocean pollution, the first step in what we aim to turn into an on-going initiative to save the seas. You will also be assisting us in our very first beach clean up initiative.

Other Ways You Can Help

EVERY bit helps, please do spread the word, share our initiative with your friends and if you are in Cape Town in December, make sure not to miss the Plastic Oceans Exhibition!!!!

story:
I am currently inspired and excited by my acceptance and upcoming participation in a 9 Day Natural Building Extravaganza (http://www.kleiwerks.org/natural-building-extravaganza) at Ashevillage Institute (http://ashevillage.org/) a nonprofit in Asheville, NC, that runs educational programs dedicated to sustainable solutions in action. It is an educational experience that I am eager to gain knowledge, inspiration and skills from so that I can apply them and share them in my life and communities around me, therefore expanding awareness through demonstration of how we might live more lightly upon the Earth...

The non-profit that is offering the workshop is called Kleiwerks International, (founded in 1998) which is a global network of natural building specialists collaborating with communities to create ecological and social resilience.  It is a woman-run organization whose main initiative is to support and train women leaders to construct, educate, organize, and advocate for strong and empowered communities through ecological design-build practices. I am inspired by their mission and share their vision of creating a way of life that incorporates principles of natural building, permaculture, community building and resiliency!

Here's a video to learn about KI’s history: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J4p5CspV-Mc   


There are so many things I love about the idea of natural building, including but not limited to:

*the sense of community provided when many hands work together to build something both useful and aesthetically beautiful

*the sense of harmony with nature that is acheived by using tried and true low-impact building practices based on locally-available and renewable resources- and knowing that it can all be returned gently into the Earth if ever need be...

*the sense of empowerment provided by the dependence on human labor and creativity (with an emphasis on simple, easy-to-learn techniques) rather than on capital, high technology and specialized skills

*Natural materials like stone, wood, straw and earth, on the other hand, are not only non-toxic, they are life-enhancing- clay, one of the most useful natural building materials, is also prized for its ability to absorb toxins and restore health

For more information regarding the "why's" of natural building, I found this to be a particularly helpful resource:

http://www.networkearth.org/naturalbuilding/natbild.html

I am hoping to return home from this workshop with an exhuberant energy to demonstrate and share what I have learned from it.  I am beginning the process of being in touch with town officials to get approval to do a community-based project (all-ages will be invited to be involved to collaborate on this) at our local community center, hopefully early fall.  I'm thinking a play hut for some shade from the very sunny playground, or at the very least, a bench under the shade at the woods edge.  This would be the first of many projects I would hope to facilitate in the area- providing an opportunity for community-building and learning that is in line with what I believe our true nature is as humans- to be in harmony with our environment.  I eventually, and before very long, hope to build a home for not only my own family, but also for others', preferably in an "ecovillage" setting, using these methods I will learn.

OK- now, here's the part where I ever-humbly invite you to support me on my journey ahead, and I thank you in advance for anything you are able to offer.  This means so much to me and I look forward to using what I learn in ways that help to heal our planet...

In order to attend this workshop, I will need to pay a tuition of $1111 (a strange amount, but something seems lucky about it, perhaps?) as well as $390 in airfare.  Beyond that, I have confirmed a friend's yard to be a place I can pitch a tent and camp out, as well as shower, prepare food from the market, etc. (Thank you, Victoria!) 

Would you be willing to help support my journey into this empowering movement by making a contribution? Any amount is welcome and so appreciated!

 

In appreciation of your support, I will add those who donate $5 or more to an email list where I will send out a daily photo/journal entry while I am there.  I will also keep you updated in the future of any related events/community projects I am facilitating so that you can come and try your hands (and heart!  and feet!) at natural building. 

In addition, I have some homemade items to offer as "perks", including:

 

For each donation of $10, choose ONE of the following:

"Eat Local" onesie with LLL logo  

One 4oz. jar of Homemade Tooth Powder

One bar of hand-felted (with locally grown wool) soap

 

 Construction wastes globally account for 40% of all waste, 40 % of goods, 40% of energy usage, and 18% of fresh water usage globally.  We as humans are in great need of detoxifying our lives and reducing our consumption.  One way to do this is to educate ourselves about building with natural materials and find ways to incorporate it into any future building projects we might have where it could be applicable.  I look forward to bringing this information and experience back home to New England, where we don't see a whole lot of natural building techniques being utilized, and become a leader and resource in the movement of bringing it back to Earth...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, no worries!  You can also help by spreading the word!  Please use the Indiegogo share tools to let others know about my campaign for support!  I am doing this as much to spread awareness as anything and would love for interested folks to know about it and get connected! 

 

 

 

 

***I'd like to take a moment to thank my Aunt Anne for enthusiastically being willing to come to NH and be with my girls for a large chunk of this time and as well my sister Jen and all the friends that have offered to help cover any needs we might have while I am gone.

Other Ways You Can Help

***I'd like to take a moment to thank my Aunt Anne for enthusiastically being willing to come to NH and be with my girls for a large chunk of this time and as well my sister Jen and all the friends that have offered to help cover any needs we might have while I am gone.

story:
The ocean deserves its own day

The ocean needs you - help expand World Oceans Day for a healthier future ocean!


UPDATE - January 6th, 2014

Happy new year everyone! There's just 4 days left in our campaign, and we need your help to raise more funds. It would mean the world to us if you could share our campaign with your friends, families, and social networks. Things are gearing up for World Oceans Day 2014 and we appreciate your support!

  • Tweet about us
  • Share a Facebook post
  • Send an email

The funds raised from this campaign will help grow the community and support the people who make this day possible with:

  • Free educational tools

  • Personal support

  • A better website

  • And more!


WORLD OCEANS DAY IS PEOPLE-POWERED

June 8th is World Oceans Day - when thousands of people around the world celebrate and take action to create a healthier ocean for everyone. Last year's World Oceans Day again was an inspiring experience. People around the world came together and took action for the ocean’s healthy future in a big way, with over 600 events in 70 different countries, held by aquariums, zoos, schools, businesses, local governments, moms, surfers, and so many more. These are people are reaching out in their own communities to do something to help protect the ocean and what it does for each one of us. The funds we raise from this campaign will go towards growing the community and supporting the people who make this day possible - with free educational tools, personal support, a better website, and more.

These events don't just happen on their own! World Oceans Day is a truly grass-roots effort, thanks to the hard work of many dedicated people all over the globe.

With hundreds of events last year that reached 1 million on Facebook and over 55,000 on Twitter - all on a shoestring budget - we're ready to do our part and make it a global rallying point for taking better care of our ocean.


While our actions on our own may seem inconsequential, together, collectively, we can and are making a real difference. Help us make World Oceans Day 2014 even bigger and better around the world. “Together we have the power to protect the ocean!”


HELP POWER A WORLD THAT IS BLUE

Earth is 70% ocean, yet we often focus 100% on land. Meanwhile the ocean, and the vital role it plays in human life, faces serious threats: massive overfishing, rampant plastic pollution, ocean acidification, climate change, and more. What will future generations inherit from us?

Our hope is for a healthy, thriving ocean that continues to connect people everywhere - from every country, culture, and creed across the planet.


The great news is that people in communities all over the world are caring more about the oceans every day and are taking action. The Ocean Project helps them by coordinating World Oceans Day, a day of action and celebration held globally every June 8th. We need your help to give these amazing people and organizations the support they need. We want to take this event to the next level by providing organizers with free tools and materials, growing the community and its impact, greatly improving our online engagement platforms, and much more.


SUPPORT & GROW THE IMPACT

Even though many of us don’t see the ocean daily, the ocean affects us and we affect the ocean. Our actions help protect it and the animals that call the ocean home. World Oceans Day is an opportunity to create widespread action and discussion about what we each can DO to keep it healthy.

Your personal contribution will help support our community of event organizers, and build World Oceans Day into a bigger global rallying point for celebration and action; it will be an even better day to unify organizations and capture people's imaginations around the world to create important changes, locally, nationally and internationally.

By supporting us with a gift for the ocean, we'll be able to:

  • Greatly improve the World Oceans Day online engagement platforms
  • Provide free educational materials and tools to event organizers
  • Work tirelessly to promote this event and empower our partners to be the best ocean ambassadors to their communities

And much more. With your help, we can collectively grow this event into a real force for change. Thank you!



AN OCEAN OF ACTION

There are too many World Oceans Day stories to share in this little space – read our 2013 wrap up to learn more about the wide variety of celebrations and people getting involved.

Partners around the world asked people to make an Ocean Promise on June 8th to do something for the ocean for the rest of the year. Hundreds participated and made a promise to help the ocean! Check out their promises here.



REWARDS

To thank you for your support, we've teamed up with Pergamo Paper Goods with ocean-themed art and stationary that is sure to delight you. Check out their website to see some awesome work!


BACKGROUND ON THE OCEAN PROJECT

Since its formation in the late 1990s, The Ocean Project has grown from a handful of founding North American aquariums into the world’s most extensive network for advancing ocean education and action. Our growing network includes approximately 2,000 partner aquariums, zoos, science, technology, and natural history museums, and other education and conservation organizations, agencies, and institutions in all 50 U.S. states and 80 other countries that together serve more than 400 million visitors each year. The Ocean Project seeks to build upon the work of existing institutions and organizations and spark meaningful engagement.

The concept for a “World Ocean Day” was first proposed in 1992 by the Government of Canada at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. As a result of a United Nations General Assembly resolution passed in December 2008, World Oceans Day is now officially recognized by the UN as June 8th each year

Since 2002, The Ocean Project has helped promote and coordinate World Oceans Day events worldwide. Each year an increasing number of countries and organizations have been marking June 8th as an opportunity to celebrate the world ocean and our personal connection to the sea, as well as get involved in helping protect our ocean.

The Ocean Project is a fiscally sponsored project of The Ocean Foundation. So we can thank you for your contribution, we will add you to our mailing list - but it's simple to unsubscribe with one click.


THANK YOU!

All the photos and footage in our campaign video came from our partner organizations and World Oceans Day event organizers. We thank them for their continued support and suggest you check them out.

  • Thanks to One World One Ocean for the amazing ocean footage.

  • Fish Eye Project
  • Stefanie Mathews at CleanLB
  • Simon Hall with Reef Safari and Shangri-La Fijian Resort & Spa
  • A Rocha Kenya
  • Kelly & Ken Tarsitano at Flagler Beachfront Winery
  • Low Isles Caretaker, Great Barrier Reef Australia
  • The Reef-World Foundation
  • Lost Chambers Aquarium, Atlantis The Palm
  • Kym Pollard of Aqua Planet Dive Centre and Charter, Shelly Beach, South Africa
  • Kalena de Brum of the Jo-Jikum Organization in Majuro, Marshall Islands
  • Saiful Rizal Marali at Wasan Vocational School's Eco Divers
  • Mrs. Smith's 2nd grade class at Del Rey Woods Elementary School
(Think you should be credited here? Email us at aisakower@theoceanproject.org)

story:
HUMBLE BEGINNINGS OF HUMANITY4WATER AWARDS

Kem Ra Joseph, one of our first Polar Bear Awardees with Omi, Derrick and their new baby girl

The Humanity4Water awards is an exciting international multicultural initiative which raises awareness about our planet’s wellness by bringing attention to facts about how we are actually treating Mother Earth, waterways, and humanity. One of the major ways we do so is by honoring the footsteps of unsung and sung planet heroes, and having themed award parties. The award was started by myself, Omileye Achikeobi-Lewis, and husband Derrick Lewis. It is in its seventh year. Last year we were so excited when we were invited to the United Nations to announce the 6th annual Humanity4Water Awardees.

HELP MAKE THE  HUMANITY4WATER AWARD 2014 PARTY FOR UNDERPRIVILEGED KIDS AND THEIR MOMS HAPPEN

We need to raise $500 in two weeks time by December 19th 2014 Why? Well, this year the Humanity4Water Award theme will be Honoring the Light of the Mothers and Children. As such we want to hold a children's party for underprivileged children and their mothers, who are often the forgotten leaders who will help light the way to creating a beautiful blue planet.

To honor the theme of the mothers and children being the lights of our tomorrow we will hold the Humanity4Water Awards on the winter solstice day, which is the shortest day of the year and marks the moment that our days begin to have more light. At the award party we will announce our Humanity4Water 7th year youth and adult awardees who will include local women and mothers who bring forth, protect and nurture our precious future every day. 

 In  2011 we held a Humanity4Water award party for local underprivileged children and it went down a treat. Read Lancaster News Article .

Pic from our 2011 Humanity4Water Award Party for the Kids


HOW CAN YOU HELP THE PARTY HAPPEN?

We really need your help to raise $500 in just two weeks to help make this party happen! We believe together we can make this happen. Party will happen at the Preston Blackmon Career Center in Lancaster South Carolina. Thanks!

story:
The Facts

Burnaby Residents Opposing Kinder Morgan Expansion (BROKE) is a grassroots community group located in Burnaby, British Columbia, on the unceded territory of the Musqueam, Squamish and Tsleil-Waututh First Nations. It was started in 2012 by a group of local residents impacted by an oil spill from the nearby TransMountain Pipeline, owned by Kinder Morgan.  Kinder Morgan has a project to triple the volume of oil shipped through our neighbourhood, and BROKE is being sued for interfering with work in a local conservation area:

  • The project is opposed by the City of Burnaby and 70% of local residents.
  • BROKE is a peaceful community group who organized picnics in the work area.
  • Kinder Morgan is claiming $5.6 million in damages against individuals named in the suit.

We need help to win in court and continue supporting our community against big oil. Maneuvering 400 supertankers a year through the narrows of beautiful Burrard Inlet will bring spills that foul the shores of Burnaby, Vancouver, and several other municipalities. 

The Help We Need

Fighting legal battles against a huge corporation is time consuming and expensive:

  • We must pay $20,000 for legal fees already incurred fighting an injunction and civil suit (against us).
  • We may face additional legal fees in the next months.
  • 100% of the funds raised will go to court battles against TransMountain Pipeline. 

The Impact

BROKE’s small group of members may face charges if Kinder Morgan wins, while our homes, schools, and parks will face increased danger from pipeline spills like the one we had in 2007.  We're standing up for our public lands, for the rights of First Nations who have not been properly consulted, and for the rights of our local government to decide what happens in our public parks.

  • Our members have legitimate concerns about local impacts and stopping global climate change.
  • Your support will help BROKE continue its opposition to the proposed Kinder Morgan Pipeline Expansion Project. 
  • This suit is also about civil liberties and free expression.  

Kinder-Morgan has launched this SLAPP suit (Strategic Lawsuit Against Public Participation) in an attempt to curtail genuine and legitimate participation by ordinary people. It is anti-democratic and we must not let people be silenced by threats of lawsuits for peaceful political activities. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks don't have the funds to donate. We understand! You can still help us by:

  • Sharing this page with your contacts
  • Visiting our website http://burnabypipelinewatch.ca/
  • Joining us on on Facebook
  • Following the trial coverage on the Vancouver Observer 


Every little thing helps!

story:
Klær kan inneholde miljøgifter. I treningstøy brukes det ofte antibakterielle stoffer for å motvirke vond lukt. Disse stoffene kan gjøre bakterier resistente mot antibiotika. Samtidig kjemper helsemyndigheter verden over en innbitt kamp for å hindre spredningen av antibiotikaresistente bakterier.

Det vil vi ha slutt på. Derfor skal vi analysere innholdet av antibakterielle stoffer i treningstøy. Men det er dyrt, og vi trenger din støtte for å kunne gjøre det.


Hvor utbredt er bruken av antibakterielle stoffer?

Antibakterielle stoffer brukes i en rekke forbrukerprodukter, blant annet:

  • Tannkrem
  • Deodoranter
  • Klær, særlig sportsklær
  • Sko
  • Skjærefjøler
  • Plaster
  • Mikrofiberkluter
I august undersøkte Framtiden i våre hender innholdet av antibakterielle stoffer i deodoranter, og fant ut at kjente merkevarer som Calvin Klein og Davidoff inneholder slike stoffer. Nå vil vi gå videre til klær. På sikt vil vi se på andre produktgrupper også.

Hvorfor trenger vi din støtte?

Framtiden i våre hender har begrensede budsjetter, og laboratorietester er dyrt. Med 10.000 dollar (ca 60.000 kroner) kan vi kartlegge store deler av sportstøymarkedet i Norge, og analysere forekomsten av antibakterielle stoffer i ca 10 produkter. En kartlegging, kombinert med laboratorietesting, vil bidra til å sette et kritisk søkelys på den utstrakte bruken av antibakterielle stoffer i klær. Målet er å få slutt på bruken. Med din hjelp kan vi klare det.


Hvor alvorlig er det?

Antibiotikaresistente bakterier kan sette medisinen hundre år tilbake i tid. Hudinfeksjoner kan bli dødelige. Rutineoperasjoner kan bli langt farligere. Tuberkulose og andre nesten utryddede sykdommer kan komme tilbake, og kirurgiske inngrep kan bli langt mer risikofylte enn i dag. Verdens helseorganisasjon (WHO) kaller antibiotikaresistens en av de mest alvorlige folkehelsetruslene verden står overfor.

Det er flere grunner til at antibiotikaresistente bakterier er på fremmarsj. En er for mye bruk av antibiotika i helsevesenet og landbruket. En annen er bruken av bakteriedrepende stoffer i hverdagsprodukter.

Mattilsynet har i mer enn 10 år jobbet for et europeisk forbud mot et av de vanligste antibakterielle stoffene: Triklosan. Miljødirektoratet mener at unødvendig bruk av antibakterielle stoffer, for eksempel i klær, bør stoppes.


Hva går pengene til?

  • Laboratorietesting av 10 plagg: 25.000,-
  • Innkjøp av 10 plagg: 10.000,-
  • Arbeid: 2 ukesverk: 25.000,-
  • Gebyr Indiegogo (4%): Ca 2.500,-
  • Totalt: 62.500,- (omtrent $ 10.000)

Hvem er vi?

Framtiden i våre hender er en av Norges største miljøorganisasjoner, med 23.000 medlemmer og 20 lokallag. Vi har arbeidet i 40 år for at det skal bli enklere å leve etisk og miljøvennlig. Vi setter ofte søkelyset på forbrukerprodukter og selskapene som produserer dem, fordi vi ser at dette ofte kan føre til raske endringer.

Vi ønsker å jobbe mer med miljøgifter framover. Mens klimaendringer og tap av naturmangfold får velfortjent mye oppmerksomhet, er miljøgifter et tema som i mindre grad dekkes av den norske miljøbevegelsen. Det ønsker vi å gjøre noe med.

Vi har jobbet lenge for at maten skal bli renere. I høst har vi gjennomført en test av deodoranter, og nå ønsker vi å følge opp med en test av klær.

er vi?

Norges største miljøorganisasjoner, med 23.000 medlemmer og 20 lokallag. Vi har
arbeidet i 40 år for at det skal bli enklere å leve etisk og miljøvennlig. Vi
setter ofte søkelyset på forbrukerprodukter og selskapene som produserer dem,
fordi vi ser at dette ofte kan føre til raske endringer. 
Vi ønsker å jobbe mer med miljøgifter
framover. Mens klimaendringer og tap av naturmangfold får velfortjent mye
oppmerksomhet, er miljøgifter et tema som i mindre grad dekkes av den norske
miljøbevegelsen. Det ønsker vi å gjøre noe med.
Vi har jobbet lenge for at maten skal bli renere. I høst har vi gjennomført en test av deodoranter, og nå ønsker vi å følge opp med en test av klær.

story:
Do you fish for Coho in the......

Puget Sound?

Snohomish/Skykomish River System?

If you do, this is for you!

Eagle Creek Hatchery is located on private property and operated solely by volunteers with limited funding.

Over 60,000 eyed-eggs, surplus from Wallace Hatchery, are hatched, raised, and released into the Skykomish River annually. This year we are home to over 88,000 fish!

Why is a private hatchery important? The surplus fish from the WDFW hatchery, if not kept local, would be given to other organizations and released in distant river systems. We need to keep these fish local!

Whether you fish the Sound or the rivers, from a boat or from shore, with friends or alone, get paid to fish or pay to fish, buy fishing gear or sell it, this directly benefits YOU!

Eagle Creek Hatchery is as ongoing project that brings community together!

More About the Hatchery

In mid-2009 Everett Steelhead and Salmon club took over the operations of the hatchery. The entire water system had been severely damaged in the 2007 floods and required total replacement. The hatchery is operational now, but in need of more upgrades to remain a safe and happy environment for the fish and our volunteers.

To see what we started with check out Hatchery- 2009 on the photo gallery menu.

http://www.everettsteelheadandsalmonclub.com/images/Photo_Gallery/index.html


What the Coho need!

The following list of repairs and upgrades will ensure the hatchery's existence and reduce the chance of fish mortality and injury to volunteers.

  • Rubber snakes - $27 (keeps the predators away)
  • 5 gallon plastic buckets - $40 (how we transport the fish between ponds)
  • Improved upstream water intakes - $2,400 (need steady water flow)
  • Emergency oxygen system - $800 (if we lose flow, we save fish)
  • Replacement of the small rearing pond (above ground pool) - $2,700
  • New  liner in the large pond (Firestone PondGuard) - $3,000
  • Weather resistant predator netting for both ponds - $720
  • Control valve excavation and replacement in four locations - $400

(these costs are materials, volunteers provide the labor)

    How You Can Help?

    Donations please!  Did I mention it's TAX DEDUCTIBLE!!

    Fishing guides: Think of it as job success- catching clients are happy clients.
           Retailers: Think of it as free advertising. Better fishing increases sales!
                Recreational fishermen: Think of it as good karma and improved odds!
                      Everyone else: Think of it as a fresh fish dinner!

    Please help us get the word out about this campaign by sending this to friends, relatives, fellow club members, politicians, retail outlets, marine repair shops, bait companies, and of course, wealthy people that like to donate to worthy causes!

    All fish released from Eagle Creek are adipose clipped (hatchery marked) fish! Yep, they are all clipped by volunteers!

    Visit and like the Eagle Creek Hatchery Facebook page:
    https://www.facebook.com/EagleCreekHatchery?ref=hl

    Enjoy this video of the adult Coho returning to Eagle Creek to spawn in 2013!
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5QFuznyr-mI

story:
It is not too late to make a donation.  We will continue our effort but all support now will be very welcome and remembered.

Our Vision

You’d like to buy products that are better for your family, as well as better for the planet – but to do that, you need answers to some basic questions. Does this product contain toxic ingredients? Was it made with renewable energy? Has the company taken steps to minimize waste in manufacturing, and then make the product recyclable?

EarthTouch provides you with a simple way to get the information you need to make smart choices.

When people vote with their wallets, companies listen. If everyone used their purchasing power to demand their products were made with clean energy, no harmful chemicals, and a reduced waste stream, companies would pay attention.


EarthTouch In The Press:

EcoWatch
Huffington Post
DailyKos
Yahoo Finance



EarthTouch will break new ground 

  • Independent evaluation – we'll provide a "just the facts" approach so you can make your own decisions about what to buy.
  • Multiple-categories – other apps only cover one product category. In order to shop effectively, you would need five different apps, cluttering up your phone.
  • Comprehensive – covering everything from clean energy to animal testing to product life cycle, you’ll have one app that gives you ALL the information you need.
  • Customizable – this is YOUR app. Set it to tell you about YOUR priorities.

Initially, EarthTouch will cover the following categories:

  • Packaged foods
  • Household cleaning products
  • Cosmetics
  • Clothing
  • Pet food

Consumers in the US alone spend over $1.2 trillion per year on these categories of products. After our rollout, we'll add more.


Referral Campaign

If your friends and followers donate you can get a commission and more.  
Check how simple it is here;
http://earthaccounting.com/blog/referrals/


Getting the data

The non-trivial part in any project like this is gathering the information to deliver to consumers.

In order to do that, Earth Accounting is forming a strategic partnership – the Alliance for Consumer Empowerment and Sustainability (ACES), an information cooperative that will put together all the data for EarthTouch.

We already have commitments from a wide range of eco-labels, environmental and government organizations, companies, and others who are providing the data we will deliver through EarthTouch.


The Team

Earth Accounting, a benefit corporation, was formed specifically to build EarthTouch. Our team brings years of experience to the table – from the worlds of business, tech, media, academia, and environmental research. 

Funding

The $40,000 we are raising here on Indiegogo will act as seed money, allowing us to grow the infrastructure we will need to make this happen:

  • Finalize the design for the initial product categories
  • Finalize the go-to market strategy 

Conclusion

We’re all in this together. That’s why we’re building the ACES cooperative, why we’re forming alliances with industry leaders, and why we’re asking YOU to join in.

We have a few perks for you – at the $25 level you’ll get an organic cotton shopping tote to help remind you to shop smart every time you go to the store (see below). At higher levels, we’ve got a cool perk – a solar-powered lamp from our friends at Buy Green (see below). But this campaign is about a lot more than the perks – it’s about the future.

Become a partner with us. Help us harness consumerism that is in balance with the needs of people, businesses, and the planet.  Let us build you the tools that will benefit our children for a healthier, sustainable future.

Help us make EarthTouch happen.


A perk for donors: An organic cotton Earth Accounting shopping bag.

Or, a solar charged boat lamp.



 To gift a donation in someone else's name during the holiday season, please send an email to mareka@earthaccounting.com. She will forward you this GIFT CERTIFICATE that you may print out and fill in for a co-worker or loved one. Thank you for your support and Happy Holidays from Earth Accounting.

Our founder and CEO Dr. Bruce Hector singing our vision and having some fun;

A candid of Co-Founder, Al, leading the way in one of our weekly brainstorming sessions

story: I am Frances Leader, Treasurer at Balcombe Community Protection Camp during the summer of 2013. I am retired and devote my entire time to campaigning for a Frack Free Planet. Contributions to this Campaign will assist our Protectors to travel to & from our present & future Camp sites, attend Court & cover their personal hardships as they defend our country against this dubious fossil fuel extraction method. We need to maintain a strong presence at every potential fracking site & convince our Government to think again about continuing to force its Corporate agenda on the British people. We want a green & sustainable future for our planet, we want renewable energy that does not pollute our water, air and land. We want this for ourselves, our children & all other lifeforms that share our precious planet and we want it NOW. Even if you cannot help us financially you can help us enormously by telling everyone about our campaign & why we MUST keep trying to stop this fracking nightmare from spreading sickness & misery around the world. Thank you for reading my plea.

story:
Where's the Rio Marañon anyway?

You've heard of the Amazon River, but have you thought about all of the tributaries that make it what it is? The Marañon, in Peru, is its hydrological source, meaning it contributes the most water to its final flow, and contributes massively to the general vitality of the Amazon basin. Did you know that the Marañon contains the Grand Canyon of South America?  Or that it, and therefore the Amazon, is under attack? I don't blame you! I didn't either, until Paddling with Purpose brought to my attention the 20 large dams proposed for the river's 1000+ mile stretch.

Look at those walls! Makes you want to protect that river, doesn't it?

I am a river guide from the United States with nearly a decade of experience, passionately in love with free flowing water. Rivers have sustained me in my adulthood and now it's time for me to put some of my river miles to good use and give back. This is my chance to help save one of the last free flowing rivers in South America from yet another big hydro project.*

Paddling with Purpose is partnering with Conservamos Por Naturaleza to raise awareness about the threats to this amazing river. Along with a group of Peruvians who are engineers, environmental and social lawyers, biologists, marketing professionals, graphic designers, and film makers, we will be filming a documentary about the Rio Marañon and launching a huge media campaign in Peru to inspire Peruvians to explore their country. In order to do this, we're going to the heart of it- a river trip through the Grand Canyon of South America.

Where's my money going?

Making movies and getting it out to LOTS of people costs money! There's cameras to pay for, software to edit the movie, the cost of producing the DVDs and distributing them. We need:

  • US$4000 for cameras and potential damages to them
  • US$1000 for the post-production of our film, and
  • US$3000 at least to promote the film throughout Peru. 

Getting people on the river cost money! Any of you who've ever done one know that. So firstly we need to pay for boats, frames, coolers, oars, PFDs (life vests), transportation and, of course, food! We need:

  • US$5000 for equipment rentals
  • US$3500 for food
  • US$3000 for transportation. 

Just me and some lovely people enjoying the rio!

I'm just one of many international volunteer river guides raising a portion of the cost of the project. Raising $20,000 altogether for this trip is just the bare bones minimum. Extra money we raise will go toward making a bigger impact with our advocacy campaign in the big cities and rural communities of Peru. And we will be better able to distribute the film throughout Peru, and the world! Even if I don't raise my goal of US$5000, the money I do raise will go first toward funding local Peruvians to go on the rafting trip. So give generously!

NOTE: I will be personally paying for my own transportation and gear expenses, including the flight to Lima! I can't stress enough that you are not funding my vacation to Peru, you're helping spread the word about a really poorly planned dam that will hurt Peruvians and the rest of the Amazon river basin.

Also, don't forget to check out all the cool things you can reward yourself with for supporting us in our mission to save the Marañon! 

What will this project accomplish?

Through its multimedia campaigns, Conservamos por Naturaleza has created an active and growing community of Peruvians who are exploring their natural heritage and taking an active role in its protection. Think of the Sierra Club's success to galvanize the US public into saving our Grand Canyon through massive media campaigns! A more recent example is the Patagonia Sin Respresas campaign, which successfully stopped dams in Chilean Patagonia.

Not only will this project help the 14% of Peruvians whose livelihood would be destroyed by a massive reservoir, but it also preserves the river for international travelers to enjoy! A river trip through the Grand Canyon in the United States has been called the trip of a lifetime. This could be another major river adventure destination. But only if it isn't turned into a reservoir first.

Risks & Challenges

Every project comes with risks. Of course, the challenges this campaign faces are nothing compared to those face by the river. There is always the potential that our efforts and the voices of the Peruvians directly affected will be drowned by the waters of yet another large dam, and by the money and power of huge corporations and the governments they're in bed with. We are doing everything we can do not let this happen.

With regards to our campaign, we risk having insufficient funds to leverage and effective media campaign in Peru. Filming on the river has obvious potential to damage the equipment and allows limited time to get the best shots. And of course, every whitewater river trip has inherent risk to the participants. But we are a group of professional, experienced guides who are committed to ensuring the safety of ourselves and our guests.

    I'm a dirtbag raft guide with no money, what can I do?

    I'm right there with you. Donating money can be daunting, especially when you're doing everything you can just to get by. But remember, literally every little bit helps. But, there are other things you can do to help! Share this page with YOUR parents and friends and family and let them know how much we care about rivers. Every little bit counts! Every river matters!

    Volunteer on another expedition with Paddling with Purpose. Go on a rafting trip down the Marañon with Sierra Rios.

    Go on a rafting or canoe trip on your local river, and learn about how important it is to your environment!

    LEARN about dams: Watch DamNation to learn more about the US history of dams. Read a book about dams- I highly recommend Deep Water byJacque Leslie, or if you want something a bit wonkier and harder to read, there's always the classic Cadillac Desert by Marc Reisner. 

    Raise a stink about protecting our precious rivers all over the world- consider getting engaged with your local conservation groups or bigger ones like American Rivers or International Rivers.





    *I want to say a little bit more about big hydro, because I find that my opposition to big dams is not easily understood, or even close to universally held. Recently, Costa Rica made news for having generated the last couple months of power solely through "renewable" energy. The majority of that power is coming from hydroelectric dams in the country. But are dams renewable? Is hydropower green? Maybe not. Dams, we are finding out, contribute heavily to global warming through the emission of massive amounts of methane being released from the sediment buildup behind them. They contribute, also, to increasing salinity in our soils, a sure death knell for the previously rich and productive soils that produce much of the world's agriculture. Also, dams have limited lifespans, depending on a variety of factors, such as sedimentation load, seismic factors, evaporation, and upkeep costs. Not only that, but when we take into consideration the cost of removing dams, which always has to happen at some point, the benefits of building them in the first place don't look so good. So much for sustainable, so much for "green".

    Next, let's take a look at the direct human consequences. Just like building the interstate system in the US required displacement of people, so does building dams. To the tune of nearly half a billion people; mostly already impoverished people. The resettlement and displacement due to dams cause greater poverty, often alcoholism, and cultural destruction to the displaced people. The large corporations that fund big dams rarely account for the cost of compensating the people who live upstream of the dam, and leave that part up to the government of the developing country, which either doesn't or can't deliver on its promises. What's more, the people who live next to these life-giving rivers rarely want to leave. Sometimes they never even hear about the projects until they're already being built, and are forced, nightmarishly, to leave abruptly and forced onto unproductive lands with little or no money, no water, and no electricity to start them off. All of this is largely in the name of "development." So much for that.

    I will leave you with a thought from Jacques Leslie's incredible book Deep Water:

    "The larger the dam, the more expensive its dismantling becomes, until, in the case of a hydroelectric megadam, the expense may surpass the cost of erecting it. Imagine these dams in five hundred or a thousand years, after their useful life has ended, when an earthquake from the fault line beneath Sardar Sarovar fractures it, or the bankruptcy of Zambia and Zimbabwe leads to Kariba's fatal neglect, or Three Gorges fills with sediment, or Katse gets too expensive to maintain--and when every one of them suffers from an altered hydrological regime as a result of climate change. Take your pick of mortal scenario: cumulatively, they're more plausible than the assumption that megadams will be successfully financed, adroitly managed, and properly maintained into perpetuity. Some dams will crumble into the basins from which they rose, while others may still be intact but no longer storing water, which instead runs over or through or around them. They'll be relics of the twentieth century, like Stalinism and gasoline-powered cars, symbols of the allure of technology and its transience, of the top-down, growth-at-all-costs era of development and international banks, of the delusion that humans are exempt from nature's dominion, of greed and indifference to suffering. If there are tourists then, they'll circulate through the ruins and they now inspect the Pyramids, awed by the structures' technological prowess and unimaginable cost. The people who lived around the dams will have been dispersed, of course, and their cultures shattered, and the rivers and their valleys may still be depleted. But the dams' ephemerality, not the rivers', will then be on display. They'll be reminders of an ancient time when humans believed they could vanquish nature, and found themselves vanquished instead."

Go on a rafting or canoe trip on your local river, and learn about how important it is to your environment!
LEARN about dams: Watch DamNation to learn more about the US history of dams. Read a book about dams- I highly recommend Deep Water byJacque Leslie, or if you want something a bit wonkier and harder to read, there's always the classic Cadillac Desert by Marc Reisner. 
Raise a stink about protecting our precious rivers all over the world- consider getting engaged with your local conservation groups or bigger ones like American Rivers or International Rivers.




*I want to say a little bit more about big hydro, because I find that my opposition to big dams is not easily understood, or even close to universally held. Recently, Costa Rica made news for having generated the last couple months of power solely through "renewable" energy. The majority of that power is coming from hydroelectric dams in the country. But are dams renewable? Is hydropower green? Maybe not. Dams, we are finding out, contribute heavily to global warming through the emission of massive amounts of methane being released from the sediment buildup behind them. They contribute, also, to increasing salinity in our soils, a sure death knell for the previously rich and productive soils that produce much of the world's agriculture. Also, dams have limited lifespans, depending on a variety of factors, such as sedimentation load, seismic factors, evaporation, and upkeep costs. Not only that, but when we take into consideration the cost of removing dams, which always has to happen at some point, the benefits of building them in the first place don't look so good. So much for sustainable, so much for "green".
Next, let's take a look at the direct human consequences. Just like building the interstate system in the US required displacement of people, so does building dams. To the tune of nearly half a billion people; mostly already impoverished people. The resettlement and displacement due to dams cause greater poverty, often alcoholism, and cultural destruction to the displaced people. The large corporations that fund big dams rarely account for the cost of compensating the people who live upstream of the dam, and leave that part up to the government of the developing country, which either doesn't or can't deliver on its promises. What's more, the people who live next to these life-giving rivers rarely want to leave. Sometimes they never even hear about the projects until they're already being built, and are forced, nightmarishly, to leave abruptly and forced onto unproductive lands with little or no money, no water, and no electricity to start them off. All of this is largely in the name of "development." So much for that.
I will leave you with a thought from Jacques Leslie's incredible book Deep Water:
"The larger the dam, the more expensive its dismantling becomes, until, in the case of a hydroelectric megadam, the expense may surpass the cost of erecting it. Imagine these dams in five hundred or a thousand years, after their useful life has ended, when an earthquake from the fault line beneath Sardar Sarovar fractures it, or the bankruptcy of Zambia and Zimbabwe leads to Kariba's fatal neglect, or Three Gorges fills with sediment, or Katse gets too expensive to maintain--and when every one of them suffers from an altered hydrological regime as a result of climate change. Take your pick of mortal scenario: cumulatively, they're more plausible than the assumption that megadams will be successfully financed, adroitly managed, and properly maintained into perpetuity. Some dams will crumble into the basins from which they rose, while others may still be intact but no longer storing water, which instead runs over or through or around them. They'll be relics of the twentieth century, like Stalinism and gasoline-powered cars, symbols of the allure of technology and its transience, of the top-down, growth-at-all-costs era of development and international banks, of the delusion that humans are exempt from nature's dominion, of greed and indifference to suffering. If there are tourists then, they'll circulate through the ruins and they now inspect the Pyramids, awed by the structures' technological prowess and unimaginable cost. The people who lived around the dams will have been dispersed, of course, and their cultures shattered, and the rivers and their valleys may still be depleted. But the dams' ephemerality, not the rivers', will then be on display. They'll be reminders of an ancient time when humans believed they could vanquish nature, and found themselves vanquished instead."

story:
WCFF STORY
October 16-25, 2015
New York, NY

The Wildlife Conservation Film Festival is the premier global event that celebrates and informs people on the importance of preserving global biodiversity. The WCFF will celebrate its 5th year in October 2015 and will feature over 90 films representing 30 countries. This year we include a biodiversity conference that takes place at John Jay College and New York York University. Also new this year is weekend retreat to the Black Rock Forest Consortium, a 4,000 acre wilderness preserve in the Catskills for vising film producers, scientists and donors.

The WCFF has become an integral part of the conservation and cultural landscape of New York City. The event has been identified by scientists such as Dr. Birute' Mary Galdikas, Dr. Sylvia Earle and HRH Prince Khaled bin Sultan as one of the most import conservation events on the planet. The WCFF continues to leverage the power of film to inform, inspire and enlighten people about the importance of preserving the earth’s biodiversity.

                        Ambassador Ian Redmond of the United Nations
                                Environment Program (UNEP), tells the world
                                                   why the WCFF is important!

                                Wildlife Filmmaker & Anti-Poaching Ranger,
                                          Matt Bracken at the WCFF

The documentaries showcased at WCFF are made by leading conservationists and filmmakers, many of whom are on the front lines of international wildlife conservation efforts. The WCFF stands as the foremost venue for wildlife filmmakers across the globe to present their work to an international audience.

The documentaries range from feature films such as Game of Lions narrated by Academy Award Winner Jeremy Irons and produced by world famous wildlife filmmakers Beverly & Dereck Joubert to shorts as Isla Hilbox: Whale Shark Island, narrated by Dr. Sylvia Earle. Every film series has a panel discussion with one of the film producers and/or esteemed wildlife conservationist that is an expert in the species or ecosystem related to the films.

             "Game of Lions" produced by Dereck & Beverly Joubert
                    Narrated by Academy Award Winner Jeremy Irons

                              "Hope" featuring Sir David Attenborough
                                        at the Karisoke Research Center

                                        "Isla Holbox: Whale Shark Island"
                                              Narrated by Dr. Sylvia Earle

WCFF is more than a film festival, it is also a conference, an education program that informs, engages and inspires thousands of secondary, post secondary students, inspiring and veteran film producers, wildlife conservationists and the general population that travel from across the globe to attend.

Throughout the year the WCFF hosts monthly film screenings, receptions, and a education outreach program for students. During the annual film festival and conference attendees have the opportunity to interact and network face-to-face with international filmmakers, scientists and some of the world’s most respected conservation leaders.

Attendees in 2015 will include world-renowned primatologists, Dr. Biruté Mary Galdikas and Dr. Patricia C. Wright, Emmy award winning producers David Hamlin, Bob Poole and Irene Magafan. Film producers are coming from Kenya, South Africa, India, Turkey, Germany, Iran, Canada and Sweden to name just a few countries.

The WCFF Gala & Awards Ceremony is planned for Friday, October 23. The Gala has been identified as one of the premiere conservation events in the country with international experts in wildlife conservation, film, fashion and sports personalities, foreign dignitaries, international royalty, political figures and prominent New Yorkers.

                   Virginia McKenna, BAFTA Award winning actress, co-star of                               blockbuster film "Born Free" and Founder of Born Free
                     Foundation along with Adam Roberts speak to the audience
                                                  at the 2013 WCFF in New York

WHY THE WCFF IS IMPORTANT

The WCFF is the only film festival on the globe dedicated to spreading the word of the importance of preserving global biodiversity. We foster relationships between international filmmakers, world's leading conservationists and scientists with the audience.

WHAT WE NEED

We are seeking $35,000 -$50,000 to help with some of the costs for the WCFF to continue providing exceptional education programs through the film festival and biodiversity conference. This will allow thousands of students, teachers and adults across the globe to be informed, engaged and inspired for the need to protect global biodiversity.

EXCITING REWARDS

We have a number of unique perks (see that section) to reward generous donors to help achieve our goal.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Join the "Friends of the WCFF" or make a tax deductible contribution to support our ongoing work to promote the preservation of global biodiversity. Contact: Christopher@wcff.org

SPREAD THE WORD

Tell your friends about the WCFF and send them to: www.WCFF-NYC.org

 Join us for the 2015 WCFF & Biodiversity Conference
 October 16-25 in New York, NY

WE NEED YOUR FINANCIAL SUPPORT!

Expenses to host this film festival include but are not limited to:

  • Theater Rental
  • Advertising
  • Public Relations
  • Liability Insurance
  • Legal fees
  • Printed material
  • Lifetime achievement awards
  • Awards for film category winners
  • Acquisition fees
  • Reception venue rentals
  • Biodiversity conference venue rental
  • Travel expenses for WCFF volunteer team
  • Posters, flyers, trailers
  • Flights & hotel for selected film producers
  • Educational outreach program for secondary & postsecondary students
  • and much more...

story:
ecoCOMP Electronics Service and Recycling:

My name is Evan Snow of Rochester, New York.  I was raised to believe that responsible conservation is the best way of protecting the environment, rather than oppressive regulations.  I was blessed to have parents that felt that their children should experience all that life had to offer, which led to my father exposing us all to the latest technology as well as the great outdoors.  This started a lifelong interest in technology with me and how it could improve the world.

A Little About Me:

In 1993, I had my first professional job as a PC Technician, and I have always kept my skills current.  I began to notice a growing concern as computers and other tech evolved, called e-waste.  As you can see by the video, the current US model is to dump all e-waste onto third world countries for marginal recycling.  This doesn't have to be this way.  In New York State, recycling centers built with taxpayer dollars are quietly being closed, and consumers are facing fines for trying to dispose of old electronics, especially old televisions.  At ecoCOMP, we collect and disassemble all electronics for responsible recycling.  Any working equipment we gather gets reconditioned and available for purchase at a fair price for consumers.  All data on old computers and cellphones is wiped completely, protecting privacy.

Enter ecoCOMP:

Founded in September 2012, ecoCOMP was started when I participated in the Green For Gold program.  This program helped me to get all the necessary certifications to start a Green business.  The set goal was to provide the community with an accessible place to drop off their old electronics for recycling, rather than letting them end up in a landfill, poisoning the environment.  Unfortunately, shortly after getting the business started, the program was abruptly ended before the start-up funds were provided.  To help offset the costs involved, ecoCOMP began to offer computer and electronics service, cellphone repairs and data wipe/recovery, to mention a few of the services.

              

Newer, Better Facilities!

The original location proved to be less than ideal, which led to a search for a better location.  In November of 2013, a much better location was found at 785 Spencerport Road, Rochester.  Easy access, triple the space and visibility has definitely helped.  In addition to the store services, I am offering free classes to senior citizens, e-waste educational materials, free cellphone and electronics recycling drop off and local pick-up service.  We are also providing space for a local cultural dance company to practice, as well as various community classes offered locally.  The move was costly, yet it was necessary to provide the community with a much needed service.


Why We Need Your Help:

Funds that were available to facilities like ecoCOMP are no longer available due to budget cuts.  Costs for processing e-waste for recycling have increased as a result.  To offset these added costs, I am expanding the service available on computers, cellphones, tablets, televisions, etc.  I am seeking funding to pay for classroom materials,  website launch, repair parts inventory, utility costs and facility upgrades to make the new location more energy efficient by upgrading the lighting, signage and windows.  Also needed are funds to repair the current van used for pick-up and transport.  Thank you for your time and kind consideration, as you read through my campaign.  If you have any questions, feel free to contact me at evan.e.snow@gmail.com.  Thank you for doing your part for the environment, every little bit will help us to save our environment!

story:
This morning (February 8, 2017), Sea Turtle Conservation Bonaire (STCB) staff received a call on the STCB Hotline. Nolly, a local Divemaster, had found a stranded Olive Ridley turtle on the East coast of Bonaire, close to the Willemstoren Lighthouse. 

After a first assessment by STCB's Project Coordinator, it became clear that the turtle, which was immediately named after its rescuer by STCB volunteers, is missing her front left flipper. In addition, 'Nolly' has a deep wound on her left side - possibly caused by the stranding. However, at the moment we don't know what caused 'Nolly' to become washed up on the shores of Bonaire.

As Bonaire is a small island and fortunately strandings are rare, there are no permanent rehabilitation facilities. Therefore, STCB needs to raise money to help with the costs of setting up an assessment tank for 'Nolly', and for all the associated costs, such as x-rays, medication and nutrition.

Sadly, in quite a large percentage of the time, a stranded sea turtle cannot be saved, even with much more specialised services than we can offer. To at least give 'Nolly' a chance of survival, we ask for your help. 

Your Donation Will Be Used To...

... Set up an assessment tank with pump etcetera

... X-rays

... Veterinary costs

... Medication

... Nutrition

You Can Also Help By

  • Sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or by e-mail.
  • Liking us on Facebook, following us on Instagram!
  • Signing up for our newsletter, via our website.

To learn more about the work that we do, please check out our website.

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign to help 'Nolly'!

If STCB raises more than what's needed to help 'Nolly', the extra donations will also go towards saving Bonaire's endangered sea turtles. Please have a look at our website (www.bonaireturtles.org) to find out what we do to help!

story:
Since it's inception, The Green Suite has been on a Mission to save the world. With innovative classes, hydroponic kits and recycled products, Nick Conrad has shared his eco-obsession with countless future green-o-philes in the Chicago area. Despite this success, Nick was looking for a bigger way to expand his audience and have a greater impact. The solution, quickly revealed itself: a DIY, sustainable showroom on wheels. Enter The Green Van Project.

With a goal of 15,000, this eco-prototype will test the limits of a mobile yet sustainable lifestyle. The more money that can be raised, the more features will be added to The Green Van. This project is a culmination of five years worth of R+D in solar electricity and hydroponics and will prove just how far a DIY green lifestyle can take you. Taking  the tiny house concept a step farther, the goal of this project is to combine every off-grid necessity into the compact space of a Dodge Sprinter. Once completed, The Green Van will be mobile classroom/laboratory/workshop/micro house all rolled into one sleek, well-designed package. 

Plans to include:

  • eco-friendly, veggie fuel system to recycle used cooking oil into fuel
  • regenerative water system to recycle rain water 
  • solar panels on the roof to power on-board electrical system
  • composting toilet and worm bin to turn waste into soil
  • multi-purpose internal furniture for maximum use of space
  • sleeping area for up to four people 
  • roof top deck and storage rack
  • integrated soil and hydroponic garden
  • compact, propane powered kitchen for organic, on the road cooking
  • hot and cold running water system complete with shower  

Only with your help can The Green Van Project bloom into a reality.  Support today and The Green Van might be rolling to a city near you!


As seen on:
