story:
Rangeland Solutions just launched a new campaign! http://igg.me/at/rangelandsolutions


Thanks to everyone who donated to our campaign! Thanks to our Indiegogo campaign and outside donations, we raised $8,000. For updates on the progress of the pilot project visit our our blog and Facebook page.  Thank you again everyone for all of your support!


Rangeland Solutions, Inc.

Overview

Rangeland Solutions is an innovative social not-for-profit business with the mission to provide sustainable income-generating opportunities to pastoralists, by restoring the local ecosystem and utilizing better rangeland and livestock management techniques to increase the productivity of the land and livestock.

Working through community-based field staff, Rangeland Solutions partners with pastoralist groups to provide them the resources, training and support they need to implement Holistic Management, a ranch planning system. This unique approach to rangeland management has been shown to rehabilitate habitats by reducing overgrazing and erosion and enhancing natural processes, thereby increasing land productivity and generating significantly higher rates of beef production.

Overall, this approach has the potential to significantly improve the livelihoods of pastoralists, who are often some of the poorest and most marginalized members of society, while reversing the processes of desertification and climate change, which threaten our planet.

Problem

The livestock sector is an important global player with significant and wide-ranging social, economic and environmental impacts.  Worldwide, livestock production provides livelihoods for 1 billion of the world’s poor.  However, the livestock sector is also a major driver of deforestation, land degradation, pollution, climate change and biodiversity loss.

Kenya is a clear illustration of livestock’s complex social, economic and environmental role.  In the Arid and Semi-Arid Lands (ASALs) of Kenya, which constitute 80 percent of the country, the livestock sector provides livelihoods for 95 percent of families and employs 10 million people. 

However, pastoralism in ASALs faces many challenges.  Population and livestock growth has led to overgrazing, creating a negative-feedback system of environmental degradation, reduced livestock yields and greater poverty.  In addition, pastoralists lack access to capital, markets and extension services, such as veterinary care.  The lack of these services is a major detriment to pastoralist income and livelihoods and inhibits market efficiency.

Solution

Holistic Management (HM) is a Ranch Planning System that helps pastoralists better manage agricultural resources. In this system land is managed on a large-scale and the livestock are grazed in concentrated groups, mimicking wild herds, within demarcated areas. The cattle are moved daily, rotating through the landscape, allowing previously grazed grass enough time to regenerate.

This form of management is shown to rehabilitate habitats by reducing overgrazing and erosion and enhancing natural processes, such as nutrient and water cycling.  As a result, land productivity increases, generating higher beef production rates of up to 50 percent, and ROA up to 200 percent ; while sequestering carbon into the soil at 0.1-5.3 T C · ha-1 · yr-1(Roughly equivalent to removing 1-2 cars off the road).

Business Model

Rangeland Solutions will be a social enterprise that engages pastoralists in the practice of Holistic Management.  Rangeland Solutions will become involved in the value chain by providing needed services to small-scale livestock producers, such as access to financing, livestock inputs, and training.  In addition, Rangeland Solutions will act as a transactional intermediary, helping small-scale pastoralists sell their livestock into larger-scale commercial markets, thereby addressing the missing market linkages between small producers and large-scale buyers.

In the initial phase, Rangeland Solutions will work with community members to form Pastoralist Production Groups (PPG).  Once formed, Rangeland Solutions will provide training on Holisitic Management, as well as build a waterhole for livestock and provide grass seeds for reseeding (At no cost).  Rangeland Solutions will also help PPGs market their livestock as a group and sell them into larger-scale commercial markets, providing pastoralists with better access to terminal markets and higher prices.  As part of the arrangement, Rangeland Solutions will have the rights to raise cattle on the lands of the PPGs for five years, at no cost.  This approach allows Rangeland Solutions to make back its original investment, while turning a small profit.

Each PPG requires approximately $5,000 USD in initial investment to begin, or less than $500 per pastoralist family (Dependent on number of families in each PPG)

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need

We are currently in the process of starting our first pilot project, which will act as our "proof-of-concept".  We plan on launching it in Spring 2014, in the village of Olekimunke (100 km south of Nairobi), where Rangeland Solutions previously conducted research and has established communal ties.  The pilot project will involve forming one PPG, in which we hope to sign up 10-15 pastoral families.  This initial PPG will help Rangeland Solutions to test our model and work out any issues.  In addition, it will be used as a demonstration site for other pastoralists to see the intended outcomes and benefits.

As mentioned above, it costs approximately $5,000 to start each PPG, and we need your help to raise that amount. You can donate any amount.

What You Get In Return:

Many of the pastoralists we work with are Maasai and we would like to share a bit of their culture with you.
  • Maasai Herder ($25): Receive a beautiful beaded bracelet, hand-crafted by Maasai women from the communities we work in.  These are wonderful items, worn by almost every Maasai person.
         
  • Maasai Warrior ($75): Do you want to dress like a Maasai warrior? Of course you do.  At this level you will receive a traditional Maasai shuka, worn by warriors (Warani) during cold nights out in the bush.  This is a versatile piece of clothing that can be used as a blanket, towel or sweater.    
        
  • Maasai Elder ($150):  Receive a leather beaded belt, hand-crafted by Maasai women from the communities we work in.  This is a wonderful accessory to brighten up any outfit.
        

  • Maasai Village Elder ($500): Help support a pastoralist family and receive all of the items listed above, plus a profile of the family you support (including photos).
  • Maasai Village Chief ($1,000): Help support two pastoralist families and receive all of the items listed above, including profiles of both families, as well as a ceremonial club (rungu). These are carried by elders to signify their status.
      

Other Ways You Can Help

There are lots of ways you can still help Rangeland Solutions and contribute to a more sustainable future.

Be Social:
Follow us on Twitter - retweet our tweets
Follow our blog
Like us on Facebook and share us on your timeline

Last, always consider how your food choices impact the environment and people.
story_txt:
Rangeland Solutions just launched a new campaign! http://igg.me/at/rangelandsolutions
Thanks to everyone who donated to our campaign! Thanks to our Indiegogo campaign and outside donations, we raised $8,000. For updates on the progress of the pilot project visit our our blog and Facebook page.  Thank you again everyone for all of your support!
Rangeland Solutions, Inc.
Overview

Rangeland Solutions is an innovative social not-for-profit business with
the mission to provide sustainable income-generating opportunities to
pastoralists, by restoring the local ecosystem and utilizing better rangeland
and livestock management techniques to increase the productivity of the land
and livestock.
Working through community-based field staff, Rangeland
Solutions partners with pastoralist groups to provide them the resources,
training and support they need to implement Holistic Management, a ranch
planning system. This unique approach to rangeland management has been shown to
rehabilitate habitats by reducing overgrazing and erosion and enhancing natural
processes, thereby increasing land productivity and generating significantly
higher rates of beef production.

Overall, this approach has the potential to
significantly improve the livelihoods of pastoralists, who are often some of
the poorest and most marginalized members of society, while reversing the
processes of desertification and climate change, which threaten our planet.Problem
The livestock sector is
an important global player with significant and wide-ranging social, economic
and environmental impacts.  Worldwide,
livestock production provides livelihoods for 1 billion of the world’s poor.  However, the livestock sector is also a major
driver of deforestation, land degradation, pollution, climate change and
biodiversity loss.
Kenya is a clear
illustration of livestock’s complex social, economic and environmental
role.  In the Arid and Semi-Arid Lands
(ASALs) of Kenya, which constitute 80 percent of the country, the livestock
sector provides livelihoods for 95 percent of families and employs 10 million
people.  
However, pastoralism in ASALs faces many
challenges.  Population and livestock growth
has led to overgrazing, creating a negative-feedback system of environmental
degradation, reduced livestock yields and greater poverty.  In addition, pastoralists lack access to
capital, markets and extension services, such as veterinary care.  The lack of these services is a major
detriment to pastoralist income and livelihoods and inhibits market efficiency.SolutionHolistic Management
(HM) is a Ranch Planning System that helps pastoralists better manage agricultural resources. In this system land is managed on a large-scale and the livestock are grazed in concentrated
groups, mimicking wild herds, within demarcated areas. The cattle are moved
daily, rotating through the landscape, allowing
previously grazed grass enough time to regenerate.This form of
management is shown to rehabilitate habitats by reducing overgrazing and
erosion and enhancing natural processes, such as nutrient and water cycling.  As a result, land
productivity increases, generating higher beef production rates of up to 50
percent, and ROA up to 200 percent ; while sequestering carbon into the
soil at 0.1-5.3 T C · ha-1 · yr-1(Roughly equivalent
to removing 1-2 cars off the road).Business ModelRangeland Solutions will be a social enterprise that engages pastoralists in the practice of
Holistic Management.  Rangeland Solutions will become
involved in the value chain by providing needed services to small-scale
livestock producers, such as access to financing, livestock inputs, and
training.  In addition, Rangeland Solutions
will act as a transactional intermediary, helping small-scale pastoralists sell
their livestock into larger-scale commercial markets, thereby addressing the
missing market linkages between small producers and large-scale buyers.In the initial phase,
Rangeland Solutions will work with community members to form Pastoralist
Production Groups (PPG).  Once formed, Rangeland Solutions will provide training on Holisitic Management, as well as build a waterhole for livestock and provide grass seeds for reseeding (At no cost).  Rangeland Solutions will
also help PPGs market their livestock as a group and sell them into
larger-scale commercial markets, providing pastoralists with better access to
terminal markets and higher prices.  As part of the arrangement, Rangeland Solutions will have the rights to raise cattle on the lands of the PPGs for five years, at no cost.  This approach allows Rangeland Solutions to make back its original investment, while turning a small profit.Each PPG requires approximately $5,000 USD in initial investment to begin, or less than $500 per pastoralist family (Dependent on number of families in each PPG)What We Need & What You GetWhat We Need
We are currently in the process of starting our first pilot project, which will act as our "proof-of-concept".  We plan on launching it
in Spring 2014, in the village of Olekimunke (100 km south of Nairobi), where
Rangeland Solutions previously conducted research and has established communal
ties.  The pilot project will involve
forming one PPG, in which we hope to sign up 10-15 pastoral families.  This initial PPG will help Rangeland
Solutions to test our model and work out any issues.  In addition, it will be used as a
demonstration site for other pastoralists to see the intended outcomes and
benefits.As mentioned above, it costs approximately $5,000 to start each PPG, and we need your help to raise that amount. You can donate any amount.What You Get In Return:Many of the pastoralists we work with are Maasai and we would like to share a bit of their culture with you.
Maasai Herder ($25): Receive a beautiful beaded bracelet, hand-crafted by Maasai women from the communities we work in.  These are wonderful items, worn by almost every Maasai person.          
Maasai Warrior ($75): Do you want to dress like a Maasai warrior? Of course you do.  At this level you will receive a traditional Maasai shuka, worn by warriors (Warani) during cold nights out in the bush.  This is a versatile piece of clothing that can be used as a blanket, towel or sweater.             
Maasai Elder ($150):  Receive a leather beaded belt, hand-crafted by Maasai women from the communities we work in.  This is a wonderful accessory to brighten up any outfit.         
Maasai Village Elder ($500): Help support a pastoralist family and receive all of the items listed above, plus a profile of the family you support (including photos).

Maasai Village Chief ($1,000): Help support two pastoralist families and receive all of the items listed above, including profiles of both families, as well as a ceremonial club (rungu). These are carried by elders to signify their status.
       Other Ways You Can HelpThere are lots of ways you can still help Rangeland Solutions and contribute to a more sustainable future.Be Social:Follow us on Twitter - retweet our tweetsFollow our blogLike us on Facebook and share us on your timelineLast, always consider how your food choices impact the environment and people.

story:
Summary

I’m Arvin Pierce and welcome to my campaign! With your support we can truly Save More Bees!

You've read the articles and seen the news. The reports just keep coming in on how the bees are dying off. It's hard to figure out what you can do. Well, now you can truly help Save More Bees by donating directly to my campaign. 

I've been a beekeeper for over 11 years. As a beekeeper, one of my main jobs is to rescue colonies or swarms of bees that have taken up residence in buildings, homes, trees etc. Often, people used to just spray the colony with insecticide and kill them, but with all the awareness about bee populations dying off, people have started to call me to Save More Bees. I get a lot of calls to collect colonies from barns, houses, churches and even trees. I place these colonies into a hive (woodenware) and relocate them to a farm, yard, etc. so they can continue pollinating our crops and flowers.

Unfortunately, I have run out of hives and I need many more.

I am asking for your support, so I can continue to Save More Bees. Let's remember that although this is my campaign, it is not about me...it is about the bees. 

 

My History

11 years ago, my wife Colleen and I figured we’d “just get a couple of hives” to provide our own honey.  By the end of that first year we had 6 hives, and that number just kept increasing. As I began to learn more about honeybees, I became totally fascinated. My love of bees has grown and now I take care of numerous bee yards around Central Illinois with at least 70 hives.

After a few years of keeping bees, I started to get calls from folks who had bee colonies in their buildings or trees and wanted them removed. I’ve been known to drive over 100 miles to remove bees from people’s property. The folks who call me have also seen the reports about the declining bee populations and they want to Save More Bees as well. It seems that the more colonies I save, the more folks find out about what I do.  Often in the middle of doing one job, I receive calls about other colonies needing to be saved. The year isn’t even close to being over yet!

To date, I have 2 pest control companies that will call me instead of destroying honeybee colonies. I also have 2 tree trimmers who will contact me when they find a tree with bees. This doesn’t include the numerous swarms of bees I personally get called to retrieve. After these colonies are saved, I need to keep them in my apiary until they become established in a hive (woodenware). Then, the hive needs to be moved to a yard or farm where the benefits of these wonderful, fascinating pollinators can be appreciated and utilized. 

 

What I Need

A few years ago, I was fortunate enough to purchase some used hives. Well, now those hives are completely used up. Things have become so bad that I’ve begun to piece together hives with scraps of wood or parts of old ones. I really need new hives (woodenware) and that includes the top covers, bottom boards, hive bodies, and frames. It doesn't stop there. I need so much more than just the hives themselves. I also have the cost of the maintenance of my equipment which includes; my bee vac, saws, scaffold, ladder, and numerous hand tools. I also have the miles traveled to the jobs and the miles moving the hives, which creates cost for fuel and maintenance of my vehicle. This ALL adds up. 

Here is the breakdown.  I need 30 hives right now. On average, the hive and the equipment used (per rescue) runs $250. I've captured and removed a total of 22 colonies of bees so far this spring and early summer. These colonies are being kept in my yard in old, single-box hives and nucs (a nuc is half a box), with 3 of these colonies still in logs and one still in an old porch post. At this point in time there are 8 more bee colonies on my list to save. These bees will all need to be put in full-size hives to be relocated and become beneficial colonies.  With all the calls coming in, these rescues just don’t end. They keep coming and coming and we need to Save More Bees. They are simply too important to lose.

So it looks like this:

Right now, I need...

30 hives @ $250 each = $7500 

That's 30 colonies that we saved from extermination and placed on farms or in yards. But remember, the more you give the more bees I can save.

 

What You Get

I need your support to be able to continue to Save More Bees. In exchange for your donations I am offering many different exciting rewards!

• Of course, everyone gets a big thank you on my website. http://www.acbees.org

• I am also offering a two-sided professionally printed postcard that I photographed myself. See the Gallery Page on this site. 

• At most levels, I will send you seed packets of 4 of the top nectar-producing flowers: Lemon Balm, Echium, Phacelia Tansy and Borage. Then you can help the bees without having to have a hive. (That was a mouthful!) 

• How about some honey from my hives? It is always chemical-free, as I only run treatment-free hives. My honey is also processed without heat and I just "filter out the big chunks". It is some of the purest, raw, natural honey you can get.

• I am also offering a couple fun T-shirts with custom designed bee characters on them. Thanks to Nino LoGrasso and Matthew Schultz for those. See the Gallery Page on this site. 

• At a higher level you can Sponsor a Hive and I will name the colony after you. I'put Your name will be placed on a plaque on the side of the hive. Then I will send you photos of the hive and let you know where it is located.

• Finally, at the highest level you are a Supporter of Bees. I will bring you a hive (woodenware) with a queen and a colony to your land and teach you how to care for them. However, I can only offer this within 200 miles of Springfield, Illinois. Sorry for all of you in Australia!!

 

The Impact

Bees are an integral part of our eco-system and much needed pollinators. We need to be saving as many bees as possible. With the increase in the number of hives that I save, I can continue to increase the awareness in treatment-free bees and promote healthy beekeeping practices, while increasing the availability of raw, natural honey. But the greatest reward you can get…is knowing that you and I are Saving More Bees.   

Please pick a level you can afford and donate now. If you can't afford to donate money, that's ok too. Please help us by spreading the word; post this site on Facebook walls, Twitter and through other social media. Indiegogo has some easy and efficient social networking tools!!! Let's all spread the word!

Thanks!

 

For more information, photos, and videos about bees and bee removal, please go to my website:

http://www.acbees.org

Go to my Facebook page to check out photos of my most recent efforts to Save More Bees:

http://facebook.com/arvinpierce

Disclaimer: Because I can't control the weather or acts of God, I have to add a disclaimer. If honey production is low this year due to circumstances beyond my control, I promise to send it out next year. Remember, Illinois had one of the worst droughts last year and there just wasn't enough honey to harvest. No worries though. This year has had plenty of rain so far and the hives are looking good. I just want to be upfront here. Thanks!

story:
RAINBOW NATION

The Worldwide Rainbow Nation Art Fair is a virtual and traveling exhibit of conscious dreams for a loving, healthy, peaceful world. The Fair pools collective creative potential and will curate from submissions a virtual exhibit/gallery online as well as a traveling exhibit to attend fairs, festivals, farmers markets, and other occassions as invited or as possible. This project will produce a  compilation book featuring artwork and writing that envision the change we want to see in the world and a compilation album featuring songs around the same theme. Both are offered as rewards for this Indiegogo drive. In addition, a traveling exhibit will be constructed to exhibit creative contributions and promote the book and album. Additional rewards include prints of artwork donated to this effort and the ability to host the Rainbow Nation exhibit in your community.


ABOUT THE PROJECT INITIATOR

22 Years an Earth Activist 
Hi, my name is Reya. I started a Kids for Saving the Earth club on my school playground at age 10. I am about to turn 32 and in these 22 years I have dedicated my heart energy to a variety of causes on this path. I would like to share with you details of my journey and work on this path to illustrate my commitment and dedication to this mission and my ability to organize and execute complex projects. And so, I have expanded on my story at the bottom if you scroll down so you don't get bogged down in my story before learning about the project. (SCROLL TO BOTTOM FOR MORE OF MY STORY...)

WHAT IS RAINBOW NATION?

Rainbow Nation is one of five facets of Rainbow Camp's work.

  1. Rainbow Nation: Uniting creatives to dream a new world.
  2. Model Sustainability Camp: Demonstrating how a small group of people can come together to share and create abundance and support for all.
  3. Trail of Food: Propagating, Planning, Planting, and caring for food forests in the surrounding community.
  4. Giving Corp: A service-oriented camp for youth teaching self reliance skills, teamwork and group communication skills, permaculture, and natural building. The Corp assists in maintaining the Trail of Food project and the free children's summer camps.
  5. Kids Summer Camps: Free to area children, summer camps offer nature immersion and exploration on 160 acres of forested land that backs up to over 1,000 acres of public lands and trails including a limestone cave. Camp will also engage area youth in the Trail of Food and permaculture practice.

Rainbow Nation is the first project we are launching because the dream is where it starts. If we can envision the world we want to create, we will create it!


HOW THIS PROJECT CAN (LITERALLY) REINVENT THE WORLD

Quantum physics has helped illuminate how our thoughts impact the world around us. The biggest secret is the law of attraction. What we think, what we envision, what we pray for is what we attract into our lives. Our thoughts create our reality.


With this knowledge we have a great responsibility and great opportunity to dream the world we all know is possible. If enough of us combine our creative intent on the question: What does a peaceful harmonious world look like? imagine the ripples we can create!

There are plenty of experiments and stories that have emerged to illustrate this important once-supressed secret. From Emoto's photographs of water molecules subjected to words and prayer, to the 100th monkey phenomenon...

With this new understanding of the nature of reality, we are free to stop living a story we know is toxic, and dream a new one to replace it. This work is already being undertaken by Rainbow Warriors and creative pioneers worldwide such as Sacha Stone with the New Earth Project and permaculturists worldwide. But just as it takes a village to raise a child, it will take a village to raise the collective vibration and enter the world of our dreams. This is the rationale for Rainbow Nation - gathering collective creative potential to unite people around a shared vision for a healthy free harmonious Earth.

Rainbow Nation will create the following tangibles:

  1. Compilation Book: Revolution Blueprint: Collective dreams to heal the world
  2. Compilation Album: Dreaming New Earth
  3. Virtual Exhibit online at RainbowNation.com
  4. Traveling Exhibit to promote book, Revolution Blueprint and Album Dreaming New Earth and exhibit collection of creative visions.
  5. Kids Collective Mural: In April Rainbow Camp will work with children at the Dome School to create a collective artistic representation of a healthy abundant world.

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the bare expenses needed to make Rainbow Nation a success. The bulk of the budget is to provide modest stipends to selected artist/creative contributors. This is both fair practice and will help attract quality submissions to the project by set deadlines. $15,000 of $26,908 budget goes towards contributor stipends. $3,000 goes for stipends to master the album and layout/design the book. $2,700 goes to compensate performers and support for the exhibit launch April 19, 2014 in honor of the 44th Earth Day (April 22, 2014). $2,364 goes toward building the live exhibit and booth fees for events where the exhibit will go. $650 goes to purchasing art supplies for working with school children on collective art that will contribute to this exhibit.

Rainbow Nation Launch Expenses Hours/qnty Cost/unit Total Cost
ALBUM      
ALBUM: Cost to produce 200 reward and contributor copies 200 $3 $594
ALBUM: Stipend for mastering CD 15 $100 $1,500
ALBUM: Stipends for 15 musicians/spoken word contributors 15 $400 $6,000
BOOK      
BOOK: Cost printing 200 reward and contributor copies 200 $11 $2,200
BOOK: Stipend for editing and layout/design     $1,500
BOOK: Stipends for 45 literary and visual artist contributors 45 $200 $9,000
PROMOTION      
COMMUNICATE: website fees     $150
COMMUNICATE:printing advertising     $250
EXHIBIT LAUNCH: Musicians/guest performers  5 $500 $2,500
EXHIBIT LAUNCH: Sound     $200
EXHIBIT: Booth fees 10 $50 $500
EXHIBIT: earth flags, rainbow flag 2 $100 $200
EXHIBIT: Materials and contractor to building exhibit 60 $25 $1,500
EXHIBIT: Pots for live trail of food plants 12 $20 $164
KIDS CREATE      
KIDS CREATE: paper     $150
KIDS CREATE:modge podge     $200
KIDS CREATE:paints     $300
    TOTAL $26,908

Additional funding from this campaign would be directed toward:

  • EXHIBIT: Gas money to travel to events.
  • EXHIBIT: Truck rental: We would rent a truck from a neighbor to transport exhibit to events.
  • PROJECT COORDINATION: My time is as a volunteer for this effort. Additional funding would allow me to take a small stipend to support our land payments and livelihood at Rainbow Camp.
  • PRODUCTION: Additional resources may be directed towards better production of the compilation book and album.

If we do not reach our funding goal we will reduce the value of stipends offered to contributors and make cuts to production stipends. The Rainbow Nation solicitation does not mention stipends so achieving funding for the project will make these stipends possible and help raise the bar for contributions.

Take Part in Collectively Dreaming New Earth

  • Your investment makes it possible!
  • Our thoughts create our reality! Together, we can dream a new world.
  • Your investment spreads creative visions of a peaceful, healthy, loving world.
  • Your investment allows these visions to travel igniting dialogue in new circles.
  • See these visions take root in real grassroots actions.
  • Your support makes it possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

Investing money is great, but there are other ways you can help:

  • Help make music about Rainbow Nation! Share this campaign with your friends and family and ask them to contribute!
  • Get creative! Submit your dreams for a harmonious world to www.RainbowNation.us. 2D, 3D, performing art, videos, images, essays, poetry, etc. welcomed!

Thank you for your support!


Together, we're dreaming Earth green again!


ABOUT THE PROJECT INITIATOR

22 Years an Earth Activist 
Hi, my name is Reya. My legal name is Kristen Steele. As a kid my classmates called me Smiley (because they said I never stopped smiling) and I've also been known by the forest name Dandi. I started a Kids for Saving the Earth club on my school playground at age 10. I am about to turn 32 and in these 22 years I have dedicated my heart energy to a variety of causes on this path.

After a few years of extensive research into animal testing and the food industry, I became vegetarian at age 14 and volunteered with Earth Save in my hometown of Louisville, KY. I went on to attend College of Charleston in South Carolina where I was a campus and community organizer. I worked with and led the student organizations Alliance for Planet Earth and Womyn's Forum on a number of campaigns, events, and actions. I attended the National Conference on Organized Resistance from 2003-2005 and a numerous marches and organized protests in Washington, DC and throughout the U.S. I've marched for Women's Rights, protested the KKK, protested the World Bank, protested the Free Trade Area of the Americas, protested genetically modified organisms, protested the war, protested nuclear power, and protested electronic waste alongside thousands of sisters and brother warriors. In 2002 I co-created a new community garden and began growing food and plants wherever I could. In 2003 I began forest defense training and sat in a tree for 45 days as part of an Earth First! campaign. I participated in two mission-driven multi-state bicycle tours around this time. 

 
In 2003 I participated in the Flying Rutabega Cycle Circus Caravan Across the Cornbelt raising awareness of the risks of GMO food. (That's me with the One Less Car shirt).

Focusing on People Powered Movement
Upon returning from my activism tour, I created Charleston Cycle Fest, a week long celebration of bicycling which included a community-generated bicycle art show, an outdoor  bicycle film festival, kids bicycle rodeo, community bike ride, and bicycle maintenance and touring workshops which I organized for two years. The success and publicity generated by this event led to co-founding the nonprofit Charleston Moves and becoming active in the international bicycle and pedestrian advocacy movement. This marked a shift in my activist work away from protests and anti- messaging and towards positive solution-oriented advocacy. I attended the National Bike Summit in Washington, DC every March from 2005-2010 where I participated in lobbying for more federal transportation money to  create healthy safe places for biking and walking. 

In 2009 with sleeping baby in Senate building Washington, DC lobbying for biking and walking.

In 2006 I moved from South Carolina to San Francisco, CA where I met my ex-husband who is an artist and long-time bicycle advocate and co-founded Critical Mass. 

In January 2007 began working for the Alliance for Biking and Walking (then Thunderhead Alliance), the North American coalition of grassroots bicycling and walking advocacy organizations.

In 2008 co-leading a Winning Campaigns training for biking and walking advocates in hometown of Louisville, KY.

 I worked with the Alliance for 6 years where I lead a research project funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and published 3 biennial benchmarking reports that compiled data from the 50 states and 50 largest U.S. cities. 

Publishing and Visual Communications

I also led the Alliance's communication efforts including a renaming and rebranding process, website redesign, and building a resource library with thousands of resources for member groups. While with the Alliance I created the People Powered Movement Photo Contest which attracted thousands of photo submissions worldwide and partnered with a number of media and other businesses to promote and offer contest prizes.

       In 2010 created the People Powered Movement Photo Contest

In 2009 I began writing for Momentum Magazine (Vancouver, BC) and eventually began writing the column "The Advocate"  I have also published in Earth First! Journal, Carbusters and here, Fit and Sport (South Carolina), and Public Sector Digest. I was the primary author and designer of the 2007, 2010, and 2012 versions of the 100+ page research report Bicycling and Walking in the United States. I co-authored, designed, and edited the Alliance for Biking & Walking's Guide to Fundraising Rides and Guide to Complete Streets Campaigns. I wrote two chapters for the book On Bicycles

    Some of the publications I have contributed to, authored, and designed.

Transition to Permaculture Path
In 2008 the focus of my heart work began to shift. My son Axel was born and I began self-directed study in permaculture starting with Gaia's Garden. In 2009 I took my first natural building course with Pat Hennebery of Cobworks and began designing a cob house with my then partner. 

    2009 at Natural Building Workshop with Pat Hennebery and son Axel.

In 2009 and 2010 we prepared the site and met Michael G. Smith of Emerald Earth who agreed to consult with us on the project. In 2010 my daughter Ayla was born and we moved to the rural Humboldt County location and began building a home of natural materials. 


Tossing straw in clay slip for slip straw wall system with Ethan.

I started Sustainability School, a project to host and share permaculture practice projects, natural building, and self reliance skills. 

 Daughter Ayla munching strawberries in a newly developing permaculture garden.

In 2011 and 2012 Sustainability School hosted two natural building workshops with Smith and hosted 100 people through these workshops, Worldwide Opportunities on Organic Farms, and Workaway. 

  Becky and Myles, two of our amazing volunteers with the project.

 also created the blog Muddy Hands to chronicle the natural home building process.

   With ex-partner and children in garden, posing for Muddy Hands blog.

Transitions, Evolution, and Moves
In 2012 I left my ex-partner and father of my two young children and the land we had shared. He had bought the property before we joined and sharing it proved unhealthy for us all, so I moved in search of a new home to continue life and work with my then 2 and 4 year old. This search for a new place coincided with an evolution of the Sustainability School project into what is now Rainbow Camp, a spirit-centered nature awareness and self reliance skills camp and research center for low-cost energyt-efficient technologies that promote freedom and preserve Earth's resources for the next seven generations.
After nearly 18 months of searching I signed for 160 acres of rural forested land in Southern Oregon and relocated to this land with my two children, cat, and converted school bus.

Daughter Ayla Belle outside of our newest home, the Nautilus school bus at Rainbow Camp.

I am currently coordinating the launch of Rainbow Camp, Rainbow Nation, Rainbow Giving Corp, and the Trail of Food Project to coincide with the 44th Earth Day on April 22, 2014.
story_txt:
RAINBOW NATIONThe Worldwide Rainbow Nation Art Fair is a virtual and traveling exhibit of conscious dreams for a loving, healthy, peaceful world. The Fair pools collective creative potential and will curate from submissions a virtual exhibit/gallery online as well as a traveling exhibit to attend fairs, festivals, farmers markets, and other occassions as invited or as possible. This project will produce a  compilation book featuring artwork and writing that envision the change we want to see in the world and a compilation album featuring songs around the same theme. Both are offered as rewards for this Indiegogo drive. In addition, a traveling exhibit will be constructed to exhibit creative contributions and promote the book and album. Additional rewards include prints of artwork donated to this effort and the ability to host the Rainbow Nation exhibit in your community.ABOUT THE PROJECT INITIATOR22 Years an Earth Activist Hi, my name is Reya. I started a Kids for Saving the Earth club on my school playground at age 10. I am about to turn 32 and in these 22 years I have dedicated my heart energy to a variety of causes on this path. I would like to share with you details of my journey and work on this path to illustrate my commitment and dedication to this mission and my ability to organize and execute complex projects. And so, I have expanded on my story at the bottom if you scroll down so you don't get bogged down in my story before learning about the project. (SCROLL TO BOTTOM FOR MORE OF MY STORY...)WHAT IS RAINBOW NATION?Rainbow Nation is one of five facets of Rainbow Camp's work.
Rainbow Nation: Uniting creatives to dream a new world.

Model Sustainability Camp: Demonstrating how a small group of people can come together to share and create abundance and support for all.

Trail of Food: Propagating, Planning, Planting, and caring for food forests in the surrounding community.

Giving Corp: A service-oriented camp for youth teaching self reliance skills, teamwork and group communication skills, permaculture, and natural building. The Corp assists in maintaining the Trail of Food project and the free children's summer camps.

Kids Summer Camps: Free to area children, summer camps offer nature immersion and exploration on 160 acres of forested land that backs up to over 1,000 acres of public lands and trails including a limestone cave. Camp will also engage area youth in the Trail of Food and permaculture practice.

Rainbow Nation is the first project we are launching because the dream is where it starts. If we can envision the world we want to create, we will create it!

HOW THIS PROJECT CAN (LITERALLY) REINVENT THE WORLD
Quantum physics has helped illuminate how our thoughts impact the world around us. The biggest secret is the law of attraction. What we think, what we envision, what we pray for is what we attract into our lives. Our thoughts create our reality.With this knowledge we have a great responsibility and great opportunity to dream the world we all know is possible. If enough of us combine our creative intent on the question: What does a peaceful harmonious world look like? imagine the ripples we can create!There are plenty of experiments and stories that have emerged to illustrate this important once-supressed secret. From Emoto's photographs of water molecules subjected to words and prayer, to the 100th monkey phenomenon...With this new understanding of the nature of reality, we are free to stop living a story we know is toxic, and dream a new one to replace it. This work is already being undertaken by Rainbow Warriors and creative pioneers worldwide such as Sacha Stone with the New Earth Project and permaculturists worldwide. But just as it takes a village to raise a child, it will take a village to raise the collective vibration and enter the world of our dreams. This is the rationale for Rainbow Nation - gathering collective creative potential to unite people around a shared vision for a healthy free harmonious Earth.Rainbow Nation will create the following tangibles:
Compilation Book: Revolution Blueprint: Collective dreams to heal the world

Compilation Album: Dreaming New Earth

Virtual Exhibit online at RainbowNation.com

Traveling Exhibit to promote book, Revolution Blueprint and Album Dreaming New Earth and exhibit collection of creative visions.

Kids Collective Mural: In April Rainbow Camp will work with children at the Dome School to create a collective artistic representation of a healthy abundant world.

What We Need & What You GetHere are the bare expenses needed to make Rainbow Nation a success. The bulk of the budget is to provide modest stipends to selected artist/creative contributors. This is both fair practice and will help attract quality submissions to the project by set deadlines. $15,000 of $26,908 budget goes towards contributor stipends. $3,000 goes for stipends to master the album and layout/design the book. $2,700 goes to compensate performers and support for the exhibit launch April 19, 2014 in honor of the 44th Earth Day (April 22, 2014). $2,364 goes toward building the live exhibit and booth fees for events where the exhibit will go. $650 goes to purchasing art supplies for working with school children on collective art that will contribute to this exhibit.

Additional funding from this campaign would be directed toward:
EXHIBIT: Gas money to travel to events.
EXHIBIT: Truck rental: We would rent a truck from a neighbor to transport exhibit to events.
PROJECT COORDINATION: My time is as a volunteer for this effort. Additional funding would allow me to take a small stipend to support our land payments and livelihood at Rainbow Camp.
PRODUCTION: Additional resources may be directed towards better production of the compilation book and album.
If we do not reach our funding goal we will reduce the value of stipends offered to contributors and make cuts to production stipends. The Rainbow Nation solicitation does not mention stipends so achieving funding for the project will make these stipends possible and help raise the bar for contributions.Take Part in Collectively Dreaming New Earth
Your investment makes it possible!
Our thoughts create our reality! Together, we can dream a new world.
Your investment spreads creative visions of a peaceful, healthy, loving world.
Your investment allows these visions to travel igniting dialogue in new circles.
See these visions take root in real grassroots actions.
Your support makes it possible!
Other Ways You Can HelpInvesting money is great, but there are other ways you can help:
Help make music about Rainbow Nation! Share this campaign with your friends and family and ask them to contribute!
Get creative! Submit your dreams for a harmonious world to www.RainbowNation.us. 2D, 3D, performing art, videos, images, essays, poetry, etc. welcomed!
Thank you for your support!
Together, we're dreaming Earth green again!

story:
The Rickshaw Run

We are Joel, Lewis and Tom - The Riders of the Lost Tuk participating in the charity fund-raising crazy adventure that is the Rickshaw Run! This is a page where you can help fund the costs of our trip - mainly the fuel and inevitable breakdown/repair costs.

How you can help

Very simply... please donate as much as you would like to!

What's in it for you?

All contributors will get a big thank you on our Website, Facebook page, and Twitter page! 

Corporate Sponsor?

If you are a business, and would be interested in becoming one of our corporate sponsors then please get in touch at sponsors@lost-tuk.co.uk. All sponsors get a special introduction on the above pages, along with their company logo on the website, and social media.

story:
My name is Lilli Barrett-O’Keefe. I am a junior at Pitzer College, one of the Claremont Colleges outside Los Angeles, California. I am studying Environmental Analysis and Social Development through Sports. I grew up in Chicago, Illinois and have been an avid soccer player since I could walk. I have played soccer competitively throughout my childhood and have continued to play in college. It was not until college that I realized the power of the game.  It is a universal language that connects all corners of the globe.  Throughout my work with StreetSoccerUSA and other development programs I have begun to see the power the sport can have on people’s lives.  Indeed sport has the power to change the world, to inspire, to unite people in a way that little else can.

TakaBin Project

Takataka Yetu Jukumu Langu.
Our Trash, My Responsibility.
 
Throughout my time in the Eastlands of Nairobi I have noticed one ongoing challenge- trash. During the 1990’s the city discontinued regular trash collection. This led to an area wide crisis, trash began to pile up on the road sides and the people were left no other option than to burn their trash which resulted in harmful chemicals released into their neighborhoods. Many families of five or more adults and children live in small shacks about three meters squared. The homes are made of mud, sticks, cardboard and flattened tins. The homes have no water, no electricity, no toilets, no garbage collection and no sewage lines.  The homes are not built to harness the natural world – rainwater usually pours through the roofs and walls. Even on sunny days it is too dark to read or do schoolwork inside. Overpopulation and underdevelopment has led to the spread of diseases. There is no proper sewage system, which leads to human waste being improperly disposed. When the rain season strikes garbage as well as human waste enters people’s homes. Most of the trash collection today is run by youth initiatives and private businesses. These small run trash collections require weekly payment from the different homes and communities. Many of residents of Mathare work in the industrial area where they provide manual labor which earns them a little more than $ 3 a day. Due to the severe poverty in the areas most people cannot afford trash collection when money is so pinched they can barely manage to put food on the table. Despite the issues in policy I think the main problem lies on the youth’s mindset towards nature. The natural world in the slums is tainted by human waste and overpopulation. The river is sandwiched between piles of plastic bags, and the few trees are layered with thick brown dust from the roads.

I am beginning the piloting phase of the TakaBin Project. Our motto is: Our Trash, My Responsibility. We hope this makes each individual be accountable for the litter in their community. There might be huge communal piles of trash in the streets but it is up to the individual to insure that it is properly disposed. The project not only will reduce the amount of trash surrounding schools but will hopefully alter the minds of the schoolchildren. I plan to construct permanent large metal trash bins. The bins will be rationed off into three sections- food waste, recyclables, and paper. They will be built locally in Nairobi.  The aim of this will be to give value to their ‘trash’. Not only will we implant the trash bins but we will deliver workshops in the classrooms as well. With the combined impact of the physical separation of trash and the environmental curriculum I hope the youth change their perception of the natural world. The goal would be that the schoolchildren retain the lessons and diffuse the message into their families and greater communities.

We will implement this project throughout the various slum communities of MYSA. The large bins will be strategically placed depending on the various community needs. Workshops and tree planting will accompany each bin’s introduction into the community. We hope to create sustainable change instead of quick solutions such as burning trash or illegally dumping waste on the road side.

What happens when the bins are full?

We have appointed field coordinators in each community that the bins will be placed in. The collection varies among the locations. Thus far we have confirmed that the bins will be implanted in Maili Saba, Mathare, and Kayole. Since there is no government assistance the collection is done by the community. In Mathare we have partnered with a local environmental group, The Mathare Environment Conservation Youth Group,  that will be in charge of the bins once they are installed. They will be watering the newly planted seedlings, emptying and washing the bins, as well as monitoring them. In Maili Saba we have partnered with local schools. The schools will be in charge of developing a collection system. This same structure we have put in place in Kayole. They will then transport the garbage to a legal dump site.

“Waste is not waste until it's wasted.” We also encourage the different groups we are working with to use the collected trash in an environmentally sound manner. The collected items can be used as revenue for themselves, as well as support for the varying community initiatives. We have visited local recycling projects that use plastic bags to make handbags, plastic water bottles to make furniture and even animal bones to make jewelry. 'Trash' has value!

This project we hope will not only help the community get much needed resources but also ensure there is a sense of responsibility and ownership for the project.

Budget:

Bin- $300.00 each

Transport for the Bin- $25.00

Seedings- $20.00 each

Curriculum material- $100.00

We see this as an opportunity to complement what MYSA is doing with slum clean up activities as well as create a more environmentally sustainable solution. This approach will help deal with the excessive amount of garbage in Eastlands, which is over 2,000 tons per day. Findings suggest that there are severe public health and environmental impacts because of this.

Any amount can help us accomplish our goal of implementing this project in at least three communities. Your money will go directly to the construction of the bins and the seedlings for the schools and communities. We hope to put at least three bins in each community. The more money we raise, the more bins we can make! As simple as that.

Thank you much for your time! Return back to the site to see updated pictures of the bins and the project as a whole!
Lilli & TakaBin Staff

Mathare Youth Sports Association
I have been working at Mathare Youth Sports Association for a month. MYSA is a local non-profit that links sports with environmental cleanups, AIDS prevention, leadership training and other community service activities. Currently over 25,000 youths from 16 different slum communities are active members of this organization. MYSA is a global pioneer in linking sports with social and community development activities. I specifically focus on the organization’s activities in community service and public outreaches, its significant success in creating opportunities for women’s involvement in sport, and its interactions with the government. MYSA provides crucial lessons for the youth development in Kenya by harnessing spirit of volunteerism, its holistic approach to development, its innovative use of sports, and its emphasis on youth leadership. 

What does MYSA do?

MYSA is the largest self- help youth sports and community service organization in Africa. The Mathare area is one of the largest and poorest slums in Africa and home for over half a million people.

MYSA organizes a wide range of self-help youth sports and community
development activities. Highlights include:

Involving youth in development: Although youth are over half the population in Mathare, Kenya and Africa, their many needs, concerns and talents are often neglected. The main goal and motto of MYSA is to “Give youth a sporting chance” to help themselves and their community. Their longer term goal is to help develop the leadership skills and leaders needed to accelerate sustainable development in Kenya.

Linking sport and environmental cleanup:  MYSA is based on the simple fact that every football team is also a "mobilized" youth group. Our boys and girls teams play matches but also carry out a wide range of environmental cleanup and other self-help community service activities.

Reducing disease and deaths in the slums: Uncollected garbage and blocked drainage ditches are major causes of disease, disability and deaths in Mathare. The greatest threat is during the seasonal rains when water contaminated by garbage and human waste floods around and even into homes. So the youth carry out weekly garbage and drainage ditch cleanup projects. Teams earn six points in the league standings for each completed cleanup project.

Tackling the AIDS threat: Poverty and ignorance are major causes of AIDS. Like many slums, Mathare is a high risk area. Hundreds of Mathare youth leaders between 13-20 years of age have been trained on AIDS prevention and peer counseling. As the new heroes and role models in the slums, the best players are also the best way to reach many other youth with crucial information on AIDS risks and prevention.

Reducing substance abuse: To blur the edges of their tough lives, too many youth sniff glue and petrol or abuse drugs and alcohol. A top priority in MYSA is to give footballs to every team so they can train regularly. That helps many to stop abusing drugs because of peer pressure from teammates to keep fit.

Helping young leaders stay in school: Due to their large families and desperate poverty, many youth are forced to leave school. Under the MYSA Leadership Awards Project, the youth earn points for their achievements in different sports and community service activities. Over 450 awards are now made annually to help the best young leaders stay in school. The awards are paid directly to their school.

Helping youth excel in school: Without electricity, even at noon it is too dark to read inside homes in Mathare. Also, few local schools have libraries. MYSA has now created small libraries and study halls in four MYSA zones which are used by local schools on weekdays and by our own members after school and on weekends. They are so popular that we now aim to create one in each of the other 12 MYSA zones.

Encouraging young artistic talents: Our programs include training youth in dancing, drumming and singing as well as drama and puppetry. Their performances highlight key social issues such as AIDS, drug and alcohol abuse. Since 2004 MYSA’s youth have performed at the annual Haugesund Children's Festivals in Norway.

Helping disabled kids: MYSA organizes special sports, music and other activities for kids with mental and/or physical disabilities.

Helping jailed kids: Over a hundred streetkids from 4-16 years old were being processed weekly at the Juvenile Court. In cooperation with local authorities, MYSA helped renovate the court facilities and also feed and interview the kids. Our staff help contact and return jailed kids to their families and then link their families with microfinance programs.

Changing gender attitudes: Traditional views of men toward women and of women about themselves are serious constraints on social and political development. Both views changed among the Mathare youth since the mid-1990s with the rapid success of the girls’ teams in Kenya and abroad and the integration of girls in our decision-making committees and staff. Half of all elected MYSA leaders are girls, including the elected chair of the overall MYSA Executive Council.

Practicing good governance and accountability: MYSA is owned and run by the youth. In the 16 MYSA zones, key decisions are made by locally elected youth leaders. The best leaders are elected to the overall MYSA executive bodies. The average age of our several hundred MYSA volunteer organizers, leaders, coaches and referees is 15-16 years. Our accounts are independently audited every year.

Expanding horizons and hopes: Through their many achievements on and off the field our youth acquire new self-esteem and confidence. Over 1,000 MYSA youth have participated in the Norway Cup and youth tournaments in Holland. The youth lived there with host families and returned home with new views about themselves, the world and their future. Many of our best leaders are Norway Cup graduates. Others have earned diplomas or are still pursuing advanced studies in accounting, business administration, criminal justice administration, computer programming and medicine.

Creating new role models: As too many fathers neglect or abandon their families, the survival of many kids depends on their hardworking mothers. Lacking other role models, the top players, coaches and youth leaders in MYSA have become the new heroes and role models for the youth in Mathare and for millions of youth in other poor urban and rural communities in Kenya.

Changing public images of slums: When MYSA started our youth rarely admitted being from Mathare because of the bad and unfair image of the slums. The print and TV news reports about MYSA achievements on and off the field helped change those attitudes in and outside Kenya. So do the many remarkable photographs on their lives and living conditions taken and published by the youth in the MYSA “Shootback” photography training project.

Building and maintaining communal peace: The MYSA leaders, youth and programs help reduce inter-ethnic tensions and promote reconciliation and peace in the slums, especially during the outbreaks of inter-ethnic conflict in late 2006 and the post-election violence in early 2008. MYSA also initiated the innovative youth sports for development and peace project in the huge Kakuma Refugee Camp in northwest Kenya.

Changing distorted images of Africa: Drought, famine, corruption and war too often dominate news reports on Africa. That distorts reality as the poor majority of people in Africa are peaceful, honest, hardworking and young. Projects like MYSA and the youth exchanges with host families in Norway and Holland help change distorted attitudes and images about the poor and slums in Africa.
story_txt:
My name is Lilli Barrett-O’Keefe. I am a junior at Pitzer College, one of the Claremont Colleges outside Los Angeles, California. I am studying Environmental Analysis and Social Development through Sports. I grew up in Chicago, Illinois and have been an avid soccer player since I could walk. I have played soccer competitively throughout my childhood and have continued to play in college. It was not until college that I realized the power of the game.  It is a universal language that connects all corners of the globe.  Throughout my work with StreetSoccerUSA and other development programs I have begun to see the power the sport can have on people’s lives.  Indeed sport has the power to change the world, to inspire, to unite people in a way that little else can.
TakaBin Project
Takataka Yetu Jukumu Langu.Our Trash, My Responsibility. Throughout my time in the Eastlands of Nairobi I have noticed one ongoing challenge- trash. During the 1990’s the city discontinued regular trash collection. This led to an area wide crisis, trash began to pile up on the road sides and the people were left no other option than to burn their trash which resulted in harmful chemicals released into their neighborhoods. Many families of five or more adults and children live in small shacks about three meters squared. The homes are made of mud, sticks, cardboard and flattened tins. The homes have no water, no electricity, no toilets, no garbage collection and no sewage lines.  The homes are not built to harness the natural world – rainwater usually pours through the roofs and walls. Even on sunny days it is too dark to read or do schoolwork inside. Overpopulation and underdevelopment has led to the spread of diseases. There is no proper sewage system, which leads to human waste being improperly disposed. When the rain season strikes garbage as well as human waste enters people’s homes. Most of the trash collection today is run by youth initiatives and private businesses. These small run trash collections require weekly payment from the different homes and communities. Many of residents of Mathare work in the industrial area where they provide manual labor which earns them a little more than $ 3 a day. Due to the severe poverty in the areas most people cannot afford trash collection when money is so pinched they can barely manage to put food on the table. Despite the issues in policy I think the main problem lies on the youth’s mindset towards nature. The natural world in the slums is tainted by human waste and overpopulation. The river is sandwiched between piles of plastic bags, and the few trees are layered with thick brown dust from the roads.
I am beginning the piloting phase of the TakaBin Project. Our motto is: Our Trash, My Responsibility. We hope this makes each individual be accountable for the litter in their community. There might be huge communal piles of trash in the streets but it is up to the individual to insure that it is properly disposed. The project not only will reduce the amount of trash surrounding schools but will hopefully alter the minds of the schoolchildren. I plan to construct permanent large metal trash bins. The bins will be rationed off into three sections- food waste, recyclables, and paper. They will be built locally in Nairobi.  The aim of this will be to give value to their ‘trash’. Not only will we implant the trash bins but we will deliver workshops in the classrooms as well. With the combined impact of the physical separation of trash and the environmental curriculum I hope the youth change their perception of the natural world. The goal would be that the schoolchildren retain the lessons and diffuse the message into their families and greater communities.
We will implement this project throughout the various slum communities of MYSA. The large bins will be strategically placed depending on the various community needs. Workshops and tree planting will accompany each bin’s introduction into the community. We hope to create sustainable change instead of quick solutions such as burning trash or illegally dumping waste on the road side.
What happens when the bins are full?
We have appointed field coordinators in each community that the bins will be placed in. The collection varies among the locations. Thus far we have confirmed that the bins will be implanted in Maili Saba, Mathare, and Kayole. Since there is no government assistance the collection is done by the community. In Mathare we have partnered with a local environmental group, The Mathare Environment Conservation Youth Group,  that will be in charge of the bins once they are installed. They will be watering the newly planted seedlings, emptying and washing the bins, as well as monitoring them. In Maili Saba we have partnered with local schools. The schools will be in charge of developing a collection system. This same structure we have put in place in Kayole. They will then transport the garbage to a legal dump site.
“Waste is not waste until it's wasted.” We also encourage the different groups we are working with to use the collected trash in an environmentally sound manner. The collected items can be used as revenue for themselves, as well as support for the varying community initiatives. We have visited local recycling projects that use plastic bags to make handbags, plastic water bottles to make furniture and even animal bones to make jewelry. 'Trash' has value!
This project we hope will not only help the community get much needed resources but also ensure there is a sense of responsibility and ownership for the project.
Budget:
Bin- $300.00 each
Transport for the Bin- $25.00
Seedings- $20.00 each
Curriculum material- $100.00
We see this as an opportunity to complement what MYSA is doing with slum clean up activities as well as create a more environmentally sustainable solution. This approach will help deal with the excessive amount of garbage in Eastlands, which is over 2,000 tons per day. Findings suggest that there are severe public health and environmental impacts because of this.
Any amount can help us accomplish our goal of implementing this project in at least three communities. Your money will go directly to the construction of the bins and the seedlings for the schools and communities. We hope to put at least three bins in each community. The more money we raise, the more bins we can make! As simple as that.
Thank you much for your time! Return back to the site to see updated pictures of the bins and the project as a whole!Lilli & TakaBin Staff
Mathare Youth Sports Association I have been working at Mathare Youth Sports Association for a month. MYSA is a local non-profit that links sports with environmental cleanups, AIDS prevention, leadership training and other community service activities. Currently over 25,000 youths from 16 different slum communities are active members of this organization. MYSA is a global pioneer in linking sports with social and community development activities. I specifically focus on the organization’s activities in community service and public outreaches, its significant success in creating opportunities for women’s involvement in sport, and its interactions with the government. MYSA provides crucial lessons for the youth development in Kenya by harnessing spirit of volunteerism, its holistic approach to development, its innovative use of sports, and its emphasis on youth leadership. 
What does MYSA do?
MYSA is the largest self- help youth sports and community service organization in Africa. The Mathare area is one of the largest and poorest slums in Africa and home for over half a million people.
MYSA organizes a wide range of self-help youth sports and communitydevelopment activities. Highlights include:
Involving youth in development: Although youth are over half the population in Mathare, Kenya and Africa, their many needs, concerns and talents are often neglected. The main goal and motto of MYSA is to “Give youth a sporting chance” to help themselves and their community. Their longer term goal is to help develop the leadership skills and leaders needed to accelerate sustainable development in Kenya.
Linking sport and environmental cleanup:  MYSA is based on the simple fact that every football team is also a "mobilized" youth group. Our boys and girls teams play matches but also carry out a wide range of environmental cleanup and other self-help community service activities.
Reducing disease and deaths in the slums: Uncollected garbage and blocked drainage ditches are major causes of disease, disability and deaths in Mathare. The greatest threat is during the seasonal rains when water contaminated by garbage and human waste floods around and even into homes. So the youth carry out weekly garbage and drainage ditch cleanup projects. Teams earn six points in the league standings for each completed cleanup project.
Tackling the AIDS threat: Poverty and ignorance are major causes of AIDS. Like many slums, Mathare is a high risk area. Hundreds of Mathare youth leaders between 13-20 years of age have been trained on AIDS prevention and peer counseling. As the new heroes and role models in the slums, the best players are also the best way to reach many other youth with crucial information on AIDS risks and prevention.
Reducing substance abuse: To blur the edges of their tough lives, too many youth sniff glue and petrol or abuse drugs and alcohol. A top priority in MYSA is to give footballs to every team so they can train regularly. That helps many to stop abusing drugs because of peer pressure from teammates to keep fit.
Helping young leaders stay in school: Due to their large families and desperate poverty, many youth are forced to leave school. Under the MYSA Leadership Awards Project, the youth earn points for their achievements in different sports and community service activities. Over 450 awards are now made annually to help the best young leaders stay in school. The awards are paid directly to their school.
Helping youth excel in school: Without electricity, even at noon it is too dark to read inside homes in Mathare. Also, few local schools have libraries. MYSA has now created small libraries and study halls in four MYSA zones which are used by local schools on weekdays and by our own members after school and on weekends. They are so popular that we now aim to create one in each of the other 12 MYSA zones.
Encouraging young artistic talents: Our programs include training youth in dancing, drumming and singing as well as drama and puppetry. Their performances highlight key social issues such as AIDS, drug and alcohol abuse. Since 2004 MYSA’s youth have performed at the annual Haugesund Children's Festivals in Norway.
Helping disabled kids: MYSA organizes special sports, music and other activities for kids with mental and/or physical disabilities.
Helping jailed kids: Over a hundred streetkids from 4-16 years old were being processed weekly at the Juvenile Court. In cooperation with local authorities, MYSA helped renovate the court facilities and also feed and interview the kids. Our staff help contact and return jailed kids to their families and then link their families with microfinance programs.
Changing gender attitudes: Traditional views of men toward women and of women about themselves are serious constraints on social and political development. Both views changed among the Mathare youth since the mid-1990s with the rapid success of the girls’ teams in Kenya and abroad and the integration of girls in our decision-making committees and staff. Half of all elected MYSA leaders are girls, including the elected chair of the overall MYSA Executive Council.
Practicing good governance and accountability: MYSA is owned and run by the youth. In the 16 MYSA zones, key decisions are made by locally elected youth leaders. The best leaders are elected to the overall MYSA executive bodies. The average age of our several hundred MYSA volunteer organizers, leaders, coaches and referees is 15-16 years. Our accounts are independently audited every year.
Expanding horizons and hopes: Through their many achievements on and off the field our youth acquire new self-esteem and confidence. Over 1,000 MYSA youth have participated in the Norway Cup and youth tournaments in Holland. The youth lived there with host families and returned home with new views about themselves, the world and their future. Many of our best leaders are Norway Cup graduates. Others have earned diplomas or are still pursuing advanced studies in accounting, business administration, criminal justice administration, computer programming and medicine.
Creating new role models: As too many fathers neglect or abandon their families, the survival of many kids depends on their hardworking mothers. Lacking other role models, the top players, coaches and youth leaders in MYSA have become the new heroes and role models for the youth in Mathare and for millions of youth in other poor urban and rural communities in Kenya.
Changing public images of slums: When MYSA started our youth rarely admitted being from Mathare because of the bad and unfair image of the slums. The print and TV news reports about MYSA achievements on and off the field helped change those attitudes in and outside Kenya. So do the many remarkable photographs on their lives and living conditions taken and published by the youth in the MYSA “Shootback” photography training project.
Building and maintaining communal peace: The MYSA leaders, youth and programs help reduce inter-ethnic tensions and promote reconciliation and peace in the slums, especially during the outbreaks of inter-ethnic conflict in late 2006 and the post-election violence in early 2008. MYSA also initiated the innovative youth sports for development and peace project in the huge Kakuma Refugee Camp in northwest Kenya.
Changing distorted images of Africa: Drought, famine, corruption and war too often dominate news reports on Africa. That distorts reality as the poor majority of people in Africa are peaceful, honest, hardworking and young. Projects like MYSA and the youth exchanges with host families in Norway and Holland help change distorted attitudes and images about the poor and slums in Africa.

story:
What is the Solar Decathlon?

The US Department of Energy Solar Decathlon is an award-winning program that challenges twenty teams from Universitites across the world to compete against each other. The purpose of this competition is to educate student participants and the public about the many cost-saving opportunities presented by clean-energy products. Ecohabit is the name of our cost-effective; energy-efficient, solar-powered home designed and build by students across a variety of majors at Stevens Institute of Technology. By using out uniquely decided smart technology, our house evolves over time, adapting to its users, and their lifestyles, and is some sense gets better with age.

Stevens was 1 of only 20 teams chosen to compete at the 2013 Solar Decathlon competition. This provides clear evidence of our motivation and willingness to take risks and achieve success in solar technology and innovation. With your help and our team’s dedication we plan on bringing home a 1st place finish to Stevens in addition to donating the home to a United States Veteran. 

What We Need & What You Get

Any contribution would help us out greatly! From 2x4's to build the home, energy-efficient appliances, decorations to cash. We would be more than happy to receive anything that can help us impress the judges at the competition in Irvine, California.

The Impact

The impact of this project is huge not only to us students, but to the public and the family we donate Ecohabit to. Our entire school is behind Ecohabit and we are very proud that our team has been selected out of hundreds to compete. As students we are provided with unique training that prepares us to enter our nation’s clean-energy workforce. Additionally, through our marketing effort we are addressing the public about the opportunities that clean-energy products present. Finally, we are most excited about the final step- the donation process. In the last Solar Decathlon competition, our team joined with Habitat for Humanity and donated the home to a needy family in Washington DC. This time around, we plan on teaming up with the mayors office in San Diego, California to donate the home to a well-deserved United States Veteran.

Other Ways You Can Help

Considering this is our second time competing in this competition, our team hopes to make as much noise about Ecohabit and the competition as possible. We are very confident in our design and think this is the year we can bring home the 1st place finish with your help!

Please visit our website! www.stevens.edu/sd2013

Follow us on Twitter! https://twitter.com/StevensSD2013

Like our Facebook page!www.facebook.com/StevensSD2013

Check out our Google+! https://plus.google.com/111115223109526771224/posts

story:
Update: Prices for group flights are now in. Unfortunately their estimates were quite under the actual cost. See below for new cost info.

 

Update: They've placed me in Thailand on June 20th! I'm beyond excited, and an so happy with everyone's support so far!

Who am I?

My name is Heather Topple. I'm a biology/music student at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Ever since I was little, I've been fascinated by nature; whether it was treking through the backyard on the lookout for chickadees or at the beach with my sisters, convinced the whitecaps off in the distance were pods of whales.

The Opportunity

Through school, I've learned how important wildlife conservation is, and now I have the opportunity to give my time, talents, and compassion to make a difference. Through International Student Volunteers (ISV), I have been selected to volunteer abroad in a 4-week program this summer in Thailand!

Through this program, I'll be able to help build houses in communities, teach English to local children, and interact with the local wildlife in sanctuaries and reserves. I'm really excited for the opportunity to work with elephants, hence the name of my campaign. As a full-time student and part-time brewery tour supervisor, I understand the value of money, and need to find ways to pay for this truly once-in-a-lifetime experience.

The Cost

The cost of this program is around $6115, which breaks down into the following:

Program cost.................... $3795
International airfare........... $1345 -> $1499
Airline tax/fuel.................... $550 -> $750
Domestic airfare.................. $350 -> $435
Ticketing fee......................... $25 -> $30
Academic credit fee................ $50
Travel insurance.................... TBA
Passport............................... TBA
Vaccinations.......................... TBA
Total.................................. $6115 -> $6559

For cost details:
http://www.isvolunteers.org/ca/destination/thailand/cos

My Gift to You

Given the scope of the program, these costs make sense. As a thank-you for your contribution, there are a few perks involved! For contributions of $10, I will give a special crochet elephant (pictured). $25 donors will receive a personalized thank-you and an elephant of their prefered colour. Those who contribute $50 will receive a personalized thank-you and a selection of photos from the trip. Those who contribute $100 will receive a personalized thank-you and a travel diary from the trip, including a selection of photos.

As a result of shipping costs, those of you who are donating out-of-province/country will not receive an elephant, but may choose whichever of the other perks as a substitute.

How Does This Help?

The ISV program has been organizing these volunteer efforts for almost 30 years. In that time, they've clocked over 220000 hours of volunteer work in six different countries, protected and relocatetd 8570 engangered sea turtle eggs, and spent over 27500 hours teaching music, English, conservation, recreation, & health programs to over 4100 children.
 
For more info on ISV's achievements:
http://www.isvolunteers.org/achievements

What You Can Do

Not everyone is in a position to help out financially, but that's okay! Please, if you can, spread the word. Tell friends, family, post this site on facebook, show someone a photo of the elephants, do an interpretive dance explaining the cause - whatever you feel to help get the word out there. You never know who of your friends may feel inclined to donate!
