story:
FUSE INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE WITH CUTTING-EDGE SCIENCE.

Help us run a sustainability course in a Bedouin 

village, while providing services and jobs to one of 

Israel's most underserved populations. 

___________________________________________________

WHO ARE WE? 

Hi, I'm Abra! I am the Program Guide of Reinventing Roots, a permaculture certification and design program in the indigenous Bedouin village of Kaser al-Ser, Israel. With local residents and our volunteer team of talented teachers, builders, students, farmers and scientists, we are developing an education center in Kaser al-Ser that, through a unified community effort, will provide a means of income for the village's residents and basic infrastructures the village needs. Visitors will learn best practices for sustainable building and agriculture from Bedouin residents and our certified instructors.

WHO DO WE SERVE?

Bedouin villages in Israel often lack basic public services, such as paved roads, electricity, community centers and play areas, trash and sewage disposal services, schools and public transportation. These gaps are the results of a longstanding conflict between the State and the Bedouin over the use and ownership of the Negev Desert. While the State has ruled that Bedouin must live in urban settlements--and that they be forcibly relocated from their traditional villages--many Bedouin have insisted upon a legal right to determine how, and where, they would like to live, like all other Israeli citizens. 

Reinventing Roots empowers Bedouin citizens to live a life of their choosing, in accordance with their lands and traditions, and to pass on their invaluable knowledge of living with the natural environment.

HOW FAR CAN YOUR DONATION GO?

Your support will enable us to run our summer session, this July 5-August 6 in the Bedouin village of Kaser al-Ser. We need financial support to buy the basics to build our education center, gardens, farms and playgrounds with our local community.  
Here's an idea of how far a couple of dollars (or shekels) can go:
  • $2: 2-liter bottle of drinking water
  • $6: Trowel to tend community garden
  • $6.50: Round-trip bus ticket to Beer Sheva to pick up supplies
  • $19.50: Pitchfork to build small-scale agriculture
  • $23.00: Soccer ball for soccer lessons and break times
  • $100.00: Tarp to shade playground to protect students from hot, desert sun

Getting out the word helps, too! We are part of an international movement to empower our world's indigenous peoples as partners in solving our globe's environmental crises. We would love for you to keep asking questions and learning more. And, next time you're in the Negev Desert, come join us! Find out more on our website: www.reinventingroots.com. Thank you for your time and curiosity!

Thanks, شكرا, תודה 

Abra and the Reinventing Roots Team

We would love for you to keep asking questions and learning more. And, next time you're in the Negev Desert, come join us! Find out more on our website: www.reinventingroots.com. Thank you for your time and curiosity!Thanks, شكرا, תודה Abra and the Reinventing Roots Team

story:
Our Story

Bob North here, founder and president of the non-profit Living Earth Oases Project which was started to develop reforestation, conservation and agroforestry/permaculture projects in order to save our planet's remaining rainforest. Our goal will be to boost food production efficiency in rainforest habitats eliminating the need for the slash and burn method currently used by subsistence farmers eking out a living in tropical forest across the globe. Slash and burn is a main driver of deforestation and responsible for millions of acres of lost rainforest presenting an urgent need for solutions to this ongoing and growing dilemma. We feel we've developed several working solutions to address the aforementioned problems resulting in mass deforestation but were lacking funding to develop and implement those solutions, but thanks to a very generous donor we are on the verge of resolving our fundraising problem.

Our non-profit, Living Earth Oases Project will finally be in a position to establish our first Agroforestry project thanks to that very generous donor who recently donated one of his properties to us here in Baltimore in need of renovation. I have an extensive background and experience spanning decades with the restoration, remodeling and renovation of properties so this gift of a property in need of renovation was perfect for us as a project for seed money funding. Work on the renovation of the house has already begun and it's well on it's way to completion but we have fallen behind on our planned completion date do to illness and a few other unforeseen problems that have forced us to reach out to secure more funding to complete the renovations within a reasonable time frame that will allow for marketing the house and then setting up our agroforestry project before the end of the year. I've been able to donate much of the materials used to this point as well as do the work. Most of the materials used to this point are from previous jobs and along with being able to preserve a lot of the home's original architectural features like the fireplace mantle, refinishing flooring and steps, saving old doors and hardware and so on we've managed the material cost without to much hardship. Once the renovations are completed we will sell the property and invest part of the proceeds earned from the sale toward our agroforestry project in Costa Rica and budget the remainder toward another renovation project here in Baltimore to repeat the process of renovating and selling local properties to continue our fundraising efforts into next year. Before we can move forward on to our primary goal and mission of saving our planet's remaining rainforest we need your help in raising the remainder of the funds needed to complete the renovations on our donated property.

We are so close and feel that if we can raise $3500 we will be able to get the house finished by the end of July and on the Market. The money will help with hiring an electrician to do some minor work like installing a new light fixture in the kitchen and replacing old lights with new ones, eight in all as well as replacing a few receptacles and switches. We still need to do yard work, replace fencing, purchase new refrigerator and stove and find used base cabinets we can refinish at the Loading Dock or the Restore that will work with the upper cabinets we were able to save and we have some paint but need more so we are reaching out for more funding but we are giving back with great perks in return for your help. Our perks are pretty cool, like our T-shirts with our original logo, our wildflower and Milkweed seeds which will present the opportunity for you to enjoy beautiful flowers while giving a second time, this time to nature by helping to save the Monarch Butterfly and other pollinators, and then there is our Children's books that were written by Baltimore legend Lucretia (Lu) Fisher who helped save both Fells Point and Federal Hill from the wrecking ball by helping to stop a planned Highway Project back in the 70's and there are beautiful Art Prints and other great perks to choose from. These wonderful perks will be our way of giving back to you for your generosity. Please help us in our efforts and our quest to find solutions to deforestation while helping subsistence farming communities improve their lives all while helping to save our Planet's Remaining Rainforest and the creatures that call the rainforest home.

story:
Video Credit

Music by Joseph Alexander - Check him out at http://www.josephalexandermusic.co.uk

Filmed and Edited by David Zant 

Short Summary

Laie Bay is more than just a scenic view.  It is a sought after escape where people enjoy surfing, swimming, snorkeling, spearfishing, or just laying on the beach.  Unfortunately some of those activities may end if we don't step in to save the dying bay.  We have seen first hand the dying coral and the decreasing fish population.    Many people are unaware of the dying reef and even more people are unaware of the long term consequences.

Your contribution will give us the jump-start that we need to begin restoring Laie Bay’s vibrant life.  Any amount of money contributed will be useful in purchasing these tools.

Who We Are

Both of us, Aaron Sanders and David Zant, are seniors in Biology at BYU-Hawaii and have lived in Laie for several years.  Aaron is currently involved in marine studies, including working with polychaetes in Kaneohe Bay. David has been active in conservation projects, including working on Laie summit to preserve endemic Hawaiian plants.  Previously we were part of a research team investigating the properties of plants used in Hawaiian traditional medicine.  Both of us will graduate in April and will then move on to medical and dental school.

We both feel an obligation to give back to a place that has given us so much. 

Find us on LinkedIn for more information.

The Tools and Our Plan

The Brigham Young University-Hawaii Marine Biology Department already has some of the necessary instruments needed to begin the restoration of the bay, but there are two tools that will dramatically change the dynamics of the project and will increase the productivity exponentially.

The Sonar/GPS Combo Unit

This unit will allow us to make a topographical map of the bay.  With a topographical map we can identify the percentage of live coral that is surviving. This map will be vital in ascertaining where the damage in the bay has been done. 

 

  

The Van Veen Grab 

The grab allows us to take necessary sediment samples deep in the bay that are hard to reach.  The sediment will tell us what the marine community is like at the bottom of the bay and in the water column.  The health and makeup of the marine community will reveal critical information about what is happening in the Bay.  

 

 

 

These two instruments are imperative to analyzing the bay and taking steps toward recovery.  These tools will not "fix" Laie Bay by themselves.  However, they will help lay a foundation for all future studies done in the bay and are the first step in restoring Laie Bay's vibrant life.  

Why This Amount

$3,500 is the cost to purchase both instruments.  All funds will go into this purchase and any extra will be used in aiding the project.

Our school is aiding in other aspects of this project, but the marine department does not have the funds for these particular instruments.  

If our $3,500 goal is not met, the money we do raise will still be used in the project, but will only cover less expensive costs.  Without your help, we may never obtain these two instruments.  

The Impact

This project gives you the opportunity to play an indispensable role in saving Laie Bay.  However, restoring life to Laie Bay is only the start.  The experience that our students and professors will gain in this project, will then allow us to work on other coral reefs or coastlines that are suffering as well.

The environment all over the world suffers because of human impact.  This is an opportunity for you as a human to help save the environment.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and share this fundraiser on your social media pages!

Where The Money Is Going

We are not keeping any of the money. To speed the process of obtaining the instruments, all donations will be given directly to Bybee Consulting LLC.

Bybee Consulting LLC is a company owned and operated by David Bybee Ph.D., assistant professor at BYU-Hawaii.  Dr. Bybee received a Ph.D. in marine biology from the University of Hawaii and is a seasoned field biologist.  He will use the money to purchase the equipment for use at BYU-Hawaii, as well as overseeing the project.

story:
Para leer todos los detalles del proyecto en español, hacen CLIC AQUI, pero acuérdense que para participar necesitan utilizar la plataforma de Indiegogo.

Hello everybody!

We are Pedro and Lucia. We are nature lovers who do our best to make our contribution to a more harmonious world. We want to share our knowledge and philosophy of organic living with the community, in particular to help future generations understand the importance of looking after nature and the environment. We need you to help us achieve this.


The story of our farm begins with our wish to live better, a wish for fresh air, healthy food and protected nature. We wanted a better quality of life, a life which was more us; in agreement with our values and more environmentally friendly. So Granja Tia Nora was born in 2006, 12 kilometers from the city of San Juan in Argentina, in the small village of Albardon. On a seven hectare ground we built our farm and began our new way of life.


From the beginning we wanted to make the Tia Nora’s farm a place of learning, sharing and experimentation. So, little by little, we built an educational farm where all year we welcome school groups of all levels, volunteers from all over the world and local families. All come here to learn about animal care or simply to share a moment together in nature.

The health of our earth and our children is essential to us. We cultivate our vegetable garden without any pesticides, or chemical fertilizer and only from organic seeds. Our farm is based on harmony between the animal life and the vegetable life. The earth feeds us and our animals and in return, our animals produce the compost which feeds the earth.

At Granja Tia Nora we apply and experiment with different types of organic farming, permaculture and biointensive agriculture. These are farming methods that enrich the earth, rather than industrial agricultural methods which impoverish it. Since 2013 all our vegetable production is verified and certified organic by the label of OIA (Organisation Internationale Agropecuaria).


We want to ensure that our earth continues to provide for future generations, so we want to teach people, especially children, how to look after it and treat it well. We are working to improve the facilities we have so more people are able to visit us. This is where we need your help.


We need to raise $3800 so we can welcome more visitors to Tia Nora.

We need your help to enable us to finish bathrooms for our visitors, particularly those for disabled visitors. These facilities will mean we are able to welcome more groups to the farm, to learn and enjoy nature.

We have already built a quarter of the building, but we need your support to finish! $3800 will help us buy materials and some tools to replace those that were unfortunately stolen from us. We have set aside $500 cash to contribute ourselves and have many willing volunteers who will be able to assist our builder. Please help us complete this important project!


We are very grateful for your support and if you donate we will welcome you to visit Granja Tia Nora any time. However we know that if you live far away this might not be possible so we have other gifts to thank you, depending on your contribution you can select from the following:


-  POSTCARD FROM THE FARM: to send a piece of green air to your friends, choose our country pictures, freshly taken from the garden just for you!


- TEXTILE BAGS: Fashionable and fresh, you can show off your participation and your support of Granja Tia Nora.


- CANASTA DE LA HUERTA: for the people of San Juan we offer you a basket of vegetables from our garden, all organic of course! The basket is an artisanal one made by a local artisan. We'll deliver it to your door.


- KITS OF SEEDS: from the most common to the rarest, with these seeds you can cultivate a piece of Granja Tia Nora at home. You can choose the small kit of a selection of 5 types de seeds or the big one with 10 types of seeds. The kits included flowers and vegetables seeds.


- STAY IN OUR ECOLODGE: take time to relax a little far from any stress and share with us the farm life.


- ADOPT AN ANIMAL: select an animal to adopt, we'll send you some news from it, and we offer you to visit it for a 2 nights and 3 days stay full board, for two people, in the eco lodge of the farm. Visit us any time you please!

The animals for adoption are : 

Nube and Chocolate the lamas, Ginger the horse, Mindie the cow, Moka and Crema the goats, Liu the golden pheasant, Carlos the peacock, Mora the sheep and Aramis the billy goat.




Like our page on Facebook.

Share our campaign on Facebook, maybe asking people to support us and Like our campaign. 

Email our campaign to your friends and family.

Make a comment and tell us what you think of our work!

think of our work!

story:
Sanitation in Kigali

Rwanda does not have a sewer system.

93% of Kigali’s human waste is released into the environment untreated.

Pit Vidura provides a solution to this.

At Pit Vidura we’ve replaced inhumane and unhygienic methods of emptying waste from non-sewered toilets with our double vacuum pumping system, the “DoVac,” that reduces servicing time to minutes, eliminates odors, and minimizes contact between hazardous waste and people. Standard vacuum trucks in Kigali can empty pits from households that are up to 30 meters from a road. This means most low-income households located in dense areas far from the road are out of reach for basic waste management services. 

We’ve developed a system that can empty waste from a over 200 meters away from our truck! This allows us to offer our safe waste removal services to households in even the poorest, densest, and most inaccessible areas. Our employees are equipped head-to-toe with personal protective gear and households love our professional, quick, and affordable service.

Our system keeps thousands of cubic meters of human waste out of communities and water bodies leaving communities healthier and environments cleaner. 

 

What Makes us Different:

  • WORKER EMPOWERMENT: Pit Vidura is creating formal and reliable employment for historically marginalized waste workers by equipping them by equipping them with improved tools, training, and marketing support

 

  • INCLUSIVE URBAN SANITATION PLANNING: Many sanitation investments focus on major civil infrastructure that leaves out low-income households in informal areas that are growing in size and density. Pit Vidura develops systems and services to offer low-income households a safe, affordable and aspirational sanitation service. 

 

  • FINANCIAL SUSTAINABILITY THROUGH INNOVATION; Efficiency gains through new emptying hardware, customer-clustering, and work tracking software has put us on the path to be financially self sustaining, key to a robust and lasting service targeting low-income households. We take pride in being a bootstrapped start-up while recognizing that in order to scale our services to those who need it the most, we need more capital!

 

  • FEMALE LEADERSHIP: While we recognize the role that both women and men play in successfully implementing sanitation projects, we embrace the role of women in the design, management and communication of our work at Pit VIdura! From our advisers to our senior engineers and operations team, we are led, run and supported by women!

We need your help. . .

We have provided over 750 household customers in Kigali with a safe emptying service and prevented over 1500 m3 of pathogenic waste from entering the urban environment, we’re getting to know our customers better, the service is generating income, and we are almost at a point where we are generating positive cash flow! 

While we’re covering our current day-to-day operating costs, we need your help to expand and our services to the households that need our service the most. We are raising 15,000 USD for the down payment on a new exhauster truck that will allow us to scale our services beyond our current reach.

Acquisition of a truck will allow us to double our daily revenue and slash operating costs by 20%. In addition, a truck will allow us to serve more households per day and add an additional emptying team, creating approximately 10 more low-skilled jobs in Kigali.

Pit Vidura's Impact

If you’re reading this, you probably know a world where urban environments are free of disease causing pollution and where sanitation services are provided by trained sanitation workers providing quality services that are affordable. But the overwhelming majority-over 90%- of waste generated worldwide is dumped into the environment untreated.

With your support, Pit Vidura can purchase our own exhauster truck and increase the impact of our work by:

  • Lowering our costs to serve Kigali's poorest households
  • Performing more empties and increasing the removal of of pathogenic waste removed from communities-- preventing diarrheal disease and eutrophication 
  • Creating more jobs for low-skilled workers 
  • Developing the tools and technology to promote safe emptying practices worldwide

Frequently Asked Questions 

    Why not build sewers?

    Sewers are not always the best urban solution. They are inappropriate where water is very scarce – and where it isn’t feasible to extend them to lower-income settlements or those on city outskirts. In many cases, focusing on sewers for urban sanitation means that only the wealthy get served. Sewer systems also require high up-front capital investment, and depend on the availability of reliable water and energy supplies.  

    A mix of technical solutions including both onsite and sewerage solutions is needed to ensure citywide inclusive sanitation—a sanitation system in which everybody benefits from sanitation infrastructure. Pit Vidura focuses on developing the components of an inclusive sanitation plan that benefit the poorest of the poor in the hardest to reach urban locations.

    Do you make profits or are you a non-for-profit? Are these contributions tax deductible?

    ​​ We operate as a social enterprise. While we are a revenue-generating business, all of our surpluses are reinvested in our programs and scaling our emptying services to more communities in Rwanda and beyond.  We are legally not eligible to have tax-exempt status.

    I want to donate but I don't want to do this online. How can I get in touch with the team? 

    Please reach out directly to Rachel[at]pitvidura[dot]com

    Is there a shipping cost?

    Yes, there is a shipping cost for all of the perks associated with your contributions. When you pay for shipping, we have more money left over to dedicate to transforming sanitation in Rwanda!

    For shipping within the U.S., add $7.00-$10.00 (depends on your perk) to your pledge amount.For shipping outside of the U.S., add $20.00-$30.00 (depends on your perk) to your pledge amount.

    How do I specify between bag and t-shirt, and t-shirt size?

    If you donate $50 and above, you should receive an email asking about your preferences between t-shirt or a tote bag, t-shirt size, and mailing address. If you have any other questions please contact Julia at julia[at]pitvidura.com.

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Get the word out! Send this campaign to your friends, family, and colleagues
    • Use Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign and/or your participation with your social media networks

What Makes us Different:

WORKER EMPOWERMENT: Pit Vidura is creating formal and reliable employment for historically marginalized waste workers by equipping them by equipping them with improved tools, training, and marketing support
 
INCLUSIVE URBAN SANITATION PLANNING: Many sanitation investments focus on major civil infrastructure that leaves out low-income households in informal areas that are growing in size and density. Pit Vidura develops systems and services to offer low-income households a safe, affordable and aspirational sanitation service. 
 

FINANCIAL SUSTAINABILITY THROUGH INNOVATION; Efficiency gains through new emptying hardware, customer-clustering, and work tracking software has put us on the path to be financially self sustaining, key to a robust and lasting service targeting low-income households. We take pride in being a bootstrapped start-up while recognizing that in order to scale our services to those who need it the most, we need more capital!
 

FEMALE LEADERSHIP: While we recognize the role that both women and men play in successfully implementing sanitation projects, we embrace the role of women in the design, management and communication of our work at Pit VIdura! From our advisers to our senior engineers and operations team, we are led, run and supported by women!



We need your help. . .
We have provided over 750 household customers in Kigali with a safe emptying service and prevented over 1500 m3 of pathogenic waste from entering the urban environment, we’re getting to know our customers better, the service is generating income, and we are almost at a point where we are generating positive cash flow! 
While we’re covering our current day-to-day operating costs, we need your help to expand and our services to the households that need our service the most. We are raising 15,000 USD for the down payment on a new exhauster truck that will allow us to scale our services beyond our current reach.
Acquisition of a truck will allow us to double our daily revenue and slash operating costs by 20%. In addition, a truck will allow us to serve more households per day and add an additional emptying team, creating approximately 10 more low-skilled jobs in Kigali.


Pit Vidura's Impact
If you’re reading this, you probably know a world where urban environments are free of disease causing pollution and where sanitation services are provided by trained sanitation workers providing quality services that are affordable. But the overwhelming majority-over 90%- of waste generated worldwide is dumped into the environment untreated.
With your support, Pit Vidura can purchase our own exhauster truck and increase the impact of our work by:

Lowering our costs to serve Kigali's poorest households
Performing more empties and increasing the removal of of pathogenic waste removed from communities-- preventing diarrheal disease and eutrophication 
Creating more jobs for low-skilled workers 
Developing the tools and technology to promote safe emptying practices worldwide


Frequently Asked Questions 

Why not build sewers?
Sewers are not always the best urban solution. They are inappropriate where water is very scarce – and where it isn’t feasible to extend them to lower-income settlements or those on city outskirts. In many cases, focusing on sewers for urban sanitation means that only the wealthy get served. Sewer systems also require high up-front capital investment, and depend on the availability of reliable water and energy supplies.  
A mix of technical solutions including both onsite and sewerage solutions is needed to ensure citywide inclusive sanitation—a sanitation system in which everybody benefits from sanitation infrastructure. Pit Vidura focuses on developing the components of an inclusive sanitation plan that benefit the poorest of the poor in the hardest to reach urban locations.
Do you make profits or are you a non-for-profit? Are these contributions tax deductible?
​​ We operate as a social enterprise. While we are a revenue-generating business, all of our surpluses are reinvested in our programs and scaling our emptying services to more communities in Rwanda and beyond.  We are legally not eligible to have tax-exempt status.
I want to donate but I don't want to do this online. How can I get in touch with the team? 
Please reach out directly to Rachel[at]pitvidura[dot]com
Is there a shipping cost?
Yes, there is a shipping cost for all of the perks associated with your contributions. When you pay for shipping, we have more money left over to dedicate to transforming sanitation in Rwanda!
For shipping within the U.S., add $7.00-$10.00 (depends on your perk) to your pledge amount.For shipping outside of the U.S., add $20.00-$30.00 (depends on your perk) to your pledge amount.
How do I specify between bag and t-shirt, and t-shirt size? 
If you donate $50 and above, you should receive an email asking about your preferences between t-shirt or a tote bag, t-shirt size, and mailing address. If you have any other questions please contact Julia at julia[at]pitvidura.com.
 
Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Send this campaign to your friends, family, and colleagues
Use Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign and/or your participation with your social media networks

story:
We love animals, and so does the most of the internet!

You can find groups, profiles and communities of animal lovers everywhere, on every social network. So why shouldn't pets have their own social network, just for them?

Another reason behind this idea is a large number of animals in shelters and on the streets. We want to help those animals. We could have just created an app for that, but we are aware that an app for that purpose only would have low user base and therefor insufficient impact.

Through analyzing and planning we came up with this idea. People love animals, they love to share them and look at them. By creating a network specified for this type of content we are connecting all animal lovers in one place, increasing the potential impact of our message. Which will hopefully inspire those who don't have pets to adopt them and find homes for as many sheltered animals as possible.

Help us make this happen! Let's help as many animals as we can, together!

PetConnect is a Social Network App dedicated to all our pets. PetConnect allows you to interact with pet owners all around the world, sharing experiences and multimedia content such as posts, photos and videos about your pets.

Simply register or log in with facebook, add your pets and their info, choose what you are interested in and you're ready to go! Post content, include your's and other pets, share and make your pet famous! Explore all kinds of pets or funny pet images and moments. Enjoy a place thats all about pets!

One of the biggest risks is low user base of our app. Of course PetConnect will function even with few users, but our goal is provide all users with enough content to choose from, and create large community for people with similar interests, our love of animals!

What will we do to overcome this risk?

For this reason we have set aside a certain budget from the campaign to be used for marketing. We also have many partners and supporters of our project that have communities of their own to share our app with! And last but not least we trust YOU, our supporters, to help us spread the word and share it with your friends, family and everyone you know how loves animals. You don't even have to be an animal lover to enjoy looking at all these cute animals!

Other challenges

Also some of other challenges that we might encounter are spam, ads and irregular content on our network. We want our network to be spam and ads free, and only for pets. All we want to see in this app are pets, for everything else there are other social networks, apps and sites. We will reserve this network for animals only! What is our plan on solving this challenge?

Our plan in dealing with this challenge is having strict policy for irregular content posters. Each user will be able to report any post he or she thinks does not belong on PetConnect or his/hers feed. The reports will be closely tracked by us and every post will be either moved to the right category or deleted, and spam or advertisement accounts will be deleted.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute with money, no sweat! There are still a few great ways you can really help us make this project a reality:

Get the word out! Use the Indiegogo share tools and tell your friends and family about the project.

Give us feedback. We LOVE feedback because we constantly strive to improve for our amazing users.

After all we are doing this for YOU, so tell us what you would like to add in the app! Or tell us what you think of the campaign, the perks, or anything!

Thank you for your support!

story:
HI!

We are E.C.O.S- a team of 6 students working on a course project that we hope will make a positive small change in our community.

The focus behind our campaign is the conservation of water through rainwater collection. We are campaigning to raise funds to purchase a water tank to collect rainwater from the rooftop of the horticulture greenhouse at Thompson Rivers University. 

Horticulture plays an important role throughout universities by educating students and expanding their knowledge on various educational aspects, including gardening, sustainability, and  current green initiatives throughout the larger community. Students who are employed in this field will have jobs that directly or indirectly relate to caring for plants, fruits, and vegetables. 

The horticulture department's aim is to protect, nurture, and improve the life of plants while making them resistant to: diseases, insects, and environmental stress from human and the natural environment. 

OUR GOAL is to work with the Horticulture department and create an environment that is both sustainable and healthy to the plants. With our idea, the department can collect water that will not burden the Kamloops water supply. 

There are so many benefits of rain water collection on campus and in the community: 

- Rainwater provides an easy, reliable and inexpensive complementary source for the greenhouse's water needs

- It shows a commitment from the university when it comes to the importance of water conservation, and other resource saving initiatives associated with living in a desert climate.  

- Saving water will also save money: as a community, we are now metered on water use, and rainwater is a free source once the equipment is installed.

Other benefits for Horticulture:

 -  Becoming a leader in sustainable development in the community

-  Teach students about the value of water to their livelihood and ways to collect your own water

-  Ability to educate others on the vast potential of rainwater capture in Kamloops

-  On a citywide scale, it would limit pollution from runoff entering our waterways

-  Defence against droughts and water restrictions; with a storage tank, you can store water from times when it rains more enabling an individual to continue watering their garden, plants and lawn in times of water restrictions.

-  Cost savings!


What We Need 

We are looking to crowdfund 1000.00 CAD which will go towards purchasing a rain water collection system for the TRU horticulture greenhouse. 

Our goal of raising $1000.00 can be broken down into the following: 

-Water Barrel 

-Filter

Plus any additional shipping and installation costs.

If our goal is not entirely met, the money will be passed on directly to the horticulture department, who will continue on with the efforts of creating a sustainable water collection system for the greenhouse.


Other Ways You Can Help

By following the link below, you can access resources to help make water collection possible in your own community! 

By sharing this page and the website below, you will be making a simple, sustainable initiative on campus a reality, demonstrating that anything is possible- and something as simple as rain water collection CAN and WILL make a difference! 

every last drop counts.

http://www.ecosh2o.com/

story:
My name is Daniel Bernazzani. I have a Ph.D. in Environmental Studies from Antioch University. I have seen first hand the damage floods cause. Unfortunately, once the floodwaters recede and TV cameras are gone, secondary damage from mold and other microorganisms becomes a potetial health health concern for homeoweners and cleanup workers alike. Post-flood dangers can be dramatically reduced with simple training. Shockingly, the US has no central training organization for flood victims or volunteers. The educational resources currently available are fragmented and fraught with outdated procedures that could endanger the very individuals the information seeks to protect.

To remedy this situation, Flood Safe Habitats will provide up-to-date, centralized, accessible online training developed by leading experts in the field.

What We Need

We need funding to produce our first training video that provides guidance to workers. We need this because in the absence of insurance coverage or other funds necessary to secure the services of a professional water damage mitigation contractor, the homeowner is faced with the formidable task of conducting the remediation, typically with the assistance of friends, relatives, or volunteers. In these situations it is imperative that the homeowner and volunteers be sufficiently prepared to conduct such an effort with professional guidance and with the health and safety of all involved uppermost in mind. It is crucial to point out some areas of the home that appear to have only minor mold growth or appear to be or non-water damaged, may actually harbor considerable contamination. Moreover, other hazards may be present. Our training can help prevent further disaster.

Our program is an extremely cost-effective way to thwart preventable diseases and potential hazards. Along with the reduction in human suffering, this program should reduce the burden on healthcare, eliminate duplication of efforts by state and local organizations, and provide a resource that can be readily updated as new remediation techniques are developed.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate please tell others to visit and help us train people to work safely.

story:
*Who We Are

Mother Earth Buildings

Is an organization that shares  skills and knowledge for people to create their own sustainable way of life.

We are the founders and creators of this organization. It feels like for most of our life, we both have had the desire to make a difference in peoples lives. Since our meeting with each other while building a straw bale cabin in New York, we have set upon this amazing journey together.  Both of us come from a background in alternative building and have been living our lives in the most effective and efficient way we can. We have taught people about building with natural materials and have helped with the site design and layouts for many eco villages in Europe, as well as, Friland, where we currently live in Denmark. Our family also includes Bella, our 2 year old daughter who is the most beautiful, friendly and loving little person you could ever meet. We want to do everything we can to make a positive impact, for people, families, and all living creatures on earth.

My name is Peter Jensen. I come from Denmark. For 15 years I have been in love with straw bale homes. I've found how easy it is to live in harmony with nature and found such joy in building. I've been involved in building a lot of straw and wooden houses throughout the world and have designed many of them. I have given a number of presentations on sustainable housing and ecological ways of living with nature. I am a product developer and am always trying to find better ways to build houses. I am a project leader for building and designing schools and homes for the people of Nepal. I have seen great success with the work I have done in Nepal and would like to continue that throughout the world.  I have traveled around the world and have seen many poor people use so much energy to just survive, which has touched me deeply. We have created solutions to help give these people a better life.  My heart has fallen in love with spreading sustainable knowledge around the world.

My name is Ashley Ritzel. I am from Upstate New York in the U.S. I have been involved with natural building for a number of years and have experience with permaculture in a number of different climates as well. I love learning new ways of building to understand what works best in order  to create self-sufficiency around the world. I find it extremely rewarding to share information with people that enables them to be independent. Not only is it sustainable to build with natural materials, it can be healing on many levels as well. By working together in creating something, people learn the importance of teamwork and develop healthy relationships with each other, themselves and the planet. I enjoy teaching and facilitating these workshops for people to come together and experience this deep connection.

*Our Lifes Passion

MEB wants to make e-books that explain simple step by step methods in how local and natural materials can be used to create an inexpensive, safe and beautiful home. We want to fill our website, with the knowledge and information on how to become self-sufficient in food, electricity, water and heating of houses made from natural and renewable materials.

We feel extremely passionate about our goal in making a difference for people around the world.  We have traveled and seen with our own eyes, the unnecessary suffering of many poor people around the world. We have the personal experience with living in sustainable ways, as well as, building and design experience. We realize how simple and important it is to live in harmony with mother earth.  So, we want to do our part in sharing this life changing information to make a difference for all people around the world.

*How YOU can help

“Give a man a fish, feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish, feed him for his life.” Chinese proverb

With your support, Mother Earth Buildings can reach the lives of millions of people around the world.  We can help teach people how to become self-reliant and independent through living sustainably. We don’t just want to give people a home or food for them to be safe and healthy. We want to give people the knowledge for them to be able to support themselves and to be independent from outside resources.

 

*What We Need

We are looking to raise $20,000.00.

 

In many places throughout the world, many people live on less than a dollar a day. With every dollar we receive, an enormous amount is being accomplished.

We are seeking $20,000.00.

With this amount of money we are able to accomplish the following.

We will have the funding to go ahead and create 42 simple step by step E-books. They will include solutions for building various sustainable housing and hundreds of ways for one to become self- sufficient in food, power and water. All of these ideas can be utilized by wealthy and poor populations in any climate throughout the world.

We will have the funding to attend a workshop at CAL-EARTH in Hesperia, California to learn how to build using sandbags.

We will have the money to purchase the computer and equipment that allows us to update and manage our website.

Even if we do not reach our goal of $20,000.00 we will still be able to use the funds received. We can use the money towards the expense of writing and creating a variety of E-books on sustainability and to the cost of managing and updating our website for people to access information, videos and guides for free.

SO….Every little bit counts!

 

 

 

*Amazing Gifts of gratitude

We have number of AMAZING perks to thank you for helping us reach our goal. Peter works in Nepal quite a bit, and has brought back some very unique and stunning gifts.

Our hand designed thank you card with a photo of a child that has been helped in Nepal. We have three sizes of Tibetan prayer flags that have been blessed by a Llama, some extremely beautiful hand made wooden Mala beads on red string, a hand carved peace sign pendant to wear, a CD of Tibetan Buddhist monk chants recorded in the Himalayan Mountains, twin gongs used during meditation practices cast from precious metals, and four sizes of singing bowls hand tapped from Bronze.

These gifts are a genuine gift from us to you as a thank you for helping us reach our dream of making a difference for the lives of millions of people around the world.

 

 

*Our Success

We have had success with projects completed around the globe. We have built schools and houses for needy children in Nepal. These buildings were constructed using local and natural materials and built using man power and hand tools. If you don’t realize how phenomenal this is, try and think about cutting a 20 ft. long tree into a four sided beam using only a hand saw.  This project helped create the necessary and vital schools for impoverished students in the frigid climate of the Himalayan Mountains.  We have also helped start numerous ecovillages in Europe that are very successful.

With your help we have a better chance to reach people around the world that are in serious need of basic things to survive. We don’t want to go and put a band aid on the problem, we are dedicated to finding the best answers and giving people these solutions.

 

 

 *Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for all different kinds of help.

 As a new organization on the non-profit scene, we need some advice on where to go and what to next. We would love some helpful person that can assist us in filing some NPO paperwork. Maybe some savvy web creators that can give us some advice in making our site better? If you feel compelled to help and make a difference in the world, but don’t have money to support us, we would love to accept other offers!

You can definitely help out our organization by checking out our website www.motherearthbuildings.com and Facebook page. https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mother-Earth-Buildings/500358736644356?ref=hl

Please tell your friends and anyone you know that may be interested or able to help! We appreciate your thoughts and help in reaching our goal … Namaste

We will have the money to purchase the computer and equipment that allows us to update and manage our website.
Even if we do not reach our goal of $20,000.00 we will still be able to use the funds received. We can use the money towards the expense of writing and creating a variety of E-books on sustainability and to the cost of managing and updating our website for people to access information, videos and guides for free.
SO….Every little bit counts!
 
 
 
*Amazing Gifts of gratitude
We have number of AMAZING perks to thank you for helping us reach our goal. Peter works in Nepal quite a bit, and has brought back some very unique and stunning gifts.
Our hand designed thank you card with a photo of a child that has been helped in Nepal. We have three sizes of Tibetan prayer flags that have been blessed by a Llama, some extremely beautiful hand made wooden Mala beads on red string, a hand carved peace sign pendant to wear, a CD of Tibetan Buddhist monk chants recorded in the Himalayan Mountains, twin gongs used during meditation practices cast from precious metals, and four sizes of singing bowls hand tapped from Bronze.
These gifts are a genuine gift from us to you as a thank you for helping us reach our dream of making a difference for the lives of millions of people around the world.
 
 
*Our Success
We have had success with projects completed around the globe. We have built schools and houses for needy children in Nepal. These buildings were constructed using local and natural materials and built using man power and hand tools. If you don’t realize how phenomenal this is, try and think about cutting a 20 ft. long tree into a four sided beam using only a hand saw.  This project helped create the necessary and vital schools for impoverished students in the frigid climate of the Himalayan Mountains.  We have also helped start numerous ecovillages in Europe that are very successful.
With your help we have a better chance to reach people around the world that are in serious need of basic things to survive. We don’t want to go and put a band aid on the problem, we are dedicated to finding the best answers and giving people these solutions.
 
 
 *Other Ways You Can Help
We are looking for all different kinds of help.
 As a new organization on the non-profit scene, we need some advice on where to go and what to next. We would love some helpful person that can assist us in filing some NPO paperwork. Maybe some savvy web creators that can give us some advice in making our site better? If you feel compelled to help and make a difference in the world, but don’t have money to support us, we would love to accept other offers!
You can definitely help out our organization by checking out our website www.motherearthbuildings.com and Facebook page. https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mother-Earth-Buildings/500358736644356?ref=hl
Please tell your friends and anyone you know that may be interested or able to help! We appreciate your thoughts and help in reaching our goal … Namaste

story:
Bamboo Forest Fruits is the name of an independent initiative, located in Tenerife, Spain. The name in itself is quite descriptive and to simplify it even more: Bamboo means wood, Forest means biodiversity and Fruits means food.

Tenerife is a volcanic island in the North Atlantic Ocean and belongs to the group of islands called Canary islands, situated close to African continent and are part of Macaronesia. It is a home to one of the largest volcano and one of the richest biodiversity in the world, but also, one of the most fragile ecosystems, that are highly sensitive to climate change, threatened by the pollution and loss of natural habitat, due to the conventional agriculture, unsustainable tourism and urbanization. Here in the island, we developed an even greater passion for nature and have spent most of the time, in recent years, learning about the climate, ecosystems, plants and other living creatures, while gaining more experience in agriculture and Eco-tourism.

This is how the idea to establish the nature reserve with Eco-retreat and the food forest was born. Finally, we have a suitable plots of land to start this project and now are few months here, living and working, but we need more funds to continue the work. Some of the funds needed are crucial and urgent, for example water compartments and ponds, to give us an important security of water supply for irrigation. 

Our regenerative agriculture concept consists of a mix of few agricultural systems and our own interpretations. The aim is to rejuvenate the degraded agricultural land, increase natural productivity and biodiversity, combat soil contamination and desertification, adapt agriculture to natural conditions and cycles.

Agroforestry system is a combination of forestry and agriculture, where trees and shrubs grow alongside smaller edible plants or pasture. This type of agriculture gaining increasing recognition around the world, as a way of reducing land desertification, soil and water contamination and the carbon emissions, produced by the conventional agriculture. 

Food forest or edible forest is another term of gardening in harmony with nature, following the nature's patterns and letting the natural formation of ecosystem to take place, it is a low-intervention and low-maintenance type of gardening. The term food forest is now widely adopted by the permaculture enthusiasts and community gardeners alike, and is associated with polyculture gardening.

Bamboo is a perfect woody crop for both agroforestry and permaculture systems with the unbeatable benefits of growth rate, self-regeneration and resilience. Bamboo plays an important role of providing alternative, green material for construction, furniture and numerous everyday items, that are currently made of unsustainable materials, including highly polluting plastic and aluminium.  Besides, bamboo absorbs high levels of CO2 and produce more oxygen than trees. There are two main types of bamboo, clumping (non-invasive) and running (invasive). We plant only non-invasive clumping bamboos. 

An important part of this project is the integration of agriculture with consumers. The social networks and the on site visits enable the consumer to familiarize with the process of food production, consequently develop a better understanding of nature and agriculture. The one to one relations with the grower and the buyer, reduces food waste and carbon footprint, optimizes the quality and freshness, creates a greater value for consumer and fairer profit for producer.

The idea to create a small eco-retreat is to provide an ecological and affordable accommodation surrounded by nature and powered by renewable energy. Visitors have the benefit of fresh fruits, veg and herbs grown here, an opportunity to experience the rural life of northwestern side of Tenerife and learn about agriculture and natural surroundings.

What are the funds for:

  1. Water compartments and ponds for irrigation. The pond also has a role of attracting wildlife. For irrigation purposes, it is needed for connecting to the antique canal system and to store water, this is known as "own water". The company that provides water for us at the moment has a low quality water, frequent pressure problems and cuts during the summer, when it is needed the most. We prefer not to use irrigation, but for young plants and trees it is crucial and it is necessary for the veg and fruit gardens, during the drought. 
  2. Bamboos, fruit trees and other edible plants. We have already started planting bamboos, fruit trees, bushes and climbing plants, also herbs and veggies. There are a wide selection of the plants that can be established in the land, because of the mild climate conditions and the different micro climates here, due to the altitude variations and sun and wind distribution. The size of the plot for planting is 4000 square meters and is spread through the 167 - 200  meters in altitude.
  3. Nature resort and retreat. The largest part of the property is the mountain, an area of 10000 square meters (1  hectare). Most of it is already protected, as it is located Teno Rural Park boundaries. The plan is to clean and fix the paths, replant some local flora and create a view point.  Although the Eco-retreat accommodation will be constructed in the lower and gated area. The geodesic dome structure cabin, will have all the basic amenities and due to the shape and open design, spacious and airy. The mixture off glass and wood, makes it light, fresh and warm. The dome is not only the strongest structure known, it is also energy efficient.
  4. Renewable energy. We have 3500 W solar system, which we need to double to make it more efficient.
  5. New entrance. There are two entrances at the moment, but both of them with the difficult access for vehicles.  It is necessary to create new entrance for the easy access and to avoid accidents and damages to vehicles.
  6. Gates and fences. Due to the age and the material, some need to be fixed or replaced.

There is a lot that needs to be done and we ask you for help. In return we offer some exciting perks. If you cannot help financially, there are other ways you can support this project by sharing with friends, family and social networks.

story:
Our Story

The Earth Junkies Project uses storytelling to develop creative, social, life and literacy skills around ecological issues, principally among children.  The project targets relationships between individuals and their environment, their ideas on conservation, its importance, and how these ideas are shared between generations. 

The project works in schools and alongside teachers. During each workshop the following core aims will be fulfilled: 

• Developing the first global Children’s Charter for the Rights for Mother Earth, a document consisting of promises made by children on how they will try to protect Mother Earth. 

• Compiling the first series of ‘The Adventures of the Earth Junkies’ stories, a series of tales about conservation created along with children through storytelling workshops.

• Producing a feature-length documentary under the working title: ‘Mother Earth and Me’.

• Leaving each school with an indigenous tree that they are encouraged to take personal responsibility for. 

The Impact

We recognise that a huge part of our current environmental problem is the growing disconnection between people and their natural environment.  In working with children to re-establish this connection we are planting a seed that, no matter how small, will grow to have an effect on their future, as well as those they come into contact with.  There can be no doubt that environmental conservation is one of the most pressing responsibilities humanity faces today.  With your help we can do a series of workshops in a very significant area in South Africa, The Cradle of Humankind (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), and from there develop a 15min short film and interactive website to take this project to the next level and spread even more awareness online.

What We Need & What You Getâ€¨

We have several volunteers that will work with us in the week to compile the film, but we need $8000 USD to hire enough cameras, develop an interactive website, buy stationary and recycled paper and produce a cutting-edge little short-film to inspire the world through the heartfelt responses and ideas of children about our planet online.

The Earth Junkies Project encourages cross-cultural understandings and experiences of climate change and environmental conservation issues, promoting a global ecological citizenship grounded in local knowledge. By supporting us you can, like all children, become a part of a global first-initiative, adding your own pledges to the Children’s Charter for the Rights for Mother Earth by means of a small amount of money.

You are investing money into an initiative that is driven by creatives and conservationists that care. We are always enthusiastically at work in South Africa and not planning to stop any time soon.

Other Ways You Can Help

There is only one way we can really help the children's wishes for the planet to be heard, and that is with your help. Please share our Facebook Page (The Earth Junkies Project), follow our blog (earthjunkies.blogspot.com), watch our trailer above and send it to friends and keep up to date with us on Twitter @EarthJunkies.

story:
Who We Are

We are students at the University of Arizona who are traveling to South Africa this summer with International Student Volunteers. Here's a little info to tell you who we are.

Ashlynn Harris is a 4th year student studying animal science. She is traveling with ISV for the first time.

Justin Marshall is a 4th year student in biomedical engineering and has previously volunteered with ISV in New Zealand doing conservation work. He was involved in helping to plant over 4,000 native trees and plants to help regrow lost forest in New Zealand.

Amber Sumpter is a 4th year student dual majoring in journalism and gender and women's studies. She has previsouly worked with ISV in the Domincan Republic

Most of us had our passion for traveling and volunteering sparked with our first ventures with ISV and are greatly looking forward to working with them again.

What We Need & What You Get

The project will cost $3,795 for each of us, which will cover lodging, program fees, a mojority of food costs, and touring costs. In addition we will have to cover airfaire and any other fees that come up, so overall it is roughley $5,000 a piece. This campaign is to get some funds to get everyone a little help.

Whatever is raised during this campaign will be distributed evenly to the students involved.

The Impact

The South Africa trip offers both community development and conservation work as a focus for the volunteers, chosen at the preference of the volunteer upon signing up.

Community development includes building schools and playgrounds, community health and education programs, sustainable food production, and recreational activities for children.

Conservation work includes working at wildlife preserves, preservation of habitats, and wildlife park management.

ISV offers several award winning programs and recently won "Outstanding Volunteer Project" at the World Youth and Travel Conference held in Barcelona, Spain. This is a conference of over 450 world travel and volunteer programs. Over the past decade they have sent of 25,000 volunteers across six different countries to allow students to have a positive impact on the world.

The ISV alumni doing this campaign know how rewarding international volunteering is, and their individual journies have led them to once more put their efforts into ISV because they know that they can really make a difference. Any help in these efforts would be greatly appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help even more by sharing this page with anyone you can. Facebook, twitter, or just tell your friends, even if all it does is spread the message about volunteering that will help.

If you would like to get involved with this program check out the ISV webpage http://www.isvolunteers.org/  Most of us are ISV alumni and have been greatly influenced to continue volunteering thanks to them. If you have any questions about ISV that you can't find on the webpage feel free to ask us!

story:
Global Mission:

  So how much can ONE person do really?  The world is warming and there are millions of people, animals, and plants struggling to survive these days.  Every one needs, at minimum, food, water, and shelter.  Michael Reynolds created Earthships as a solution to these needs.  He has encountered many obstacles in America as he experimented with recycled materials to build architecture over the past 30 years.  Yet his work is changing lives and communities in third world countries devastated by tropical storms. I want to join him and his hardworking crew.

I personally have been searching for a cause in recent years.  I get frustrated as an Artist and Painting Conservator struggling to sell my work to the 1 percent to survive.  As an Environmentalist who longs to be of service, I can't wait to learn from the ground up how Earthships are made so that I can begin to share this knowledge with those who need it most.  Every Earthship is unique in all the world and is a piece of functional art in itself!  I believe we all need to live more simply and to not waste any resources especially water.  Reynold's Earthship is a self contained dwelling where food is grown, water recycled, and solar energy gained.  What an opportunity to get off the grid and stop feeding the oil mongers!!!  Visit www.earthship.com for more information.

This campaign will fund my participation in a two week build from February 23 - March 4, 2014 on Samar Island in the Philippines near the town of Basey.  The Earthship we will build is the beginning of what will be the Windship Village.  It will be built partly into the ground with recycled local materials and will house a food bunker and medical unit upon completion.  We will be educating the locals so that they can continue to build sustainable Windships for their entire village and beyond.  The Windship is a type of Earthship specially designed by Reynolds to withstand the winds and rains prevalent in tropical regions.

In this time of scarce resources, we need to use materials we already have available.  We need long term solutions.  Earthships are made using recycled bottles, tires, and local earth.  Building them is low cost and creates a sturdy structure that collects rain water and uses the water to feed indoor plants which is then filtered for other uses.  Earthships use natural light to light the interior, and takes full advantage of passive solar to avoid additional energy costs.  So once you are in an Earthship, you don't need to depend on the energy grid to stay warm!  Building and educating about Earthship construction allows humans a long term solution to meeting their basic needs   Earthships empower communities as they lessen their dependence on the outside.

Project Budget:

$1000 = my financial contribution to be a part of the Earthship Team;

     This money goes to the costs of the project for the entire team.

$1500 = Flight costs (It's expensive to fly to the Philippines!!!)

$500 = Travel related expenses including parking, driving, eating, kenneling my dog. .

$1200 = My monthly expenses that won't be funded while I am making Perks and Volunteering including cell phone, equipment storage, and insurance.

Total Campaign Budget:  $4200

What you Get:

As patrons of this project, you will receive a One-of-a-Kind creation made by me, Artist Deborah Uhl.  Most recently, I have ventured into the fashion realm, creating eye-turning accessories and clothing using a combination of antique objects and found materials.  My unique line of embellished hats and head wear are sure to bring joy to the people around you as well as to the wearer. I have made it a point to dress up everyday "in celebration" of being alive since a car accident I survived in 2009.  Now I want to share my wearable art with all of my friends, family, and patrons far and wide so they can receive complements like I have for years!  Larger perks include becoming a collector of an original Deborah Uhl oil painting, or having a custom Pet Portrait made of your family friend, or someone else's.  Check out my art and references at www.deborahuhl.com.

If I do not reach my campaign goals, the funds will be set aside for the next Internship I can participate in with the Earthship Community.  In April, they will be going to Easter Island to build a Music School.  I may also intern with them at their home base in Taos, New Mexico if I do not acquire the funds to go abroad.  Either way, I will learn how to build an Earthship using their latest technologies.  Then I can share this knowledge of building affordable sustainable housing with those in need in the future. 

This campaign is an important project to fund because:


People in the Philippines need affordable housing NOW!

Sustainable off-the-grid housing is the long term solution to meeting the basic needs of humans in this time of increasing global warming. 

We need more active young fancy free people like myself boarding planes to help those in need.  I travel far and wide for my Conservation work and I plan to share my new found knowledge wherever I go.

Eventually I will build my own Earthship/Art Studio and then my carbon footprint will become much much smaller!

I want to stay in touch with all of you and let you know how to build your own Earthship, live more sustainably, and be more actively involved in our greater global community. 

Creative minds are worth financially supporting.  Our global community needs to encourage people like Michael Reynolds and myself who think outside the box.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much and Blessings to all of you in this New Year!

I have made it a point to dress up everyday "in celebration" of being alive since a car accident I survived in 2009.  Now I want to share my wearable art with all of my friends, family, and patrons far and wide so they can receive complements like I have for years!  Larger perks include becoming a collector of an original Deborah Uhl oil painting, or having a custom Pet Portrait made of your family friend, or someone else's.  Check out my art and references at www.deborahuhl.com.If I do not reach my campaign goals, the funds will be set aside for the next Internship I can participate in with the Earthship Community.  In April, they will be going to Easter Island to build a Music School.  I may also intern with them at their home base in Taos, New Mexico if I do not acquire the funds to go abroad.  Either way, I will learn how to build an Earthship using their latest technologies.  Then I can share this knowledge of building affordable sustainable housing with those in need in the future.  This campaign is an important project to fund because:
People in the Philippines need affordable housing NOW!Sustainable off-the-grid housing is the long term solution to meeting the basic needs of humans in this time of increasing global warming.  We need more active young fancy free people like myself boarding planes to help those in need.  I travel far and wide for my Conservation work and I plan to share my new found knowledge wherever I go.Eventually I will build my own Earthship/Art Studio and then my carbon footprint will become much much smaller!I want to stay in touch with all of you and let you know how to build your own Earthship, live more sustainably, and be more actively involved in our greater global community.  Creative minds are worth financially supporting.  Our global community needs to encourage people like Michael Reynolds and myself who think outside the box.Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you so much and Blessings to all of you in this New Year!

story:
Social Need

Water quality is a global concern. Almost 1 billion people lack access to safe drinking water and 2 million die every year from unsafe water. Even in the United States, it is estimated that as many as 2,000,000 households have drinking water with dangerously high levels of nitrate, a serious threat to infants (methemoglobinemia, more commonly known as "blue baby syndrome", inhibits oxygen transport by red blood cells).

Due to adverse environmental impacts from industry, inadequate and aging municipal infrastructure, and general shortcomings of regulatory systems, there is an express need for everyday citizen's to take more responsibility in the monitoring the environmental health of their world. Beyond our own health and safety, this need is especially vital if we want to ensure a sustainable future for our children. However, the scientific equipment and technical training required to accomplish this task is beyond the reach of most citizens, even in wealthy nations like the United States. In response to this great social need, we're developing a low-cost, high-accuracy, and extremely versatile sensor technology that makes use of nanotechnology and integrates with mobile devices: MoboSens.

MoboSens will give anyone with a smartphone the ability to measure the concentration of common pollutants - like nitrate, arsenic, chromium, lead - in water (municipal supply, private wells) and even soil (if properly prepared). The platform will enable them to share that information through the Internet. How that data improves human health and safety, as well as fosters more effective regulatory systems, could be revolutionary.
About the Project

Our innovative project is a mobile sensor platform that is both affordable and possesses the accuracy and precision of expensive bench-top laboratory equipment. Our platform, through integration with mobile communications, enables spatial reporting of quantitative environmental data through our public data repository. If funded, we will develop a field-ready handheld water quality sensor for heavy metal (initial focus on arsenic) and nitrate detection. We have already validated our sensing technique for nitrate, but the hardware and casing needs refinement before it will be ready for field use. Future sensing targets include phosphate and bacteria.

About Us

We're a team of engineers from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. We're applying nanotechnology in new and exciting ways, building better sensors that cost less and can be scaled for global use. We're focused on improving environmental monitoring and health & human safety. We're passionate about removing barriers to advanced scientific instruments and coupling these devices with other disruptive technologies, like social media and geospatial information systems. We're building MoboSens because we want our research to mean something more than journal publications - we want to improve the world we live in.

Project Lead

Dr. Logan Liu, Assistant Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering

Sensor Development

Manas Gartia, Doctoral Candidate in Nuclear, Plasma and Radiological Engineering
Xinhao Wang, Doctoral Candidate in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Jing "Jimmy" Jiang, Doctoral Candidate in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Te-Wei Chang, Doctoral Candidate in Electrical and Computer Engineering

Software Development

Tristan Wietsma, Doctoral Candidate at the Illinois Informatics Institute
Caleb Qian, Graduate Student in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Will Wang, Senior Undergraduate in Computer Engineering

Stage of the Project and What Your Contribution Means

This project builds on technologies developed through research that we have dedicated our professional and personal lives towards. We have already developed a prototype version of our low-cost handheld sensor for nitrate measurement. The performance of this proof-of-concept device is impressive; we're detecting nitrate down to 25 parts-per-billion at a fraction of the cost of typical methods. We have field validated data sharing using Twitter. While we're very happy with our proof-of-concept, but we're nowhere near full potential.

We anticipate the project will take up to two years to reach full scale for all planned sensing targets. We plan to start deploying our sensor for nitrate measurement within the next 6 months, working with citizen scientist groups (research institutes, NGOs) in Illinois. If this early testing proves successful, we'll scale up as needed. Given our sensor's construction process, we are confident that contract manufacturing will be able to easily produce our hardware at low cost and high quality. We're also developing partnerships with individuals, non-profits, and for-profit companies that share our vision.

Currently, using on-campus rapid prototyping facilities, we can make our sensor hardware for under $200 per unit. Once scaled beyond 500 units, we estimate that price will drop substantially under $100. In addition to expanding sensing capabilities (our next focus is on heavy metals), money raised will go towards improving the device for mass manufacture and producing an initial batch to be validated by citizen scientists affiliated the University of Illinois.

story:
Hi there!

We are 2 Environmental science majors who are getting involved in a summer conversation project in South America this summer. We are both “hippies” at heart and saw this as a great way to spend our summer! Not only do we get to go and visit one of the most beautiful and bio diverse parts of the world, we also get to make a difference in a field we believe so passionately in. Not only do we get to do important conservation work we also get the chance to learn another language, Spanish! We are hoping that we can get you excited about our project and then follow our progress as we lead up to leaving and then as we explore Costa Rica!

 

This coming summer the 2 of us will be undertaking the ISV Student  Volunteer project in Costa Rica, South America.  The International Student Vollunteers is a worldwide organisation that works to connect students from university’s around the world with volunteer projects focusing on community development and conversation initiatives.

 

We have both chosen to undertake the Conservation project which involves at least 80 hours of volunteering work in Costa Rica over a fortnight! We know this experience will broaden our awareness of environmental issues outside our own backyard and give as hands on, practical experience we can use in the future.

Our team will be working in areas such as,

  • Endangered species protection such as beach patrols and light construction for sea turtle hatchlings.
  • Observing and recording animal numbers and behaviours.
  • Restoring and researching animal habitats.

 

While working in these areas we know we will also be getting a special inside look at sustainable resources and responsible development of our natural environment. A fortunate outcome of being involved in this amazing project is that it will earn us some academic credit towards our environmental science degrees!

 

 Support Us!

 

We are asking for help so that we can be involved in this project! While we will be funding our own personal parts of the project such as our flights, food and equipment, we could of course use your help in helping us do the Conservation project!

If you do get involved with us we do hope that you will get involved and follow us on our journey. Not only will we be keeping you up to date with a blog and frequent emails but we are also opening up our Facebook accounts to all of you so that you won’t miss a minute of the excitement! Also as a little bit of an incentive in getting involved with us we are also giving you guys some personalised perks that are close to our hearts. You can see all of these on the left!

 

We hope you want to get involved with us!

 Jackie & Amy

.
