For many, Shadow Box is their first theatrical experience. The interactive nature of the shows allows them to participate regardless of functional level. Elementary, special education, ESL and family audiences alike respond to the vivid sights and sounds of an SBT performance. Because of this direct involvement, Shadow Box Theatre shows have become cherished landmarks in the imaginative lives of their young audiences. Family weekend performances afford an unparalleled opportunity for cross-cultural exchange, drawing a faithful following from the immediate neighborhood and the extended metropolitan area. Shadow Box audiences continue to share their enthusiasm with classmates, friends and family long after the show is over. The impact on one child who sat in the audience years ago was so long-lasting that he went on later to become an SBT performer.
When the recent Hurricane Sandy hit New York City, it brought damage of floods, school closings, show cancellations, and major disruptions, impacting many children and families. As we look forward and see much of New York still suffering in the aftermath, we know we must maintain our plans for our spring production, The Earth & Me, even though, due to the hurricane, it is a fiscal risk. This show feels particularly vital now as it teaches peace and environmental stewardship and brings hope and empowerment to children through the inspiring mediums of story, dance, and song. Although much of the world has moved on from Hurricane Sandy, for the children and families affected by power outages and floods, the pervading darkness and fear around not having a home continues. And for others it is not easily forgotten.
What 2012 Brought: 

We all know that the economic downturn has taken its toll on many enterprises, including The Shadow Box Theatre. As a result we entered 2012 with very little money left in the bank for a “rainy day.” Our earnings are a major source of our income and Hurricane Sandy caused us to lose most of our fall season. Because of school closings, disruption in New York City transportation, and cancelled school trips for almost the entire month of November, our fall season was greatly curtailed and resulted in us losing $37,000 in expected revenue. Most recently, our winter season has also gotten off to a challenging start. The school bus strike in NYC means teachers do not have a way to transport their children to our shows. If there are no school buses, there is little to no audience. Already we have had many cancellations of our run of The African Drum, which celebrates African-American History Month. We do not yet know its entire fiscal impact. However, we do know the income loss will be many thousands of dollars.
We now have the choice to either close our doors for the rest of the spring season or to turn to the public for support. We believe the The Earth & Me is an important story that our children need to be told at this time and so we are taking the financial risk, and reaching out to you to help us keep SBT's commitment to our young audiences.
The Shadow Box Theatre’s primary medium is shadow puppets, which exist because of light. Metaphorically and literally they bring light into the hearts of children through stories of peace and hope.
The Earth & Me brings a vital message of empowerment to children using the mediums of music, dance, three dimensional puppetry, magical shadow figures and overhead projections on our shadow screen.  This inspiring production, who’s message, in todays world is so important not only for our young audiences, but for us all to remember, was last performed in 2006. Watch the promo video we created of our first year of producing The Earth & Me for a fuller comprehension of the message.  At that time we were still the Children’s Theatre in Residence at the Brooklyn YWCA. When its policy changed and it became only a residence for women, we had to move. Since then, we have not had the proper space or dance floor to rehearse and perform this show. However, its important message about peace, respect for the Earth, and creating a balanced environment, made us decide to rent rehearsal and performance space and put it back in the repertoire for our 2013 season.  The advent of the hurricane and its impact made this production a fiscal risk but even more cogent. There are many ways to TEACH PEACE!  Theatre is one of the most powerful and memorable. With your financial support we will be able to fulfill our mission. “Hand in Hand” we can do it together.
Artistic Excellence 

The artistic excellence of these works is exemplified by the recognition we have received over the years and the continuing demand for our productions from teachers and parents. We have received broad and critical acclaim for the high caliber and artistic staging of our works in The New York Times, Newsday, New York Daily News, Amsterdam News, New York Parent Magazine, El Diario and other media, and CBS Evening News, NY- 1 (Parenting Segment) and local television have featured us. We have made featured appearances at Lincoln Center, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Symphony Space, Emelin Theatre, Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse, Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC, American Museum of Natural History, the Brooklyn Museum, and other cultural institutions. In addition, SBT has appeared on Mister Roger's Neighborhood, Vegetable Soup, Romper Room and the PBS special anniversary production, Kids 13.
The Shadow Box Theatre has received multiple awards such as from the Office of the New York State Governor Mario Cuomo, Office of New York City Mayor Rudolf Giuliani, the Public Health Association of New York, the First Manufacturer’s Hanover Community Service Award, Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, and the Metropolitan Hospital Center. It has created an educational video for the New York City Department of Transportation and the theatre’s books, CDs, and DVDs for children have received excellent reviews from the American Library Association’s Booklist, the School Library Journal, and an ALA “Children’s Notable Recording” award for How The Turtle Got Its Shell.
What You Will Be Supporting
The Shadow Box Theatre is a 501(c) (3) non profit organization. All our earnings and funding from grants and private donors goes into programming. Through our tenacity and dedication we are the second oldest continuously running children’s theatre in New York City. You will be helping a theatre that serves over 30,000 inner city children and families a year. For many we are their first theatrical experience. 

Free and discounted tickets for children and families in need 
Rental of rehearsal and performing space
Production, Performer and Creative Team fees
Light and sound tech
Costume and set design 
Puppet creation and repair 
Promotional costs
The Shadow Box Theatre believes in the strength of numbers and knows that every little bit counts. So whether you can donate just $1 or $1000, your support is greatly appreciated. If you are thinking about making a large donation but would like to know more first, please do not hesitate to contact us. 
Can't give money?
That's ok. You can still help us by spreading the word! Use our share tools and your own networks to help us reach out through facebook, twitter, linkedin, etc. And if you have been touched by SBT please write us a review on yelp and google+. Are you connected to a New York City school? Contact us and we would love to work with you to bring our performances and workshops to even broader audiences.

What You Will Receive in Return         

Our funding goal is to put on the The Earth & Me in time for Earth Day in April 2013. Any amount we raise above and beyond this will help insure the longevity of SBT for your children and grandchildren to come.
Please check out the sidebar for our awesome Perks! And Check back frequently as there may be new ones, like the Early Bird Special, that you won't want to miss!
Note: Some perks are only available if you live in the greater NYC area.
If you do not live in the greater New York City area we will still, of course, send you CDs, books, and DVDs of your choice and would be happy to send you some never expiring tickets to our shows that you can use at your convenience. Or, if you choose, we can donate your free tickets and/or workshop or special event to a child, school, or community center of your choice in the greater New York City area.  
If we do not reach our goal we will do everything in our power to find the funds we need by other means. If we are not able to put on The Earth & Me we will still be able to fulfill our perks and tickets will be valid for any of our productions.  
Any money that we raise above and beyond our goal will also continue to fund and support the theatre and the work that we do serving the inner city children of New York City. The Show Must Go On!
The Team
Sandra Robbins, Originator, Artistic Director, Author, Playwright, Songwriter of the Earth & Me
Sandra Robbins is the founding Artistic/Executive Director of The Shadow Box Theatre. For 46 years her dedication and love of children, as well as her tenacious awareness that children are our future has driven her to keep SBT alive, vital & cogent. With the motto that Theatre Arts are a powerful tool to stimulate & motivate creativity, peaceful solutions, learning & the acceptance of differences, she has written and directed numerous artistic musical puppet productions, 10 children’s books with accompanying read-along audios, show audios and DVDS as well as helping develop Theatre Arts Workshops for children of all ages and their families.  The Earth & Me, as a work of art, is a culmination of her teaching and her dance and music background as well as an inspired sharing of her love for the Earth and her commitment to the children of the future.
Jeff Olmsted, Musical Director and partner in the creation of the music and the audio of The Earth & Me. 
Jeffs dedication to children is exemplified by the many years that he had been the Musical Director of the Shadow Box Theatre. He created the musical arrangements, musical interludes and co produced the audio of The Earth & Me. Jeff also co-produced the Read-Along/ Move Along book/CD series for See-More’s Workshop, the publishing arm of The Shadow Box Theatre. He founded and directs the Peace In the Valley Choir in Northampton, Mass. In 2009, the Dayton Philharmonic commissioned "Songs of Rumi", a 30-minute piece for chamber orchestra and chorus. He is an active teacher of Music with children and adults.  See/hear more at jeffolmsted.com.
Iku Oseki, Art Director and Puppet and set designer for The Earth & Me
Iku has illustrated many of the books for the Shadow Box Theatre. She was the Art Director for The Earth & Me, designing the three dimensional puppets and visuals as well as shadow figures for the overhead projector; envisioning effects with the creative use of elements such as rippling water and layered colors. Now Iku is the beloved art teacher at Fayerweather Street School, a small private school in Cambridge, MA where she encourages the creativity within each child, teaching kindergarten through 8th graders. 
Shela Xoregos, Co –Director & Choreographer of The Earth & Me
Shela choreographed and co-directed The Earth & Me from its inception till 2006 for The Shadow Box Theatre and will be returning to choreograph and co-direct the 2013 production. She has many years of experience directing dance and theatre for New York and for regional and summer stock companies. Her company, Xoregos Performing Company, has performed at the Smithsonian Institution, MoMA San Francisco, Palace of the Legion of Honor, Oakland Museum and in theaters and parks all over NYC. 
Miwa Oseki Robbins, Eldest grandchild of Sandra Robbins. Enough said. 
Richard Numeroff, Videographer of The Earth & Me video for Indigogo
We want to extend our huge thanks to Richard who donated his time to create the video for this IndieGoGo Campaign. Richard grew up with Sandra's children and has many fond memories of the theatre, including baking puppets in the oven one Sunday afternoon with his friend, Sandy's son, Michael Robbins. Richard is a veteran videographer and founder of Relay Productions with many works to his credit.  Please check out and support his work, which can be found at http://www.numeroff.com/. 
 
  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
From Miwa, Sandy, and the SBT Community.
 
Reviews of The Shadow Box Theatre 
"I arranged for my E.S.L. classes to attend The Earth & Me on (my birthday). It was the best present I could have gotten. We all had such a glorious experience! The presentation is easily understood without a high degree of facility in English. It is perfect for new language learners. If we only have one trip next year, it will certainly be to the Shadow Box Theatre presentation. May you continue your wonderful work." - Teacher, P.S. 233, Brooklyn
"I like how the book explains how the Earth was so quiet until people came along, fighting with each other for land and it's making the Earth get hurt. The bears, butterflies, dolphins, and eagles are all something special to the Earth. I really love the book."-Student, P.S. 151
"Children's theater is refreshing because it does not require the standard protocol of erect postures and silence. When something wows the children, they exhale great bursts of 'ooohs' and 'aaahs.' We adults have to stifle our natural reactions. The Brooklyn YWCA turned into an arena of screeches and yelps Wednesday morning as bigger-than-life butterfly and bumble bee puppets swarmed over the stage, in The Shadow Box Theatre's presentation of The Earth & Me."- Brooklyn Daily Eagle
"For centuries, children all over the world have been intrigued by shadows. The Shadow Box Theatre is bringing the ancient art form of shadow puppets to children in No Balloons Today. The group seems to have turned a kaleidoscope in such a way that the colorful pieces have formed winsome people, realistic animals and finely etched scenery...The youngsters are included all the way."          - The New York Times
The African Drum: "Behind the screen, busy hands artfully maneuvered thin poles to manipulate the jointed figures formed from rainbow-hued pieces of plastic. Before the screen, more than 100 youngsters watched delightedly yesterday as striped zebras, spotted leopards, magnificently garbed African warriors, elephants and engaging birds flitted in silhouette across the illuminated screen...For those who think of puppets either on strings or on the hand like a glove, shadow puppetry is a delightful new find with the charm of an animated cartoon."- The Washington Post  "This endearing presentation of The African Drum is an ideal way to familiarize children with African folklore. They are transported into a world of colorful tales enhanced by African rhythm and song. And so with this production, the Shadow Box Theatre has found a wonderful way to honor Black History Month."- The Black American 
"I must take a moment to comment on an exceptional program which we at P.S. 30 have experienced...Programs such as SBT's provide an invaluable experience to students who have had very limited exposure to the performing arts. Art as an expression of culture, history, joy, and information, helps children better understand their world."- Teacher, P.S. 30, Queens

story:
ITALIANO SOTTO / ESPAÑOL ABAJO

Etnopharmakon is a non profit organisation founded in 2014 among Italy, Spain and Perù. The association unites anthropologists, biologists, agronomists, ethnobotanists, curanderos and Amazon medicine experts. Since beginning 2015, we have been working together with EcoCentro project in Puerto Maldonado - located in the Madre de Dios region - in the middle of Peruvian Amazonia. We contributed to the project by making a botanic garden with medical plants. We also created a center dedicated to activities like educational workshops, sustainable tourism and experiential seminars concerning the use of medical plants and the related respect to be given to the locals’ knowledge and tradition.

THE PROJECT

‘Amazon Calling’ is a project aiming to build a plant nursery capable of producing 10,000 plants a year. Plants will partly be used to increase the botanical species kept inside Amarumayo botanical garden. Some others will instead be used to make phytotherapeutic treatments. However the majority of plants will be gifted to farmers - belonging to the Ecological Agriculture Association - in the Madre de Dios region. That will implement their fields by adding edible, wooden plants as well as medicinal plants.

SOCIO-ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

-    Spread and saving of plants with acknowledged medical value.

-    Protecting a thousand-year old medical tradition

-    Doing research on medicinal plants

-    Doing development on Amarumayo botanical garden and its related activities.

-    Developing agroforestry and analog forestry including medicinal plants. That aiming to both save and spread knowledge and on the other hand to have a positive impact on local economy. Farmers will in fact be given the possibility of selling plant-related material - like leaves, flowers, bark and roots -  to people who produce natural remedies.

Agroforestry: this activity focuses on the ecological system and the sustainable use of natural resources. Its target is to diversify the agricultural system through the integration of trees. Earth’s resources would be used to enforce production. That will lead to an increase of social, economical and environmental benefits. Agroforestry systems thus succeed in combining together the ecological and economical value of wooden trees, plantations and farm animals.

Analog Forestry: likewise agroforestry, it reproduces a similar type of ecosystem though inside of an architectural structure. Plants’ ecological features will here be similar to the ones of the original vegetation. Analog forestry is a more complete version of agroforestry, therefore including multiple layers and many kinds of complex interactions among dozens of cultivated species. That lets it have a very similar look to the current original forest. Analog forestry thus enforces rural communities both socially and economically.

PURPOSE OF THE CROWDFUNDING

LOCATION

EcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas km 3.2) is a multifunctional structure created in 2001. It is currently hosting a variety of non-profit organisations like: Etnopharmakon, Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Thanks to these associations’ contribution Ecocentro has acquired a pivotal role to all people interested in sustainable lifestyles and production systems that are environmentally and culturally friendly. Synergy among the organisations has managed to achieve lots of goals year by year. Many projects - such as educational workshops, involvement with schools, experiential seminars, sustainable tourism, craftsmanship, agroforestry, foresteria analoga, ecological farming, production of bio-fertiliser, phytotherapeutic remedies, biological products and much more yet to come - were activated through collaboration and the common certainty that keeping a respectful attitude toward surrounding people and environment is the right path to follow.

CONTEXT

Biodiversity in the Madre de Dios region currently is one of the vastest in the world. It is though also affected by dramatic levels of environmental risk. That occurring to an area where culture and nature are sticked together in an ancient and profound bond and consequently leading to critical cultural emergency. Such connection is seen in traditional medical practises that involve the local plants in a unique way. For too many years the region has been subject to the irresponsible and undiscriminating exploitation - gold and wood above all - of its natural resources. That is doing critical damage to both the region’s extraordinary biological balance, and people themselves  whose culture outstandingly exemplifies the ideal of a harmonic relationship between man and nature. Thousands hectares of forest are yearly taken down in favour to building illegal gold mines as well as the trade of wood, growing spread of monocultures and intensive farming. Rivers are being poisoned by mercury that is used in mines and then recklessly disposed into their waters. That leads to contamination of the river’s fauna and the related food chain. Children are illegally trafficked for prostitution and exploited to work. The lack of respect for life daily generates these and many other appalling side-effects in the Madre de Dios region. Local and international authorities and institutions are dealing inefficiently with the problem and they don’t fight against a situation that is risking to erase a priceless biological and cultural heritage.

The project is therefore born aiming to face both environmental and cultural controversies by spreading knowledge of the region’s therapeutic culture and giving value to Madre de Dios biodiversity which currently is one of the most incredible gifts mankind owns on this planet, though we are letting it disappear without ever really having the opportunity to know it for real.

PERKS

ADOPTION CERTIFICATE

DIGITAL: an email with a personalized adoption certificate

PAPER: a letter with the certificate of adoption printed with ecological inks on growing paper, from which will be born  "forget-me-nots"

ETNOPHARMAKON TEXTILE

A textile with circular Etnopharmakon’s logo. Here’s the size:

medium: 16 x 24 in - 40 x 60 cm

large: 24 x 35 in - 60 x 90 cm

TEACHER PLANTS SEEDS

You can choose between; ayahuasca, peyote, trichocereus pachanoi, trichocereus peruvianus, trichocereus terscheckii

 

 

 

ITALIANO

CHI SIAMO

Etnopharmakon è un'organizzazione no profit nata nel 2014 tra Italia, Spagna e Perù dall'unione di antropologi, biologi, agronomi, etnobotanici, curanderos ed esperti di medicina tradizionale amazzonica. Da inizio 2015 collaboriamo al progetto EcoCentro nella città di Puerto Maldonado, nella regione Madre de Dios, nel mezzo dell'Amazzonia peruviana attraverso la gestione di un giardino botanico di piante medicinali e di un centro dedicato all'organizzazione di laboratori didattici, turismo responsabile e di seminari esperenziali con piante medicinali nel rispetto delle conoscenze e delle tradizioni locali.

IL PROGETTO

Il progetto 'Amazon Calling'  mira alla realizzazione di un vivaio capace di produrre 10.000 piante medicinali all’anno. Parte delle piante coltivate serviranno ad aumentare le specie botaniche conservate all’interno del giardino botanico Amarumayo. Altre saranno destinate alla preparazione di rimedi fitoterapici. La maggior parte saranno regalate ai contadini della regione Madre de Dios (raggruppati all’interno dell’Associazione di Agricultura Ecologica) così da poter implementare i loro campi, oltre che con piante da legno ed edibili, anche con piante medicinali.

IMPATTO SOCIO-AMBIENTALE

- Conservazione e diffusione di piante dal riconosciuto valore medico

- Tutela di una tradizione medica millenaria

- Ricerca su piante medicinali

- Sviluppo del giardino botanico Amarumayo e delle attività ad esso connesse

- Sviluppo di sistemi di agroforestazione e foresteria analoga che includano anche piante medicinali nella prospettiva, da una parte di conservare e diffondere un sapere e, dall’altra, di avere un impatto sull’economia locale, con la possibilità, da parte dei contadini, di vendere materiale vegetale (foglie, fiori, radici, corteccia, etc) a produttori di rimedi naturali

Agroforestazione: lo scopo di questa pratica consiste in una gestione basata su sistemi ecologici e sull'uso sostenibile di risorse naturali che attraverso l'integrazione di alberi nel sistema agricolo diversifica e sostiene la produzione per aumentare i benefici sociali, economici ed ambientali dell'uso della terra a tutti i livelli. Dunque, i sistemi agroforestali sono caratterizzati da interazioni ecologiche ed economiche tra alberi legnosi, coltivazioni ed allevamenti.

Foresteria Analoga: è un sistema che cerca di riprodurre ecosistemi analoghi in struttura architettonica e funzioni ecologiche alla vegetazione originale. É simile alla agroforestazione, ma piú complessa e completa, dato che i molteplici strati e le complesse interazioni tra le decine di specie coltivate lo rendono in effetti simile alla vista alla foresta attuale. Questo sistema rafforza le comunità rurali, tanto socialmente come economicamente.

COME VERRANNO USATI I SOLDI RACCOLTI

 

DOVE SIAMO

EcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas km 3.2), è una struttura polivalente creata nel 2001 e che, al momento, ospita diverse associazioni no profit tra cui: Etnopharmakon, Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Grazie alla collaborazione tra tutte queste associazioni Ecocentro si è convertito in un punto cardine per tutti gli interessati ad uno stile di vita e a forme di produzione sostenibili e rispettose del medioambiente e delle diverse culture. Laboratori didattici, progetti con le scuole, seminari esperenziali, turismo responsabile, artigianato, agroforestazione, foresteria analoga, agricultura ecologica, produzione di biofertilizzante, di rimedi fitoterapici, di prodotti biologici...tutto questo e molto altro è quello che, negli anni, si è riuscito ad attivare grazie alla collaborazione e alla certezza che vivere in una forma rispettosa dell'ambiente e degli altri sia la strada giusta da percorrere.

IL CONTESTO

Madre de Dios è attualmente una delle regioni con la più vasta biodiversità al mondo ma, purtroppo, è anche una delle regioni col più alto grado di rischio ambientale, che diventa anche un’emergenza culturale in una zona in cui cultura e natura hanno un legame ancora profondo e antico che si manifesta in particolar modo nelle pratiche mediche tradizionali, caratterizzate dall’uso esclusivo di piante locali. La depredazione indiscriminata e irresponsabile delle sue risorse – prime fra tutte oro e legname – di cui è oggetto da ormai troppi anni, ha le proporzioni di una devastazione che sta compromettendo irrimediabilmente il suo straordinario equilibrio biologico e la cultura dell’uomo che ne è sua una manifestazione così diretta da rappresentare un esempio unico del legame armonico tra uomo e natura. Sono infatti migliaia, ogni anno, gli ettari di foresta distrutti dal sorgere di miniere d’oro illegali, dal commercio altrettanto illecito di legname, dalla diffusione sempre più ampia di monoculture e allevamenti intensivi. L’avvelenamento dei fiumi a causa dello smaltimento incosciente del mercurio usato nelle miniere, la conseguente contaminazione della fauna ittica e della catena alimentare ad essa legata, lo sfruttamento del lavoro minorile e il traffico di minori legati al mondo della prostituzione, sono solo alcuni degli orribili effetti collaterali di questa totale assenza di rispetto per la vita in ogni sua forma, e sono all’ordine del giorno nella regione Madre De Dios. L’azione delle autorità e istituzioni locali e internazionali è, purtroppo, ad oggi insufficiente e inefficace – quando non addirittura connivente – per contrastare questo stato di cose che sta rischiando di cancellare un patrimonio biologico e culturale di inestimabile valore.

Il progetto nasce, dunque, con l’idea d’intervenire, agendo in maniera congiunta su due fronti: quello ambientale e quello culturale, favorendo la conoscenza in una prospettiva d’integrazione, sia a livello locale che internazionale, di una cultura terapeutica e di una varietà naturalistica che ad oggi è una delle più straordinarie ricchezze che l’uomo possiede su questa terra, e che stiamo colpevolmente lasciando scomparire senza neppure averla mai conosciuta davvero.

 

ESPAÑOL

QUIÉNES SOMOS

Etnopharmakon es una organización sin ánimo de lucro fundada en 2014 entre Italia, España y Perú, a través de la colaboración de antropólogos, biólogos, agrónomos, etnobotánicos, curanderos y de expertos en la medicina tradicional amazónica. Desde el comienzo de 2015 colaboramos con el proyecto EcoCentro en la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado, en la región de Madre de Dios, en medio de la Amazonía peruana a través de la creación de un jardín botánico de plantas medicinales y de un centro dedicado a la organización de talleres educativos,turismo responsable y talleres vivenciales con las plantas medicinales en el respeto de los conocimientos y tradiciones locales. 

EL PROYECTO

El proyecto 'Amazon Calling' tiene como objetivo la construcción de un vivero capaz de producir 10.000 plantas medicinales por año.
Parte de las plantas cultivadas se utilizarán para aumentar las especies de plantas que se conservan en jardín botánico Amarumayo. 
Otras se utilizarán para la preparación de remedios fitoterapéuticos.
La mayoría serán entregados a los agricultores de la región Madre de Dios (agrupados en la Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica) para que puedan poner implementar sus campos, además que con plantas de madera y comestibles, también con plantas medicinales.

IMPACTO SOCIOAMBIENTAL

- Conservación y difusión de las plantas de valor médico reconocido

- Protección de una tradición médica milenaria

- Investigación sobre plantas medicinales

- El desarrollo del Jardín Botánico Amarumayo y de las actividades conexas

- El desarrollo de sistemas agroforestales y de foresteria análoga que incluyan  plantas medicinales en la perspectiva, por un lado de preservar y difundir el conocimiento y, por otra, para tener un impacto en la economía local, con la posibilidad, por parte de los agricultores, de vender material vegetal (hojas, flores, raíces, corteza, etc.) a los productores de remedios naturales

Agroforestería: el propósito de esta práctica consiste en una gestión basada en los sistemas ecológicos y el uso sostenible de los recursosnaturales que a través de la integración de los árboles en el sistema agrícola diversifica y sostiene la producción para aumentar losbeneficios sociales, económicos y ambientales del uso de la tierra en todos los niveles. Por lo tanto, los sistemas agroforestales se caracterizan por interacciones ecológicas y económicas entre los árboles leñosos, cultivos y ganado.

Foresteria Análoga: es un sistema que trata de reproducir ecosistemas análogos en estructura arquitectónica y funciones ecológicas de la vegetación original. Es similar a la agroforestería, pero más complejo y completo, ya que las múltiples capas y las complejas interacciones entre las decenas de especies cultivadas lo hacen, de hecho, similar a la vista del bosque actual. Este sistema refuerza la comunidad rural, tanto social como económicamente

¿CÓMO SE UTILIZARÁ EL DINERO RECAUDADO?

DONDE ESTAMOS

EcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas del 3,2 km), es una estructura polivalente creada en 2001 y que, al día de hoy, es el hogar de variasorganizaciones sin ánimo de lucro, incluyendo: Etnopharmakon, la Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Gracias a lacolaboración entre todas estas asociaciones Ecocentro se convirtió en un punto crucial para todos los interesados en un estilo de vida y a formas de producción sostenibles y respetuosos del medioambiente y de las diferentes culturas. Talleres educativos, proyectos con las escuelas, talleres vivenciales, turismo responsable, la artesanía, la agroforestería, la foresteria análoga , la agricultura ecológica, la producción de bio-fertilizantes, de remedios fitoterapéuticos, deproductos biológicos... todo esto y mucho más es lo que, en los últimos años se ha logrado activar gracias al trabajo colaborativo y a la certeza de que vivir enuna forma que respete el medio ambiente y los demás es el mejor camino a seguir.

EL CONTEXTO

Madre de Dios es actualmente una de las regiones con mayor biodiversidad en el mundo, pero por desgracia, es también una de las regiones con el mayor grado de riesgo ambiental, que también se convierte en una emergencia cultural en una zona donde la cultura y la naturaleza tienen un vínculo todavía profundo y antiguo que se manifiesta sobre todo en las prácticas médicas tradicionales, caracterizadas por el uso exclusivo de las plantas locales. El saqueo indiscriminado e irresponsable de sus recursos - en primer lugar el oro y la madera - que sufre ya desde demasiados años, tiene las proporciones de una devastación que está comprometiendo irremediablemente su extraordinario equilibrio biológico humano y la cultura del hombre de la que es su manifestación tan directa que representa un ejemplo único de la relación armoniosa entre el hombre y la naturaleza. Son, en efecto, miles cada año, las hectáreas de bosque destruido por el aumento de la minería de oro ilegal, el comercio de madera ilegal, la creciente expansión de los monocultivos y la ganadería intensiva. 
El envenenamiento de los ríos debido a la eliminación imprudente de mercurio utilizado en las minas, lo que resulta en la contaminación del pescado y la cadena alimentaria a eso asociada, la explotación del trabajo infantil y la trata de niños vinculados a la prostitución, son algunos de los horribles efectos secundarios de esta total falta de respeto a la vida en todas sus formas, y se manifiestan a diario en la región de Madre de Dios. La acción de las autoridades e instituciones locales e internacionales es desafortunadamente al día de hoy insuficiente e ineficaz- si no hasta cómplice - para contrarrestar esta situación que amenaza con acabar con un patrimonio biológico y cultural de inestimable valor.

El proyecto nace, por lo tanto, con la idea de intervenir, actuando conjuntamente en dos frentes: el del medio ambiente y el del patrimonio cultural, favoreciendo el conocimiento en una perspectiva de integración, tanto a nivel local como internacional, de una cultura  terapéutica y de una variedad naturalistica que es actualmente una de las riquezas más extraordinarias que el hombre posee en esta tierra, y que estamos culpablemente dejando desaparecer sin ni siquiera haberla conocida realmente.
story_txt: ITALIANO SOTTO / ESPAÑOL ABAJOEtnopharmakon is a non profit organisation founded in 2014 among Italy, Spain and Perù. The association unites anthropologists, biologists, agronomists, ethnobotanists, curanderos and Amazon medicine experts. Since beginning 2015, we have been working together with EcoCentro project in Puerto Maldonado - located in the Madre de Dios region - in the middle of Peruvian Amazonia. We contributed to the project by making a botanic garden with medical plants. We also created a center dedicated to activities like educational workshops, sustainable tourism and experiential seminars concerning the use of medical plants and the related respect to be given to the locals’ knowledge and tradition.THE PROJECT‘Amazon Calling’ is a project aiming to build a plant nursery capable of producing 10,000 plants a year. Plants will partly be used to increase the botanical species kept inside Amarumayo botanical garden. Some others will instead be used to make phytotherapeutic treatments. However the majority of plants will be gifted to farmers - belonging to the Ecological Agriculture Association - in the Madre de Dios region. That will implement their fields by adding edible, wooden plants as well as medicinal plants.SOCIO-ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT-    Spread and saving of plants with acknowledged medical value.-    Protecting a thousand-year old medical tradition-    Doing research on medicinal plants-    Doing development on Amarumayo botanical garden and its related activities.-    Developing agroforestry and analog forestry including medicinal plants. That aiming to both save and spread knowledge and on the other hand to have a positive impact on local economy. Farmers will in fact be given the possibility of selling plant-related material - like leaves, flowers, bark and roots -  to people who produce natural remedies.Agroforestry: this activity focuses on the ecological system and the sustainable use of natural resources. Its target is to diversify the agricultural system through the integration of trees. Earth’s resources would be used to enforce production. That will lead to an increase of social, economical and environmental benefits. Agroforestry systems thus succeed in combining together the ecological and economical value of wooden trees, plantations and farm animals.Analog Forestry: likewise agroforestry, it reproduces a similar type of ecosystem though inside of an architectural structure. Plants’ ecological features will here be similar to the ones of the original vegetation. Analog forestry is a more complete version of agroforestry, therefore including multiple layers and many kinds of complex interactions among dozens of cultivated species. That lets it have a very similar look to the current original forest. Analog forestry thus enforces rural communities both socially and economically.PURPOSE OF THE CROWDFUNDINGLOCATIONEcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas km 3.2) is a multifunctional structure created in 2001. It is currently hosting a variety of non-profit organisations like: Etnopharmakon, Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Thanks to these associations’ contribution Ecocentro has acquired a pivotal role to all people interested in sustainable lifestyles and production systems that are environmentally and culturally friendly. Synergy among the organisations has managed to achieve lots of goals year by year. Many projects - such as educational workshops, involvement with schools, experiential seminars, sustainable tourism, craftsmanship, agroforestry, foresteria analoga, ecological farming, production of bio-fertiliser, phytotherapeutic remedies, biological products and much more yet to come - were activated through collaboration and the common certainty that keeping a respectful attitude toward surrounding people and environment is the right path to follow.CONTEXTBiodiversity in the Madre de Dios region currently is one of the vastest in the world. It is though also affected by dramatic levels of environmental risk. That occurring to an area where culture and nature are sticked together in an ancient and profound bond and consequently leading to critical cultural emergency. Such connection is seen in traditional medical practises that involve the local plants in a unique way. For too many years the region has been subject to the irresponsible and undiscriminating exploitation - gold and wood above all - of its natural resources. That is doing critical damage to both the region’s extraordinary biological balance, and people themselves  whose culture outstandingly exemplifies the ideal of a harmonic relationship between man and nature. Thousands hectares of forest are yearly taken down in favour to building illegal gold mines as well as the trade of wood, growing spread of monocultures and intensive farming. Rivers are being poisoned by mercury that is used in mines and then recklessly disposed into their waters. That leads to contamination of the river’s fauna and the related food chain. Children are illegally trafficked for prostitution and exploited to work. The lack of respect for life daily generates these and many other appalling side-effects in the Madre de Dios region. Local and international authorities and institutions are dealing inefficiently with the problem and they don’t fight against a situation that is risking to erase a priceless biological and cultural heritage.The project is therefore born aiming to face both environmental and cultural controversies by spreading knowledge of the region’s therapeutic culture and giving value to Madre de Dios biodiversity which currently is one of the most incredible gifts mankind owns on this planet, though we are letting it disappear without ever really having the opportunity to know it for real.PERKSADOPTION CERTIFICATEDIGITAL: an email with a personalized adoption certificatePAPER: a letter with the certificate of adoption printed with ecological inks on growing paper, from which will be born  "forget-me-nots"ETNOPHARMAKON TEXTILEA textile with circular Etnopharmakon’s logo. Here’s the size:medium: 16 x 24 in - 40 x 60 cmlarge: 24 x 35 in - 60 x 90 cmTEACHER PLANTS SEEDSYou can choose between; ayahuasca, peyote, trichocereus pachanoi, trichocereus peruvianus, trichocereus terscheckii   ITALIANOCHI SIAMOEtnopharmakon è un'organizzazione no profit nata nel 2014 tra Italia, Spagna e Perù dall'unione di antropologi, biologi, agronomi, etnobotanici, curanderos ed esperti di medicina tradizionale amazzonica. Da inizio 2015 collaboriamo al progetto EcoCentro nella città di Puerto Maldonado, nella regione Madre de Dios, nel mezzo dell'Amazzonia peruviana attraverso la gestione di un giardino botanico di piante medicinali e di un centro dedicato all'organizzazione di laboratori didattici, turismo responsabile e di seminari esperenziali con piante medicinali nel rispetto delle conoscenze e delle tradizioni locali.IL PROGETTOIl progetto 'Amazon Calling'  mira alla realizzazione di un vivaio capace di produrre 10.000 piante medicinali all’anno. Parte delle piante coltivate serviranno ad aumentare le specie botaniche conservate all’interno del giardino botanico Amarumayo. Altre saranno destinate alla preparazione di rimedi fitoterapici. La maggior parte saranno regalate ai contadini della regione Madre de Dios (raggruppati all’interno dell’Associazione di Agricultura Ecologica) così da poter implementare i loro campi, oltre che con piante da legno ed edibili, anche con piante medicinali.IMPATTO SOCIO-AMBIENTALE- Conservazione e diffusione di piante dal riconosciuto valore medico- Tutela di una tradizione medica millenaria- Ricerca su piante medicinali- Sviluppo del giardino botanico Amarumayo e delle attività ad esso connesse- Sviluppo di sistemi di agroforestazione e foresteria analoga che includano anche piante medicinali nella prospettiva, da una parte di conservare e diffondere un sapere e, dall’altra, di avere un impatto sull’economia locale, con la possibilità, da parte dei contadini, di vendere materiale vegetale (foglie, fiori, radici, corteccia, etc) a produttori di rimedi naturaliAgroforestazione: lo scopo di questa pratica consiste in una gestione basata su sistemi ecologici e sull'uso sostenibile di risorse naturali che attraverso l'integrazione di alberi nel sistema agricolo diversifica e sostiene la produzione per aumentare i benefici sociali, economici ed ambientali dell'uso della terra a tutti i livelli. Dunque, i sistemi agroforestali sono caratterizzati da interazioni ecologiche ed economiche tra alberi legnosi, coltivazioni ed allevamenti.Foresteria Analoga: è un sistema che cerca di riprodurre ecosistemi analoghi in struttura architettonica e funzioni ecologiche alla vegetazione originale. É simile alla agroforestazione, ma piú complessa e completa, dato che i molteplici strati e le complesse interazioni tra le decine di specie coltivate lo rendono in effetti simile alla vista alla foresta attuale. Questo sistema rafforza le comunità rurali, tanto socialmente come economicamente.COME VERRANNO USATI I SOLDI RACCOLTI DOVE SIAMOEcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas km 3.2), è una struttura polivalente creata nel 2001 e che, al momento, ospita diverse associazioni no profit tra cui: Etnopharmakon, Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Grazie alla collaborazione tra tutte queste associazioni Ecocentro si è convertito in un punto cardine per tutti gli interessati ad uno stile di vita e a forme di produzione sostenibili e rispettose del medioambiente e delle diverse culture. Laboratori didattici, progetti con le scuole, seminari esperenziali, turismo responsabile, artigianato, agroforestazione, foresteria analoga, agricultura ecologica, produzione di biofertilizzante, di rimedi fitoterapici, di prodotti biologici...tutto questo e molto altro è quello che, negli anni, si è riuscito ad attivare grazie alla collaborazione e alla certezza che vivere in una forma rispettosa dell'ambiente e degli altri sia la strada giusta da percorrere.IL CONTESTOMadre de Dios è attualmente una delle regioni con la più vasta biodiversità al mondo ma, purtroppo, è anche una delle regioni col più alto grado di rischio ambientale, che diventa anche un’emergenza culturale in una zona in cui cultura e natura hanno un legame ancora profondo e antico che si manifesta in particolar modo nelle pratiche mediche tradizionali, caratterizzate dall’uso esclusivo di piante locali. La depredazione indiscriminata e irresponsabile delle sue risorse – prime fra tutte oro e legname – di cui è oggetto da ormai troppi anni, ha le proporzioni di una devastazione che sta compromettendo irrimediabilmente il suo straordinario equilibrio biologico e la cultura dell’uomo che ne è sua una manifestazione così diretta da rappresentare un esempio unico del legame armonico tra uomo e natura. Sono infatti migliaia, ogni anno, gli ettari di foresta distrutti dal sorgere di miniere d’oro illegali, dal commercio altrettanto illecito di legname, dalla diffusione sempre più ampia di monoculture e allevamenti intensivi. L’avvelenamento dei fiumi a causa dello smaltimento incosciente del mercurio usato nelle miniere, la conseguente contaminazione della fauna ittica e della catena alimentare ad essa legata, lo sfruttamento del lavoro minorile e il traffico di minori legati al mondo della prostituzione, sono solo alcuni degli orribili effetti collaterali di questa totale assenza di rispetto per la vita in ogni sua forma, e sono all’ordine del giorno nella regione Madre De Dios. L’azione delle autorità e istituzioni locali e internazionali è, purtroppo, ad oggi insufficiente e inefficace – quando non addirittura connivente – per contrastare questo stato di cose che sta rischiando di cancellare un patrimonio biologico e culturale di inestimabile valore.Il progetto nasce, dunque, con l’idea d’intervenire, agendo in maniera congiunta su due fronti: quello ambientale e quello culturale, favorendo la conoscenza in una prospettiva d’integrazione, sia a livello locale che internazionale, di una cultura terapeutica e di una varietà naturalistica che ad oggi è una delle più straordinarie ricchezze che l’uomo possiede su questa terra, e che stiamo colpevolmente lasciando scomparire senza neppure averla mai conosciuta davvero. ESPAÑOLQUIÉNES SOMOSEtnopharmakon es una organización sin ánimo de lucro fundada en 2014 entre Italia, España y Perú, a través de la colaboración de antropólogos, biólogos, agrónomos, etnobotánicos, curanderos y de expertos en la medicina tradicional amazónica. Desde el comienzo de 2015 colaboramos con el proyecto EcoCentro en la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado, en la región de Madre de Dios, en medio de la Amazonía peruana a través de la creación de un jardín botánico de plantas medicinales y de un centro dedicado a la organización de talleres educativos,turismo responsable y talleres vivenciales con las plantas medicinales en el respeto de los conocimientos y tradiciones locales. EL PROYECTOEl proyecto 'Amazon Calling' tiene como objetivo la construcción de un vivero capaz de producir 10.000 plantas medicinales por año.Parte de las plantas cultivadas se utilizarán para aumentar las especies de plantas que se conservan en jardín botánico Amarumayo. Otras se utilizarán para la preparación de remedios fitoterapéuticos.La mayoría serán entregados a los agricultores de la región Madre de Dios (agrupados en la Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica) para que puedan poner implementar sus campos, además que con plantas de madera y comestibles, también con plantas medicinales.IMPACTO SOCIOAMBIENTAL- Conservación y difusión de las plantas de valor médico reconocido- Protección de una tradición médica milenaria- Investigación sobre plantas medicinales- El desarrollo del Jardín Botánico Amarumayo y de las actividades conexas- El desarrollo de sistemas agroforestales y de foresteria análoga que incluyan  plantas medicinales en la perspectiva, por un lado de preservar y difundir el conocimiento y, por otra, para tener un impacto en la economía local, con la posibilidad, por parte de los agricultores, de vender material vegetal (hojas, flores, raíces, corteza, etc.) a los productores de remedios naturalesAgroforestería: el propósito de esta práctica consiste en una gestión basada en los sistemas ecológicos y el uso sostenible de los recursosnaturales que a través de la integración de los árboles en el sistema agrícola diversifica y sostiene la producción para aumentar losbeneficios sociales, económicos y ambientales del uso de la tierra en todos los niveles. Por lo tanto, los sistemas agroforestales se caracterizan por interacciones ecológicas y económicas entre los árboles leñosos, cultivos y ganado.Foresteria Análoga: es un sistema que trata de reproducir ecosistemas análogos en estructura arquitectónica y funciones ecológicas de la vegetación original. Es similar a la agroforestería, pero más complejo y completo, ya que las múltiples capas y las complejas interacciones entre las decenas de especies cultivadas lo hacen, de hecho, similar a la vista del bosque actual. Este sistema refuerza la comunidad rural, tanto social como económicamente¿CÓMO SE UTILIZARÁ EL DINERO RECAUDADO?DONDE ESTAMOSEcoCentro (Puerto Maldonado, calle rompeolas del 3,2 km), es una estructura polivalente creada en 2001 y que, al día de hoy, es el hogar de variasorganizaciones sin ánimo de lucro, incluyendo: Etnopharmakon, la Asociación de Agricultura Ecológica, Ecodely, La Charcita del Arte, La Planta. Gracias a lacolaboración entre todas estas asociaciones Ecocentro se convirtió en un punto crucial para todos los interesados en un estilo de vida y a formas de producción sostenibles y respetuosos del medioambiente y de las diferentes culturas. Talleres educativos, proyectos con las escuelas, talleres vivenciales, turismo responsable, la artesanía, la agroforestería, la foresteria análoga , la agricultura ecológica, la producción de bio-fertilizantes, de remedios fitoterapéuticos, deproductos biológicos... todo esto y mucho más es lo que resulta en la contaminación del pescado y la cadena alimentaria a eso asociada, la explotación del trabajo infantil y la trata de niños vinculados a la prostitución, son algunos de los horribles hombre posee en esta tierra, y que estamos culpablemente dejando desaparecer sin ni siquiera haberla conocida realmente.

story:
The Rickshaw Rally, Saving our Oceans from Plastic and fighting illegal Shark Finning:

No set route, no back-up, no way of knowing if we're going to make it. The only certainty is that we will get lost, we will get stuck, we will break down and we will help save a bit of the world. 

 

Team Diablo Organics in a rickshaw , a wholly unsuitable vehicle, traversing the subcontinent, enduring whatever shit the road throws at us. Our goal is not only to survive, but to win and raise money and awareness of the issues facing our Oceans and the sharks in them while we do it. Thank you for being part of the team!

 

 

Jimmy Buddha has been a wanderer of the world since childhood with adventure ingrained into his soul. He has always been drawn to the ocean and has been an avid diver since learning while growing up in Venezuela. More and more the decimation that the oceans are undergoing has been on his mind. He now feels like he has the influence and the ability to make a difference and he is doing it the only way he knows how, by getting dirty and exploring the far corners of the world! With his trusty side kick, Lauren "Road Dog" Wagenman, Team Diablo is out to smoke this shit and help change the world! But we need your help!           

          

 

How are we planning to make this happen? By making awesome jewelry, Duh! Jimmy Buddha isn't the type of guy that is looking for hand outs. The plan: Do what we do best here at Diablo Organics by offering unique cast brass shark tooth jewelry and a Full Access Pass, which includes lifetime access to the private Instagram account as a gift in return for your contributions. For those of you that want to be part of the action and hear from us while Team Diablo forges it's way through the subcontinent we are creating a "Team Diablo VIP pass"  which earns you personalized texts and our location coordinates via satellite GPS and life time access to the private Instagram account that we will update during this quest and all future quests!!  

 

 

The first charity is on the island of Bali, Indonesia home of Studio Diablo. Apuan Peduli dan Berbagi (APB) spreads education to small villages about the importance of recycling plastics and the detriments to our environment caused by plastic pollution. Indonesia is an island nation with some of the richest biodiversity on the planet, but it is choking on a flood of single use plastic tossed into it's rivers and getting washed out to sea wreaking havoc in our oceans.

 

 

Humans have created an estimated 8.3 billion tons of plastic since the 1950's with 60% of that still on the planet. As it stands now 91% of the 300 million tons of plastic we produce yearly is not recycled and 8 million tons of that ends up in our Oceans. The first step in combating this problem is through education and this is where this grass roots organization comes into play. We need to start cleaning up our mess or scenes like this diver swimming in plastic off the coast of Bali will become the norm.

 

 
 

The second charity we are supporting is Sea Shepherds program that targets and pursues pirate fishermen that roam the seas of Indonesia illegally fishing for sharks, which only go to the tables of the rich in the form of shark fin soup. 73 million sharks a year are killed for this soup, thats over 8,000 an hour! At the moment sharks are being killed 30% faster than they can reproduce. At this rate they will be extinct in years.

 

 
 
The over fishing of this apex predator decimates the oceans habitat and traumatically effects the the oceanic ecosystem contributing to the slow death of our oceans. The fight needs to be taken to the fishermen, the consumers and the public. Your contribution will do that and help Sea Shepard continue the cause. Sharks have roamed the Oceans for 400 million years, we cannot let them expire on our watch.

 

 

If you guys are still with us hopefully it means that you care and you believe in us! This is where it gets fun for you! If you are familiar with Diablo Organics then you know we are a wholesale only company. We firmly believe in our industry made up of small independent businesses and support them fully by not selling to the public, but we think they will understand if we make an exception this once for such a good cause. It is your chance to get jewelry from us directly and help save our planet by doing so. If you are reading this and you are one of our wholesale clients then contact us directly and ask how you can become a partner in helping us save our sharks and oceans.  

 Every little bit helps. Thank you for becoming part of the solution!!

Keep up with us @Instagram: @DiabloOrganics and @JimmyBuddha and Facebook: Diablo Organics

But we need your help!                      How are we planning to make this happen? By making awesome jewelry, Duh! Jimmy Buddha isn't the type of guy that is looking for hand outs. The plan: Do what we do best here at Diablo Organics by offering unique cast brass shark tooth jewelry and a Full Access Pass, which includes lifetime access to the private Instagram account as a gift in return for your contributions. For those of you that want to be part of the action and hear from us while Team Diablo forges it's way through the subcontinent we are creating a "Team Diablo VIP pass"  which earns you personalized texts and our location coordinates via satellite GPS and life time access to the private Instagram account that we will update during this quest and all future quests!!    The first charity is on the island of Bali, Indonesia home of Studio Diablo. Apuan Peduli dan Berbagi (APB) spreads education to small villages about the importance of recycling plastics and the detriments to our environment caused by plastic pollution. Indonesia is an island nation with some of the richest biodiversity on the planet, but it is choking on a flood of single use plastic tossed into it's rivers and getting washed out to sea wreaking havoc in our oceans.  Humans have created an estimated 8.3 billion tons of plastic since the 1950's with 60% of that still on the planet. As it stands now 91% of the 300 million tons of plastic we produce yearly is not recycled and 8 million tons of that ends up in our Oceans. The first step in combating this problem is through education and this is where this grass roots organization comes into play. We need to start cleaning up our mess or scenes like this diver swimming in plastic off the coast of Bali will become the norm.  
 

The second charity we are supporting is Sea Shepherds program that targets and pursues pirate fishermen that roam the seas of Indonesia illegally fishing for sharks, which only go to the tables of the rich in the form of shark fin soup. 73 million sharks a year are killed for this soup, thats over 8,000 an hour! At the moment sharks are being killed 30% faster than they can reproduce. At this rate they will be extinct in years.
 

 
 
The over fishing of this apex predator decimates the oceans habitat and traumatically effects the the oceanic ecosystem contributing to the slow death of our oceans. The fight needs to be taken to the fishermen, the consumers and the public. Your contribution will do that and help Sea Shepard continue the cause. Sharks have roamed the Oceans for 400 million years, we cannot let them expire on our watch.

 
 If you guys are still with us hopefully it means that you care and you believe in us! This is where it gets fun for you! If you are familiar with Diablo Organics then you know we are a wholesale only company. We firmly believe in our industry made up of small independent businesses and support them fully by not selling to the public, but we think they will understand if we make an exception this once for such a good cause. It is your chance to get jewelry from us directly and help save our planet by doing so. If you are reading this and you are one of our wholesale clients then contact us directly and ask how you can become a partner in helping us save our sharks and oceans.   Every little bit helps. Thank you for becoming part of the solution!!Keep up with us @Instagram: @DiabloOrganics and @JimmyBuddha and Facebook: Diablo Organics

story:
Historic Wintersburg in Huntington Beach, California: One of America’s 11 Most Endangered Historic Places.

“In the late 1800s, the small agricultural community of Wintersburg Village was born. While the daily life of Huntington Beach swirls around it, what is left of Historic Wintersburg tells the story of old California, Orange County agriculture, faith, and of California's Japanese Americans.”

We are inviting you to save rare American history!

It began with a little curiosity: what exactly were “those old buildings” at the corner of Warner Avenue and Nichols Lane in Huntington Beach, California?

What came afterwards prompted local residents to come forward in an effort to save a remarkable historic property that had been hiding in plain sight for decades.

The story

The Historic Wintersburg blog was created in February 2012, www.HistoricWintersburg.blogspot.com  The book, Historic Wintersburg in Huntington Beach, was published by History Press in March 2014.  The research continues and more stories unfold!

Historic Wintersburg contains stories of Japanese pioneers in Orange County, an historic goldfish and flower farm, and a pioneer community effort that founded one of the oldest Japanese missions in California. 

The Wintersburg Mission is part of the unrecognized Japanese Mission Trail that began in the late 1880s in San Francisco and made its way down the Pacific coast to Wintersburg Village by 1904.  The pioneers who settled Orange County together survived drought, earthquakes, flood, World War I, Spanish Flu, and the giddy rush of people coming to Southern California, to the land of oranges and beautiful beaches. 

Historic Wintersburg is the story of all of us.

Historic Wintersburg also is a rare Japanese-owned property that survived California’s Alien Land Laws of 1913 and 1920, and the traumatic upheaval of World War II.  Everyone associated with the Historic Wintersburg property—farmers, merchants, clergy and congregation, including American citizens—was forcibly evacuated from California and confined during World War II. 

Historic Wintersburg is a tangible icon of the brave pioneer settlement of the American West and the struggle for civil liberties.

Wintersburg Japanese Presbyterian Mission, founded in 1904, at gathering in 1910. These are among the six buildings still standing at Historic Wintersburg. Photo courtesy of Wintersburg Presbyterian Church. © All rights reserved.

Historic Wintersburg was named in June 2014 as one of America’s 11 Most Endangered Historic Places by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.  It is the first time an Orange County historical property has made the list in its three-decade long history and the only property named in the western continental United States.  

Historic Wintersburg was re-zoned by its current property owner to commercial / industrial zoning, along with a plan for demolition.   It is endangered with complete demolition of all six historic structures on the property by May 2015, unless financial support helps us save it.

Photo of Yukiko and Charles Furuta in front of their bungalow in Wintersburg Village, 1912. This is among the six buildings still standing at Historic Wintersburg. Photo courtesy of Furuta family. © All rights reserved.

Going for the National Register: All six of the structures on the 4 ½-acre property are considered eligible for the National Register of Historic Places: the 1910 Wintersburg Japanese Presbyterian Mission and manse (parsonage); the 1934 Wintersburg Japanese Presbyterian Church; the last remaining pioneer barn in Huntington Beach, circa 1908-1912; the 1912 Furuta bungalow; and the 1947 post-World War II Furuta ranch house.

“Historic Wintersburg is a unique cultural site that tells the important story of early Japanese American immigrants as they sought to make a new life and build a community in Southern California,” said Stephanie Meeks, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, “We strongly support a collaborative effort that preserves Wintersburg’s historic landscape while building upon its longstanding role as an educational and supportive space for the Huntington Beach community.”

In 2013, the U.S. Department of the Interior introduced with the U.S. Park Service a new Asian American Pacific Islander heritage theme study, to identify and find ways to preserve Asian American historical sites.  Less than 3 percent of all National Register listings represent places associated with diverse cultural groups, according to the National Trust. 

You have a chance to help us save one of these rare American heritage places! Don’t let this pioneer history be erased!


A preview of “Our American Family”, a public television series that will feature Historic Wintersburg’s Furuta family, to be aired nationally in 2014-2015. Courtesy of Our American Family, www.ourAmericanFamilytv.com.


FUNDRAISING GOALS

Immediate goal: $50,000

The immediate, critical path need for the preservation of Historic Wintersburg is funding of a $35,000 Urban Land Institute technical advisory* and professional stabilization of the six buildings at Historic Wintersburg.

Urban Land Institute technical advisory: This analysis of the property is conducted by a multidisciplinary and balanced team of builders, developers, preservationists, historians, real estate finance professionals, and planners provides a land use planning proof-of-concept document explaining how the historic features on the property can be preserved, while incorporating adaptive reuse.  This report is the tool that shows potential partners how historic preservation works in a financially viable and economically productive approach.  It provides the "road map" to a restored, beautiful and vibrant Historic Wintersburg!

Professional stabilization: The funds used for stabilization of the buildings will go toward removal of debris or ephemera that may degrade the buildings before preservation, tree trimming, branch and brush clearing near buildings, and any additional security measures that may help stabilize the structures, which, according to a recent inspection by representatives from the U.S. Park Service retain “remarkable integrity” and can be beautifully restored.

*ALL DONORS who help us meet the mid-point goal of $35,000 before October 31, 2014; will have their name in the final Urban Land Institute (ULI) technical study as an underwriter.  This report will be circulated nationally.

Photo of Depression-era Wintersburg Japanese Presbyterian Church, circa 1934. This is among the six buildings still standing at Historic Wintersburg. Photograph courtesy of Wintersburg Presbyterian Church. © All rights reserved.


Long-term objective:

We will work with partners to acquire the Historic Wintersburg property from the current landowner, who is willing to sell.  We currently are working with the National Trust for Historic Preservation to reach out to potential partners in preservation.  The 4 1/2-acre property may be valued at approximately $5 million (the Urban Land Institute report will provide an assessment).

Additional contributions that exceed the immediate $50,000 goal will go to the dedicated Historic Wintersburg Preservation Fund, which has public oversight.  This funding helps the Historic Wintersburg Preservation Task Force work with other financial partners to buy the property and begin its restoration. 

Collaborative partnerships can reduce preservation costs. All funds raised are dedicated solely to the ongoing preservation work (stabilization, expert restoration, archaeological work on the property, public education programs, long-term stewardship and maintenance).

About your donation

The Historic Wintersburg Preservation Task Force has applied for a 501c3 nonprofit designation.  The Preservation Fund has both City and Public oversight and is dedicated solely to the preservation of Historic Wintersburg.  We are considered a charitable donation today under our current organization, per IRS Code, 26 U.S.C.170(c)(1). Tax I.D. 95-6000723

TRANSFORMATION THROUGH PRESERVATION: The 4 ½ -acre Historic Wintersburg property is adjacent to a public elementary school; a church; a private preschool, junior high and high school; residential housing; and industrial use along its west boundary. Preservation with adaptive reuse can provide walkable neighborhood open space features, jobs, educational opportunities, as well as a buffer from industrial uses for the nearby residents and school.  (Image 5269_082714 © courtesy of Fred Emmert, AirViews.com) © All rights reserved.


  • Walk inside Wintersburg Village again. 

  • Save part of California’s mission history, the Japanese Mission Trail.  

  • Preserve a permanent, tangible memorial for American civil liberties education.

  • Ensure future generations have a place to honor all the remarkable pioneers who settled the American West.


Join us in our effort to save one of America’s 11 Most Endangered Historic Places: Historic Wintersburg in Huntington Beach, California!

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

After many years of writing about the issues, Trish Riley, an environmental journalist, realized that words alone are not enough to both educate people and mobilize them to act on behalf of the environment and a sustainable economy.  That realization inspired her to create Cinema Verde -- an international environmental film and arts festival.  Film truly is the perfect medium to explain complex environmental issues clearly and in a  nonthreatening way, often through the personal stories of film makers. 

In the past 4 years, Cinema Verde films have been powerful and shocking, moving and compelling, enlightening and frightening, and, yes, sometimes heartbreaking but also funny and sweet. With dramatic personal stories, powerful images, and dynamic illustrations of causes and effects, these films open our eyes, our hearts, and our minds.

Supplementing her personal funds with small grants and with the help of a few unpaid volunteers and enthusiastic university interns, Trish has grown Cinema Verde over the past 4 years and established it as a unique event that is building a strong foundation for transitioning to a culture where a healthy environment and a sustainable economy go hand in hand.

Because ticket prices are kept as low as possible to attract the widest possible audience, tickets sales are a very small source of income. Therefore, this campaign is needed to take Cinema Verde to the next level.

Thanks to donations made to this Indiegogo campaign, enlightening films from around the world and their directors will inspire many people, long after the festival is over, to help create a culture that sustains both the economy and the environment.

Check out the Cinema Verde archives and see the variety and power of the films that have been previously screened at Cinema Verde:  2010 Program, 2011 Program, 2012 film list with links to trailers, 2013 film list and trailers. 

This link takes you to a 28-minute video that provides more info about Trish and shows her discussing Cinema Verde a local public information show.

WHAT WE NEED

Donations to this campaign will be used for any of the following:

$16,000 to cover travel and housing for 4 moviemakers:

-  $1,000 for travel, including hotel and meals and $1,000 honorarium (at least 3 days including travel) = $2,000/moviemaker x 4 = $8,000 x 2 years = $16,000.

$25,000 toward salary for 1 year for a full-time marketer.

$20,000 toward salary for 1 year for a full-time office manager/volunteer coordinator.

$11,000 for a campaign to solicit individuals or companies to provide permanent supplemental funding.  This will cover expenses for research, long distance phone calls, travel, and related time and effort.

$10,000 for advertising.

Total:  $72,000

THE IMPACT

In addition to the impact the films have, the arts and fair part of the festival serves as a lynchpin that brings together the many diverse environmental organizations and cultural transformation organizations that each have their own mission but similar goals and introduces them to the community.  Because this is an international festival and also incorporates a student competition, the festival helps nurture creativity through diversity and education.  Further, the emphasis of the films selected fro CV is economic sustainability as well as environmental protection,

Cinema Verde was created literally out of thin air – there was no organization already existing that was able to jump start the process.  Despite that, a shoestring budget, and a lack of paid professional staff, the success of the festival to date is evidence that this is a much needed and appreciated event and that people want to learn about the issues even though they are complex and often even painful to learn about.

Although the Festival is based in Gainesville, Florida, there are plans to take the show on the road to magnify the effects of the connections and experiences that are generated by the films. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can’t contribute financially, please help by spreading the word about this festival as far and wide as possible by Facebook, Twitter, and any other means.

When you plan a trip to Florida, have it coincide with the Festival and come and see for yourself how film is the perfect medium for learning about complex environmental and economic issues, hearing about solutions, and being inspired to take action.

story:
Description of our group and our project

Our group consists of six researchers, who are living, working and studying in Berlin/ Germany. Four of us are students of environmental engineering and one is student of fine arts focused in cultural science. Our interdisciplinary group will focalize on the growing copper and gold mining industry, combined with the cultural background of nomad’s life in Mongolia which we intend to study from July until August.

The goal of our project is to analyze this aspect from a socio-ecological perspective by visiting two different mining areas and talking to the surrounding residents. Our documentation about mining, especially about Copper- and Gold mining and their influence on nature and humans will consist of recorded interviews, photographies and video films. We will focus on the environmental impact, like water scarcity and changes in the flora. Also we are interested in changes concerning the nomad’s lifestyle as Mongolian nomads managed to maintain their lifestyle throughout a vast period of time and global changes. Are they changing their way of life now with the mining boom in Mongolia? Using their knowledge we would like to raise awareness on that topic.

In our interviews we will ask questions like:

Changes in the life of nomads:ithe life of nomads:

- What do you know about mining? Have you been informed by the government or the companies about mining? What did you experience?

- What has changed in recent years in your nomadic life? How did elder generations live in this landscape?

- Did you experience any conflicts between mining companies and nomads? Whom can you contact in case of conflicts?

Changes in the environment:

- Did the scenery generally change (because of mining) in the last 10 years?

- Did water supply areas or grazing areas change? What is the water situation today compared to the past?

We need 6.500 Euro for our project. We expect following expenses:

  • Rent for a Minivan for 14 days. 100€/day, 14 days = 1.400 €

  • Driver/Guide since there are no street signs and a lot of streets are in a bad state, so you need a local who  is familiar with the area. 2 drivers day’s wage = 10 € * 8h=80 €/day * 14 days = 1120€ * 2= 2.240 €
  • Gas for 14 days:  Oyu Tolgoi 650km and Boroo 110km = 1520km = 228L match to 300 € (Gas current prices: super = 1,01€/L)

  • Info material for the locals, video equipment: 300 €

  • Board and lodging for six person: (10€/Person*d)*14 days*6=840€ (board) + 700€ (lodging) = 1.540€

  • Any additional money can help us to reduce our flight costs. (120 € p. person)

perks for our sponsors

All items are from Mongolia. 

  • Hadag is a blue cloth made of silk, representing the blue sky. It is used as a ceremonial cloth in Buddhist rituals, and stands for courtesy and blessing. It is symbol of the well-wishing and honorary greeting.

  • A water color picture of Mongolian landscape, which is hand painted.

  • Different brainteaser/puzzle toy (onison togloom) for all ages, handmade of wood. 

  • Shagai is a game of skill, made of ankle bones from sheep and goat. Mongolians exchange shagai as tokens of friendship. It has four possible sides (horse, camel, sheep and goat).

The importance of our project for you and us:

When new mining areas are being developed, theoretically there is always the chance to minimize the negative socio-ecological impact directly from the beginning rather than repeating former  mistakes over and over again and dealing with the consequences afterwards. But taking precautions always reduces profit so that in cases of slack governmental regulations future impact is not considered. Especially in such cases a sensitive community is indispensable.

As consumers we are part of the resource cycle, as gold and copper are essential when it comes to electric devices and their lifecycle. In industrialized countries a life without all these electronic helpers is unthinkable. But we have to realize, it has its price. What is the price?

In order to find out we will record interviews with people from local communities. We intend to record the actual state and the environmental and social (especially for the nomadic living people) changes caused by the intensive mining during the last 10 years. Hereby we provide information about the circumstances under which resources are produced. We want to learn how the nomads, who have managed to maintain their lifestyle in this globalized world, deal with the mining boom in Mongolia.  Based on their knowledge we wish to help out with information and links between mining and water scarcity or airborne pollutants etc. We want to communicate the results of our research and raise awareness to consumers too by putting together a documentary. This way we hope to contribute to a sensitized local community and consumers. 

Our cultural scientist Mady Piesold will support the documentary with her special knowledge. During 2011 she was already involved in documentary work and analyzed the cultural changes and assimilation of the native population in Alaska.  The results of her work were presented in several exhibitions and lectures. 

Besides giving us financial support you can help us to broadcast the idea of our campaign and this platform with all information about our projects.
