Rent for a Minivan for 14 days. 100€/day, 14 days = 1.400 €


Driver/Guide since there are no street signs and a lot of streets are in a bad state, so you need a local who  is familiar with the area. 2 drivers day’s wage = 10 € * 8h=80 €/day * 14 days = 1120€ * 2= 2.240 €
Gas for 14 days:  Oyu Tolgoi 650km and Boroo 110km = 1520km = 228L match to 300 € (Gas current prices: super = 1,01€/L)


Info material for the locals, video equipment: 300 €


Board and lodging for six person: (10€/Person*d)*14 days*6=840€ (board) + 700€ (lodging) = 1.540€


Any additional money can help us to reduce our flight costs. (120 € p. person)


perks for our sponsors
All items are from Mongolia. 

Hadag is a blue cloth made of silk, representing the blue sky. It is used as a ceremonial cloth in Buddhist rituals, and stands for courtesy and blessing. It is symbol of the well-wishing and honorary greeting.


A water color picture of Mongolian landscape, which is hand painted.


Different brainteaser/puzzle toy (onison togloom) for all ages, handmade of wood. 


Shagai is a game of skill, made of ankle bones from sheep and goat. Mongolians exchange shagai as tokens of friendship. It has four possible sides (horse, camel, sheep and goat).

The importance of our project for you and us:
When new mining areas are being developed, theoretically there is always the chance to minimize the negative socio-ecological impact directly from the beginning rather than repeating former  mistakes over and over again and dealing with the consequences afterwards. But taking precautions always reduces profit so that in cases of slack governmental regulations future impact is not considered. Especially in such cases a sensitive community is indispensable.
As consumers we are part of the resource cycle, as gold and copper are essential when it comes to electric devices and their lifecycle. In industrialized countries a life without all these electronic helpers is unthinkable. But we have to realize, it has its price. What is the price?
In order to find out we will record interviews with people from local communities. We intend to record the actual state and the environmental and social (especially for the nomadic living people) changes caused by the intensive mining during the last 10 years. Hereby we provide information about the circumstances under which resources are produced. We want to learn how the nomads, who have managed to maintain their lifestyle in this globalized world, deal with the mining boom in Mongolia.  Based on their knowledge we wish to help out with information and links between mining and water scarcity or airborne pollutants etc. We want to communicate the results of our research and raise awareness to consumers too by putting together a documentary. This way we hope to contribute to a sensitized local community and consumers. 
Our cultural scientist Mady Piesold will support the documentary with her special knowledge. During 2011 she was already involved in documentary work and analyzed the cultural changes and assimilation of the native population in Alaska.  The results of her work were presented in several exhibitions and lectures. 
Besides giving us financial support you can help us to broadcast the idea of our campaign and this platform with all information about our projects.

story:
NB: La traduction en français de ce texte est disponible ici !

NB: Die deutschsprachige Übersetzung von diesem Text ist hier erhältlich !


News about this Campaign

Climanosco, an independent, non-profit association, is setting the goal to make knowledge on climate understandable and accessible to everyone by building a direct bridge between citizens and climate scientists. Help us make this possible by supporting Climanosco during this Crowdfunding campaign!

Nov 4: The campaign is inDemand, which means that you can continue to support Climanosco!!! Thank you all for your fantastic and continuing support!

Our Launch Challenge is starting now! Bring your own perspective, voice your impressions, be part of the discussions! We have received 12 manuscripts from bright early-career scientists from around the world. In their manuscripts, the authors discuss the state-of-the-art climate science in non-scientific language on hot topics including Greenland ice sheet, solar variability, El Niño, natural variability, heat waves, flash floods, climate and air quality among others. We hope that very exciting discussions will develop around these manuscripts over the next 2 weeks to give a first feed-back to the authors on the content and the form (including accessibility for a large public). Bring your own perspective, voice your impressions, be part of these discussions! Don't wait, join us today at www.climanosco.org/launchchallenge.

This campaign is supported by two rising star artists with an exclusive painting. We are delighted to present the artist duo Barbara Glazar and Ryan James who supports our campaign with a fabulous 2 m diameter painting. Their Biography is available here (21Mb).

Exclusive rewards are waiting for you; in particular, a limited edition certified museum quality fine art print of the masterpiece in 57x57cm (22 x 22in) format. Please follow the Gallery link at the top of this page for a more detailed picture.

Here is the video presentation of the painting:



Our Vision on Climate

Climate has been on the international scene and in the news for more than 20 years now. But, have you ever wondered what we actually know about the climate? If you wanted to know more about it, where would you go? Do you know of a media which gives a serious, reliable and understandable access to climate science to everyone? Something you can really trust on this important and highly controversial topic? Something which is not just an opinion, but which is solidly based on the best science available?

We would like to offer the best science available to everyone in an understandable manner by building a direct bridge between citizens and climate scientists around the world. We think that it is of the utmost importance that everyone has free and reliable access to what climate scientists know on climate and that everyone can ask questions to climate scientists and get answers. We believe that we can achieve this together and that it may help everyone shape a positive future for themselves and for their children.


Goals of Climanosco

The goals of Climanosco are:

  • To provide free access to high quality climate science to everyone in non-scientific language.
  • To allow citizens to engage in the process of making climate science and of communicating it.
  • To provide a direct channel to raise questions related to climate science and obtain answers from active climate scientists.
  • To offer scientists a reliable channel for communicating their research to the public.

All our decisions and actions taken in pursuing these goals are based on three pillars:

  • Independence and neutrality
  • Individual participation
  • Highest scientific standards


How do we want to achieve our goals?

It’s quite simple! We open the door for you and all interested people to engage in the communication of science and in the making of science. We connect citizens and climate scientists, allow their interaction and publish resulting climate articles. To support these activities, we are developing an innovative platform which structures the community’s interactions and allows the free publication of articles. Here is an overview of the types of interaction it allows:




Climate Articles…

The climate articles will open the door to the inside of the world of climate science, all in non-scientific language. They will bring readers directly to the frontier between what we know and what we don’t know today as human beings. You will discover this frontier, its challenges, the avenues that are being explored. You will find out how existing paradigms are questioned and re-evaluated by the scientists, as research develops.


… and Arts

As humans, our perception and understanding go through the channels of our senses. Arts provide sensible and human perspectives on thematics, which even if very abstract, can support the process of acquiring knowledge. Arts and sciences are to work together at Climanosco. Although this aspect will be developed in the next phase, we are readily establishing the connection by having our two artists Barbara Glazar and Ryan James associated to this campaign.


How this story started…

Ideas emerged and developed over time through discussions between colleagues, friends and scientists that all had one common idea: to make climate knowledge more accessible. Then in 2014, the ideas took a coherent shape and we started to build a functional web site and an initial, yet worldwide community. Earlier this year, we defined our name, Climanosco, and founded a non-profit association that is registered in Zurich. We now have a Board of Directors, a scientific Editorial Board and about 60 members all around the world.


Meet some of our members



"This platform is the place where non-scientists people can access scientific information that is easy to understand! " - Marie

"People need to be informed about the climate issues in simple and easy to understand language so that they can start making right choices on the basis of correct scientific knowledge. This is what "Climanosco" aims for - passing the correct scientific information to people. Hence I am with Climanosco." - Ninad

"I want to help Climanosco become a respected, trusted and influential forum to which people may look out to inform themselves, get the facts right and progressively create momentum for a positive and rational change for the better. " - Enrique

"Climanosco will be a pioneer of climate information for the citizens. An independent forum, without biases, is needed" - Philippe

"This platform will be a contribution to find balance between our way of living and the Earth Climate." - Angélica

"Climanosco is an initiative to provide free online access to the climate science for everyone, with or without a science background. I invite citizens all around the world to join, support and make use of Climanosco as a bridge to connect with climate scientists." - Narendra

"With Climanosco, we are developing a community of citizens and climate scientists from all around the world which works together at shifting the old paradigm." – Michel


Why we need your support

Up to now, we have run exclusively on the high quality engagement of our members and the financial support of the founder. However to reach the next level in our reach, our community, our articles and our internet platform, we need your support.

In the coming year, we would like to improve our platform and become a bigger community in order to publish a lot of interesting articles that can be read by a lot of people from around the world. Furthermore, our plan is to develop an artistic component in our activities.

To make this possible, we need your support, even small!

Note that we accept donations up to a cap of $2000 per donor per year. This is our way to stay strictly independent.


How you can help further

We warmly welcome your help in spreading the word, one way or another. #MakeClimateKnowledgeAccessible.


A Warm Thank You For Your Support!

The entire Climanosco association warmly thanks you for your support. If you have any question remaining, don’t hesitate to contact us at crowdfunding@climanosco.org, we will be most happy to communicate with you.


FAQ

When can I expect to receive my reward(s)?

As soon as the Crowdfunding campaign is over on the 15th of October, we will start to prepare all the rewards. They will be shipped in November 2015 at the latest.

How will you know where to send my reward(s)?

Your shipping information will be collected during check-out process.

Do you ship to all countries? How will shipping be handled internationally?

Yes. You will see the shipping costs associated with your donation's rewards upon checking out.

Can you say more on the rewards associated with the painting?

Thanks to the artists associated with this campaign, we can offer for this campaign, limited edition certified museum quality hahnemuhle fine art prints of the original masterpiece, each numbered and signed by the artists (size: 56x56cm or 22x22inches). The number of copies is limited to 100 overall, and by supporting Climanosco during this campaign, you will receive the very first ones. This is a very exclusive award which is limited to the perks of $1000 and $2000.

Can you give more information on the masterpiece of the artists associated with the campaign?

The masterpiece is a uniquely beautiful painting of 2 m diameter kindly provided by our artist duo in support of this campaign, Barbara Glazar and Ryan James. More details on the painting will be soon shown on this page.

How do you know my shirt size if my reward is a T-shirt?

We will email you at the end of the campaign to get your shirt size.

Why do you give a membership voucher as a reward?

Climanosco’s membership is available for free for 2015-2016. However, we plan to introduce annual membership fees then. If your donation is associated with a membership voucher, you will be able redeem the voucher once the membership fees are introduced.

I would like to order the "Superstar"-reward, but I can't come to Zurich. Do you give me something else in return?

Instead of visiting our workspaces and have dinner with the founder, Michel Bourqui, we can offer you a personal chat with him via Skype and a voucher for a free lifetime membership.

Can I select more than one perk?

Yes, you can. However, as per our Statutes, we can only accept from a single donor a total donation per year up to a maximum of $2000.

What will you do with the money?

Our plan for the coming 1-2 years is to mandate preferably highly qualified students to work with us on the following projects: the improvement of our internet platform into a professional publishing platform with online video streaming, the development of our multi-lingual capacities, the development of the artistic component in our activities, and the growth and strengthening of our community of members and readers worldwide.

Is this the first campaign you organize?

Yes, it is our first Crowdfunding campaign and it is also the first time we raise money!

Is $12’000 really all you need to go ahead with Climanosco?

Since this is our first campaign, we don’t really know what to expect. So, we set the bar reasonably low. The more we receive during this campaign, the faster we will get to the next level. Our strategy is a long term one. We learn by doing and we will progress one step at a time, whatever happens.

How is Climanosco funded so far?

Climanosco is being funded by its founder and relies on the work of all members and especially of the Board of Directors. They are willing to take this challenge because Climanosco means something to all of them.

What means "Climanosco"?

The name "Climanosco" is composed of the Latin words "Clima" and "Nosco", the active form of the verb to know. So, it means something like "I am becoming knowledgeable on climate". That’s precisely what we wish our readers and members to feel when they connect with Climanosco. "Climanosco" is a trademark.

Where is Climanosco based?

Climanosco is based and registered in Zurich, Switzerland.

How can I get involved? Who can become a member?

You can simply register on our website www.climanosco.org and become a member. Climanosco is about the participation of its members as individuals in their diversity and uniqueness. It does not accept institutional members.

story:
The Indiegogo campaign is over...the movement is just beginning ... ratemyland.com

**Make sure you read the updates within the Update tab above.**

                                                                                                                - Thanks, Derek

CHECK OUT OUR PROTOTYPE WEBSITE!

We are losing plants and animals at alarming rates! We need to increase our conservation efforts, but we have many holes in our data; we are unclear about the distributions of the critters we are trying to conserve. To conserve a rare species it is vital that we know how many of them exist and where they are living. This data is gathered through inventories of the land. This is what biologists do…what then, is the hold-up? The challenge is that 87% of the land in the eastern U.S. is privately owned; and up to half of all rare plants and animals live solely on private land. We can’t begin to fully understand species distributions and how to best conserve rare species without thorough inventories of private property, but biologists have, by and far, only been surveying public land for decades. One of the reasons private lands have not been surveyed is because private landowners have not been invited to do so or they haven’t known how. Rate My Land (RML) will offer the invitation and walk a landowner through the process. Rate My Land will try and tackle other roadblocks too (like the financial burden!). It’s time for RML to change the norm and foster a new wave of private landowners who are exploring the biodiversity on their land with the help of biologists. 

Join with us to develop a fully-functioning website that offers education, resources, connection to biological consultants, rewards, and incentives to private landowners - empowering them to engage in conservation and have their land formally surveyed. Our goal is to create a social norm where it is commonplace and esteemed for private landowners to have their land biologically surveyed. Will you help get this project off the ground? Spread the word, make a donation...it's only through collective "small" steps of action that, together, we'll make a big impact and turn the tide of species loss. 


We are requesting funds to develop a professional and highly functioning website and to cover web hosting fees. We want the site to be dynamic and user-friendly. We realize that really good websites can cost well over our funding goal. We feel with five to six thousand, a good website can be created, especially for an initial launching. My wife, Adrienne, has some experience in graphic design and web creation that we can rely on to help reduce costs and serve to build RateMyLand.com if necessary. Anything above and beyond our goal will allow us to do that much more with our website. A portion (10%?) of the funds raised will also go towards marketing and expanding the reach of Rate My Land. This would include travel expenses to give presentations about RML to regional land conservancies. One of our marketing strategies is to work collaboratively with land conservancies in getting Conservation Easement landowners involved in Rate My Land to build a base of users and momentum. Website is priority number one, marketing and education number two; then any remaining funds would be used to purchase better equipment to keep RML going.

To thank you for your support and encourage your donation, I have rounded up some great perks. Two botanical gardens have donated admission tickets, friends Seth and May Bernard and Ken Scott (see beautiful photo below) have donated some of their talented artwork in support of the Rate My Land campaign. With a large donation, you can be one of the Rate My Land forerunners and have the botanical diversity of your land assessed by me this summer. Fellow botanists have helped me assemble excellent plant photographs that I have put into a quick reference, pocket field guide. You could elect to sport an RML t-shirt that asks, “Do you know what’s on your land?” or an RML bumper sticker to continue to spread the word about Rate My Land long after this campaign is over.


Thank you for taking a look at our campaign. I am a biologist at heart, have been all of my life, but I also am by training. I have Masters Degrees in Environmental Science and Biology. I have published scientific papers about landscape ecology and plant systematics. This project, however, gets back to the heart, to the activism side of me. I have a deep conviction to care for the earth and a profound belief that people, in community, can do great things.


Do you know that we have only identified around 20% of the biodiversity that is estimated to exist on our planet? There are four more creatures to discover for every one creature we know. Most of these creatures are arthropods (insects, spiders, and crustaceans) residing in tropical forests. While there should be great urgency to identify that biodiversity, we know far too little about the creatures that already have names. Even in temperate North America, where diversity is low, relative to the tropics, demographic and ecological data about species’ population sizes, ranges, and threats to their health are largely unknown. Large gaps exist in our data for public lands, or roughly 40% of the country. For the country as a whole, private land included, the gaps are chasms. Unfortunately, the majority of private landowners have not had biological surveys conducted on their land, either fearing regulation or uncertain on how to initiate the process.  Rate My Land will address these fears and make new or first time invitations to landowners to engage in biodiversity surveys.

Biological surveys provide data on the number and condition of populations, the ranges occupied by species, population trends and dynamics, and they identify threats from non-native pests. This data is foundational to species conservation and land management. A great potential for reversing species loss and restoring biodiversity lies in engaging private landowners. This will face challenges and roadblocks—finances, ideological hesitations, and lack of motivation. Rate My Land is an attempt to bring about new incentives that push past these roadblocks. Our vision for RML is that it will grow to be an entity that lobbies government agencies to initiate new monetary incentives (and expand the reach of existing ones) for landowners engaging in conservation. We see RML creating new incentives internally by raising the value and desire for high quality land and biodiversity through focused educational campaigns and collaborations with real-estate agencies. Rate My Land will be an advocate for landowners by petitioning governmental agencies to establish assurances that managing their land to help rare species will not lead to further regulations. When people interact with Rate My Land, we want them to feel inspired and motivated to join and take action. We hope that every action they take, every new creature they learn to see and call by name, will lead them further down the road as an advocate for biodiversity.

Consulting companies will pay a small fee to use the standardized RML inventory forms as a way to eventually help make RML self-sufficient in covering operating expenses. Extra money will be used to create a “scholarship”, which will be offered to landowners to cover a portion of the expense in hiring a biological consultant.


We can’t get to that point without you. Your monetary contribution is needed. As well, we need you to help us get the word out! Encourage your friends and relatives with land to contact a biologist this spring and get their land surveyed. It’s through these collective “small” steps that we’ll make a big impact. By pulling together, we can create a social norm for private landowners to have their land surveyed…bringing us that much closer to turning the tide of species loss. Please support Rate My Land, tackling large problems with grassroots initiative.
story_txt:
The Indiegogo campaign is over...the movement is just beginning ... ratemyland.com**Make sure you read the updates within the Update tab above.**                                                                                                                - Thanks, DerekCHECK OUT OUR PROTOTYPE WEBSITE!We are losing plants and animals at alarming rates! We need
to increase our conservation efforts, but we have many holes in our data; we
are unclear about the distributions of the critters we are trying to conserve. To
conserve a rare species it is vital that we know how many of them exist and
where they are living. This data is gathered through inventories of the land. This
is what biologists do…what then, is the hold-up? The challenge is that 87% of
the land in the eastern U.S. is privately owned; and up to half of all rare
plants and animals live solely on private land. We can’t begin to fully
understand species distributions and how to best conserve rare species without thorough
inventories of private property, but biologists have, by and far, only been
surveying public land for decades. One of the reasons private lands have not
been surveyed is because private landowners have not been invited to do so or
they haven’t known how. Rate My Land (RML) will offer the invitation and walk a
landowner through the process. Rate My Land will try and tackle other roadblocks too (like
the financial burden!). It’s time for RML to change the norm and foster a new
wave of private landowners who are exploring the biodiversity on their land
with the help of biologists.  

Join with us to develop a fully-functioning website that offers education, resources, connection to biological consultants, rewards, and incentives to private landowners - empowering them to engage in conservation and have their land formally surveyed. Our goal is to create a social norm where it is commonplace and esteemed for private landowners to have their land biologically surveyed. Will you help get this project off the ground? Spread the word, make a donation...it's only through collective "small" steps of action that, together, we'll make a big impact and turn the tide of species loss. We are requesting funds to develop a
professional and highly functioning website and to cover web hosting fees. We want the site to be dynamic and
user-friendly. We realize that really good websites can cost well over our
funding goal. We feel with five to six thousand, a good website can be
created, especially for an initial launching. My wife, Adrienne, has some
experience in graphic design and web creation that we can rely on to help
reduce costs and serve to build RateMyLand.com if necessary. Anything above and
beyond our goal will allow us to do that much more with our website. A portion
(10%?) of the funds raised will also go towards marketing and expanding the
reach of Rate My Land. This would include travel expenses to give presentations
about RML to regional land conservancies. One of our marketing strategies is to
work collaboratively with land conservancies in getting Conservation Easement
landowners involved in Rate My Land to build a base of users and momentum.
Website is priority number one, marketing and education number two; then any
remaining funds would be used to purchase better equipment to keep RML going.
To thank you for your support and encourage your
donation, I have rounded up some great perks. Two botanical gardens have
donated admission tickets, friends Seth and May Bernard and Ken Scott (see beautiful photo below) have
donated some of their talented artwork in support of the Rate My Land campaign.
With a large donation, you can be one of the Rate My Land forerunners and have the
botanical diversity of your land assessed by me this summer. Fellow botanists have helped me assemble excellent plant photographs that I have put into a quick reference, pocket field guide. You could elect to
sport an RML t-shirt that asks, “Do you know what’s on your land?” or an RML bumper
sticker to continue to spread the word about Rate My Land long after this
campaign is over.Thank you for taking a look at our campaign. I am a biologist at heart, have been all of my life, but I also am by training. I have Masters Degrees in Environmental Science and Biology. I have published scientific papers about landscape ecology and plant systematics. This project, however, gets back to the heart, to the activism side of me. I have a deep conviction to care for the earth and a profound belief that people, in community, can do great things.Do you know that we have only identified
around 20% of the biodiversity that is estimated to exist on our planet? There
are four more creatures to discover for every one creature we know. Most of
these creatures are arthropods (insects, spiders, and crustaceans) residing in
tropical forests. While there should be great urgency to identify that
biodiversity, we know far too little about the creatures that already have
names. Even in temperate North America, where diversity is low, relative to the
tropics, demographic and ecological data about species’ population sizes,
ranges, and threats to their health are largely unknown. Large gaps exist in
our data for public lands, or roughly 40% of the country. For the country as a whole,
private land included, the gaps are chasms. Unfortunately, the majority of
private landowners have not had biological surveys conducted on their land, either
fearing regulation or uncertain on how to initiate the process.  Rate My Land will address these fears and make
new or first time invitations to landowners to engage in biodiversity surveys. 
Biological surveys provide data on the number and condition of populations,
the ranges occupied by species, population trends and dynamics, and they
identify threats from non-native pests. This data is foundational to species
conservation and land management. A great potential for reversing species loss
and restoring biodiversity lies in engaging private landowners. This will face
challenges and roadblocks—finances, ideological hesitations, and lack of motivation.
Rate My Land is an attempt to bring about new incentives that push past these
roadblocks. Our vision for RML is that it will grow to be an entity that lobbies
government agencies to initiate new monetary incentives (and expand the reach
of existing ones) for landowners engaging in conservation. We see RML creating
new incentives internally by raising the value and desire for high quality land
and biodiversity through focused educational campaigns and collaborations with
real-estate agencies. Rate My Land will be an advocate for landowners by
petitioning governmental agencies to establish assurances that managing their land to help rare species will not lead to further regulations. When
people interact with Rate My Land, we want them to feel inspired and motivated
to join and take action. We hope that every action they take, every new creature
they learn to see and call by name, will lead them further down the road as an
advocate for biodiversity.
Consulting
companies will pay a small fee to use the standardized RML inventory forms as a
way to eventually help
make RML self-sufficient in covering operating expenses. Extra money will be
used to create a “scholarship”, which will be offered to landowners to cover a
portion of the expense in hiring a biological consultant. 
We can’t get to that point without you. Your monetary contribution is
needed. As well, we need you to help us get the word out! Encourage your
friends and relatives with land to contact a biologist this spring and get
their land surveyed. It’s through these collective “small” steps that we’ll
make a big impact. By pulling together, we can create a social norm for private
landowners to have their land surveyed…bringing us that much closer to turning the tide of species loss. Please support Rate My Land,
tackling large problems with grassroots initiative.

story:
Short Summary

Numerous dams are planned for the largest source of the Amazon River, the Rio Marañon, in Peru. We want to help Peruvians educate fellow Peruvians about the dams to let an informed country decide about their value.

We are volunteers who are part of a campaign to raise awareness in Peru about a series of dams being constructed on the Marañón River, the largest volume contributor of the Amazon River.

Socially and ecologically speaking, the Marañon, home of the "Grand Canyon of South America," is one of the most important rivers in the world. It supports a huge variety of endemic and endangered species spanning numerous ecosystems from high-alpine Andean terrain through the jungles of the Amazon. It is also home to more than 100,000 Peruvians and native Amazonian communities. The electricity from the proposed dams is slated mostly for use in Brazil and in a large -- and controversial -- Peruvian mining operation. A number of the dams to be constructed are "megadams" (>1000MW), which will create reservoirs that flood huge areas and displace many local people. These impacts will extend beyond the local environment as the effects of damming this river and adjusting flows and sediment supply will be significant throughout the Amazon. 

Like many dams in the developing world, very few people know about the issues at hand. Our goal is simple -- to raise awareness about what is going on. The Peruvian NGO Conservamos por Naturaleza is launching a campaign to bring the issue to the public eye within Peru. As part of this campaign, we are running the Paddling With Purpose project. We are part of a group taking a handful of environmentally-minded young Peruvians on a raft trip down the Marañon's Grand Canyon and filming their journey, aiming to produce a documentary that Conservamos por Naturaleza can use to engage the Peruvian public in this issue.

For more information about the project itself: Paddling With Purpose

For more information about the dams and the issues facing the river: International Rivers Fact Sheet

What We Need & What You Get

First and foremost, we're raising money to cover the costs of the expedition on the Marañon. Daphnee and I are donating our time and money to be there as experienced raft guides, but we need help to cover the costs of the group of Peruvians joining the trip. The base cost of this 18 day expedition is roughly $13,000 and includes transport, food, and equipment rental. We are covering our own costs for the trip, but are asking for help to support the Peruvians and other volunteer raft guides.

The raft expedition is just the first part of this project, though. Conservamos por Naturaleza is budgeting a further $7000 to produce a high quality documentary and promote it in Peru following the trip. As a team of volunteers, we're hoping to raise over $20,000, but the sky is the limit -- any additional money raised will go towards promoting awareness of the issue in Peru and running a follow-up publicity campaign to try and create the political will necessary to mitigate the harm that comes to the Marañon.

The Impact

The Marañon is in a remote area and most Peruvians aren't aware of the impacts the planned dams will have on it. There is a select group -- those that live their lives along the banks of the river -- that know very personally what those impacts will be, but lack the power to make a difference. 

This project aims to bridge that gap between the Peruvians who are aware of the importance of the free-flowing Marañon and those who wield the power to mitigate the harm being done to it. Large-scale hydro has been studied and shown, in general, to ultimately not be worth the cost; the US went down that road, as did many other countries, and is slowly coming to the realization that it was a mistake. In Peru -- on the Marañon -- the cost will be more than environmental, as thousands of people will be displaced by the reservoirs these dams create. 

Risks & Challenges

The raft trip itself is fairly straightforward -- there is an exceptional multinational team of paddlers and guides volunteering to make it possible, and it is a very manageable section of river. Aside from trying to keep a host of camera equipment charged and dry, the real challenges are in leveraging the trip to achieve our goals to raise awareness and initiate a campaign within Peru to help save the Marañon.

Conservamos por Naturaleza is trying to create a national movement, akin to Chile's "Sin Represas" campaign that has (for now) saved the Rios Baker and Pascua in Patagonia. The risk with this campaign is that we go on this trip and create a powerful documentary, but nobody sees it. This is why we need as much support as we can get. The more money we raise, the more publicity the campaign can garner after our trip, and the more momentum it can build to fight the massive proposed dams on the Marañon.

Larger Donations?

If you're able to make a larger donation, contact us directly so we can facilitate a tax-deductible contribution through our partner, Sierra Rios. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, there are still other ways to help.

  • Share our campaign -- just because you can't contribute doesn't mean someone you know might not be able to. Every time we post on Facebook, please like and share! You have no idea how big a difference this actually makes!
  • Spread the word about the Marañon -- the reason these dams get built around the world is because not enough people are fighting them. If you want, organize your own trip and raft the Marañon while we still can. We're happy to put you in touch with outfitters who are able to make private trips happen. 

Here are some links to other resources about the Marañon and the fight to protect it and the Amazon headwaters:

  • Sierra Rios
  • A video from a prior trip with interviews of locals along the river
  • International Rivers' Fact Sheet

story:
2018 EMGS Young Scientist Award

-------------------------------------------------------

Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society

Ever wonder what things in the environment do to your genes? We are the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS), scientists in academia, government, and industry working to understand the genetic impacts of environmental exposures to promote human health. Through research we learn how genes in your body respond to the environment, how changes impact health and get passed to your children, and what we should do about this.

-------------------------------------------------------

EMGS Young Scientist Award

EMGS is committed to helping young scientists - our future - make critical career transitions. At our Annual Meeting, we feature the EMGS Young Scientist Award, a chance for a new investigator embarking on an independent scientific career to give a plenary talk. Don't underestimate this honor! Face-to-face communication is one of the most important ways we learn, network, and make our science better.

Natalie Gassman
Aishwarya Prakash
Isabelle Miousse
Matt Schellenberg
Mark Hedglin

 

You Pick the Winner

The EMGS Young Scientist Award is based on YOUR support and YOU will choose the winner from the candidates below! Please view their competition videos via the links, above. Contestants are screened by EMGS and invited to participate. All are just finishing their education and training or within 3 years of establishing an independent scientific career. This is a unique opportunity to participate in science and support a promising young scientist.

-------------------------------------------------------

The Rules

Anyone making a tax-deductible donation of any amount gets a vote (you may donate/vote as many times as you'd like). The candidate with the most votes wins. Up to $2,500 will go toward hosting the award winner's attendance at the meeting and a small honorarium. Additional contributions will support the travel of more young scientists to the annual meeting in San Antonio, TX.

-------------------------------------------------------

The 49th Annual Meeting of the EMGS

Environmental toxins and toxicants impact human physiology and biochemistry by altering or modifying DNA, RNA, proteins and metabolites. Across the spectrum of scientific inquiry, we are challenged with understanding the mechanisms which respond to or modulate these genotoxic effects. Furthermore, the development of tools for analysis, as well as, for evaluation of these biological endpoints are critical for the promotion and protection of human health. By forging a bridge to bring scientists studying exposures, mechanisms, and regulatory sciences, the 2018 Annual Meeting of the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS) will provide a venue for stimulating cross-disciplinary research and discovery. We will learn how environmental agents impact genomic, proteomic and metabolic signatures, and how we can use this knowledge base to develop informed biomarkers and improved regulatory policies that address human health concerns related to environmental exposures. Join us as we cross this bridge, find common ground in our advances in the study of Environmental Health Sciences, and bring together our efforts on Exposure, Mechanism and its impact on Public Health.

story:
Who we are and what we do-

Cape Fear Environmental Film Forum is a non-profit event that aims to offer grass-roots solutions to environmental challenges by presenting environmentally themed films and galvanizing conversation between filmmakers, panels of local advocates and audience members. The Forum is open to the public and entry is free.

Our Mission-

CFEFF aims to inform and engage the people of Southeastern North Carolina on what is arguably the most important and challenging issue of the 21st century. Our goal is to bring experts and advocates from diverse backgrounds (all relating to the larger environmental issue) to brainstorm solutions that can be implemented at the grass-roots level.


What can you do?

The funds raised will help offset the cost of securing a community screening license for each of the films. Our hope is that Indiegogo will not only help with funds, but will also aid in our efforts to promote the Forum throughout South Eastern North Carolina.


Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Cape-Fear-Enviro...

story:
This is where the bees will live. 

Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory - Sandy, Oregon

Thank you for taking a look at this fundraising effort. My name is Dena Rash Guzman. I am a published poet, essayist and work as a writer and reporter for the organic food industry. Born in Las Vegas, Nevada, I now make my home on my family's 60 acre sustainable permaculture-centered produce farm deep in the pristine old-growth coniferous wilderness of the Sandy River Gorge and the Bull Run Wilderness near Portland, Oregon. Stargazer Farms, established as the Oregon Bulb Farm in the 1930s sits on a river bluff and is filled with a variety of unsprayed and organic plant life, including heirloom flowers left over from its previous life as a flower farm. It is alive with bees, butterflies and other natural pollinators, all of which forage blooms from early spring to late fall. One cannot sit still on our property during foraging season without seeing a pollinator feeding on nectar, or without hearing a constant hum-buzz of life. Three honeybee hives are kept here by our farmers at this time. I would like to add to those hives, using time-honored holistic beekeeping methods, as well as research new ways to attract and provide homes for wild pollinators like bumblebees and orchard bees. With success, I hope eventually to produce and provide these homes and habitat plans for other farms, backyard gardens and urban environments in my bioregion and beyond. Another aim is outreach, education and establishment as a nonprofit with the aim of employing at a living wage disabled people to work the hives, package honey, and help produce wild bee homes and habitats. 

The ultimate aim of Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory is to fill the world with honeybees, wild pollinators, and wildflowers. 



It is often said that the best sign of a healthy farm is a healthy beehive. Could the same be said of the world? If so, we are headed for some trouble. Bees are disappearing. Since 2006, beekeepers throughout North American and parts of Europe have watched helplessly as their honeybee hives are decimated by colony collapse disorder. From backyard hobbyists to major commercial operators, keepers have reported up to 90% hive losses each year since then, with an average yearly hive loss of 34% since 2006, since the disorder was first named and diagnosed. While hives can fall to many ailments, the mark of CCD is a hive from which nearly all the bees in the colony disappear, leaving behind the queen bee, her brood and a handful of sick bees. As bees cannot live without their colony, all the bees die. With the exception of the bees left behind in the hive, none of the other bees are found. They simply disappear. 

There are many theories but no real answers as to the cause of CCD, but some thoughts and research point to systemic pesticides, monoculture farming practices, soil erosion, changing weather patterns in North America, chemical treatment of beehives, pollution, water scarcity, viruses including a newly discovered one that jumps from flower to bee, premature replacement of queen bees to increase honey production, varroa mites (not all CCD cases show the presence of these mites, however) and management stressors such as some migratory beekeeping practices. 


It's not just honeybees that are in danger. Wild pollinators are seeing rapid declines as well. Feral honeybees are colonies that have swarmed, or left with their queen in order to make room in the hive for a new queen and colony. Feral honeybee colonies were a common sight in the wild for some time, but their numbers, along with native wild bees, butterflies and bats are diminishing rapidly as well. In China, there are areas where there are no bees left at all, and entire orchards are pollinated by hand. 

At Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory, we will put into practice time-honored beekeeping methods with an eye on current scientific research. We will utilize native wildflower seed mixtures  to provide our bees, both kept and feral, with a wide variety of food beyond what they will find in our fields and forests. We will keep meticulous records and provide up-to-date information on our website, to be built with funding from this campaign. We will provide classes, hands-on community outreach and work with existing conservation societies to promote best practices for pollinator conservation. We will also harvest and sell our honey. All proceeds will go toward our establishment as a nonprofit, and toward the goals previously listed. We will also  breed queens, and intend to learn how capture unwanted swarms and adopt unwanted existing hives in our area, and to encourage beekeepers in other regions to do the same. 

                

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our aim with this fundraiser is to raise $7000 to begin our effort. Your donations will cover our minimum start-up costs. We will buy brand new hives and equipment from local companies. This is important as this is a bioregional effort, and we want to support our local economy. We will visit Ruhl Bee Supply as well as Bee Thinking. We will do our best to buy locally bred bee packages and nucs to populate our hives. We will hire local experts to consult us if we run into problems. We will continue our research and education into the practice of beekeeping. We will join existing pollinator conservation efforts and beekeeping societies, establish an official website to share news and best practices for caring for bees and pollinators as well as to sell products from the hive, and we will buy electric fencing to keep predators safely away from our beehives. (We live in a forest where bears and other honey-lovers live.) We will purchase materials needed to build a better bumblebee home and to build and utilize orchard bee houses. Finally, we will be able to afford to apply for grants to further fund our effort, and establish a nonprofit so that your future donations will be tax-deductible. Currently we are in the process of establishing ourselves as an Oregon business and have filed a DBA to that effect. 
  • Each donation you make will come with a perk. From $5 and under (your name on our website) on up to $1000 (stay with us at the farm for a weekend, receive many one-of-a-kind gifts, and we will name the first queen bee after you) perks include poems, artwork, a salon & cocktail reception in the historic farmhouse here at Stargazer Farms, a guided hike through the gorge and down to a black sand beach below the property, a children's day out at the farm, the chance to see your manuscript put to print and designed by a respected independent press, access to exclusive updates from Dena, a bound first year beekeeping journal, an exclusive chapbook of Dena's bee poems, one of a kind works of art and books, and a cooking lesson and dinner for four at Stargazer farm with world-renowned chef Isabel Cruz, plus of course, first-harvest honey & other products from the hive. 
  • Whether we make our goal or not, we plan to put your donations to use by establishing beehives here on the farm, and to begin researching new ways to attract and host wild pollinators. The more money we raise, the more bees we can help. We will reinvest the money we make from this venture into helping more bees, and will consult with organic food company executives and farm owners as well as others to make sure we grow a financially sustainable organization. 

The Impact & Possible Risks 

  • Bees and other pollinators are important not only to human survival and our food chain, but to the ecology of forests, deserts and everything in between. Where plants grow, pollinators are present. Most of us know that bees are in danger. This is a chance to help do something about it. 
  • I am an active member of my literary community. I donate time and energy, as well as money, to its well-being. My work is widely published, I live and work on a farm in the wilderness and am supported by those who also live on my family farm, which is dedicated to sustainable agriculture. I work and have valuable contacts in the organic food industry, and have worked for political leaders in all sorts of advocacy, including disability rights. My heart is set on helping my world community save the bees, and I have a track record of dedication to the causes I believe in. I live on a sustainable farm and my bees will help it thrive, as it will help my bees thrive. 
  • Risks are obvious. Sadly, first year and even established beehives stand a good chance of dying. So many things can and are going wrong right now. That's the reason I am taking action. While the bees I raise have a good chance of never encountering pesticides, there is the chance that it could happen as they forage. They have a lot of pristine foraging ground here, but there is no way to keep them from finding a sprayed flower. I will alert my neighbors, far off as they live from me (one mile is about the closest,) of my project and ask them to only spray at night if they must spray at all. It is common for a first year hive to produce only enough honey to sustain a colony over winter. Your honey sample perks might take more than one year to produce. The health of the bees will come first. 

Other Ways You Can Help Us

If you can't contribute financially, we are happy for other kinds of support. 

  • Share the link to this campaign far and wide. You can use the social media buttons here or just copy and paste the link into emails, onto your website, or your social media page. 
  • Contact us to sign up as a volunteer - denargbee@gmail.com
  • If you would like to donate beekeeping goods such as smokers, veils, native wildflower seed mix, or wood for us to use for construction of feral bee habitats, we are happy to accept such donations. At this time we are unable to give you a tax deduction form, but our aim is to become a nonprofit. 
  • Research best practices for helping pollinators thrive and put them to use. 
  • Do not use systemic pesticides.
  • Plant a garden of organic & native plants that flower at various times during pollinator foraging season (spring, summer and even fall)
  • Support your local sustainable family farms. Eat local honey. 
  • Support permaculture. 
  • Buy organic whenever possible. 
  • Tell your representatives to label GMOs and ban neonicotinoid pesticides. 
  • Tell your local hardware stores not to sell bee-harming pesticides. 
  • Consider interviewing us about this effort for your publication. We would love any press or promotion we can get. 
  • Alert us to any grants to which you think we should apply. 
  • Offer to donate your time in helping us apply for those grants.
  • Like our Facebook page.  
  • Visit our forthcoming website for forms and tips regarding how to care for and advocate for pollinator safety. 

With thanks, 

Dena Rash Guzman


Founder 
Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory
Sandy, Oregon 



(Note: Not all perks are accumulative. Some of our perks will be fulfilled as soon as we have a website, some won't be fulfilled until after summer or later due to the nature of this project. The perk date listed is the approximate latest delivery date of one of the incentives in your donation bracket. Some of your rewards will come sooner than others. If there is no honey harvest the first year, honey perks will be received upon the next year's honey harvest. We cannot ship hive products outside of the United States due to laws and regulations. We will gladly ship any hive product you qualify for to someone within the United States as a gift. Our perks include shipping only within the United States. Shipping overseas may require your financial cooperation. Please email us with any questions at denargbee@gmail.com) 

We are grateful to all who have graciously offered these perks, their support, their art for our logo, and the filmmaking abilities of  Under Oath Productions.

Thanks to many of our sponsors and supporters. You are here in no particular order. We hope to name you all.

Billy Tosheff 

Stargazer Farms (including Jamie Farmmaiden, Farmer John, Billy, Edgar, Tim the Woodsman, Erik, Jackson and others for the support they have given or surely will give because they are my family and my people.)
Ron & Joanna Rash
Unchaste Readers—Women Reading Their Minds
KMA Sullivan, YesYes Books
Cari Luna, author The Revolution of Every Day, Tin House Books
The Portland Collage Collective (Lesley Harper, Reuben Nisenfeld, Kevin Sampsell, B Frayn Masters, Kerry Cohen, James Bernard Frost, Mark Russell and more)
Jerimiah Whitlock, Under Oath Productions (maker of our video)
HAL Publishing & Far Enough East
Back Fence PDX
Isabel Pearl, Portland OR 
Various beekeepers I have befriended already so soon into this journey.
Dave Wright
W.M. Butler (logo design)
Artistically Declined Press
Finally, Francis Lutz of Fox River Farms in Illinois. He raises grass fed beef and has 
been of incredible inspiration to me, and Carrie Brown, my dear friend who left us far too soon. One of my queen bees will be named for Carrie.
story_txt:
This is where the bees will live. Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory - Sandy, OregonThank you for taking a look at this fundraising effort. My name is Dena Rash Guzman. I am a published poet, essayist and work as a writer and reporter for the organic food industry. Born in Las Vegas, Nevada, I now make my home on my family's 60 acre sustainable permaculture-centered produce farm deep in the pristine old-growth coniferous wilderness of the Sandy River Gorge and the Bull Run Wilderness near Portland, Oregon. Stargazer Farms, established as the Oregon Bulb Farm in the 1930s sits on a river bluff and is filled with a variety of unsprayed and organic plant life, including heirloom flowers left over from its previous life as a flower farm. It is alive with bees, butterflies and other natural pollinators, all of which forage blooms from early spring to late fall. One cannot sit still on our property during foraging season without seeing a pollinator feeding on nectar, or without hearing a constant hum-buzz of life. Three honeybee hives are kept here by our farmers at this time. I would like to add to those hives, using time-honored holistic beekeeping methods, as well as research new ways to attract and provide homes for wild pollinators like bumblebees and orchard bees. With success, I hope eventually to produce and provide these homes and habitat plans for other farms, backyard gardens and urban environments in my bioregion and beyond. Another aim is outreach, education and establishment as a nonprofit with the aim of employing at a living wage disabled people to work the hives, package honey, and help produce wild bee homes and habitats. The ultimate aim of Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory is to fill the world with honeybees, wild pollinators, and wildflowers. It is often said that the best sign of a healthy farm is a healthy beehive. Could the same be said of the world? If so, we are headed for some trouble. Bees are disappearing. Since 2006, beekeepers throughout North American and parts of Europe have watched helplessly as their honeybee hives are decimated by colony collapse disorder. From backyard hobbyists to major commercial operators, keepers have reported up to 90% hive losses each year since then, with an average yearly hive loss of 34% since 2006, since the disorder was first named and diagnosed. While hives can fall to many ailments, the mark of CCD is a hive from which nearly all the bees in the colony disappear, leaving behind the queen bee, her brood and a handful of sick bees. As bees cannot live without their colony, all the bees die. With the exception of the bees left behind in the hive, none of the other bees are found. They simply disappear. There are many theories but no real answers as to the cause of CCD, but some thoughts and research point to systemic pesticides, monoculture farming practices, soil erosion, changing weather patterns in North America, chemical treatment of beehives, pollution, water scarcity, viruses including a newly discovered one that jumps from flower to bee, premature replacement of queen bees to increase honey production, varroa mites (not all CCD cases show the presence of these mites, however) and management stressors such as some migratory beekeeping practices. It's not just honeybees that are in danger. Wild pollinators are seeing rapid declines as well. Feral honeybees are colonies that have swarmed, or left with their queen in order to make room in the hive for a new queen and colony. Feral honeybee colonies were a common sight in the wild for some time, but their numbers, along with native wild bees, butterflies and bats are diminishing rapidly as well. In China, there are areas where there are no bees left at all, and entire orchards are pollinated by hand. At Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator Conservatory, we will put into practice time-honored beekeeping methods with an eye on current scientific research. We will utilize native wildflower seed mixtures  to provide our bees, both kept and feral, with a wide variety of food beyond what they will find in our fields and forests. We will keep meticulous records and provide up-to-date information on our website, to be built with funding from this campaign. We will provide classes, hands-on community outreach and work with existing conservation societies to promote best practices for pollinator conservation. We will also harvest and sell our honey. All proceeds will go toward our establishment as a nonprofit, and toward the goals previously listed. We will also  breed queens, and intend to learn how capture unwanted swarms and adopt unwanted existing hives in our area, and to encourage beekeepers in other regions to do the same.                 What We Need & What You Get

Our aim with this fundraiser is to raise $7000 to begin our effort. Your donations will cover our minimum start-up costs. We will buy brand new hives and equipment from local companies. This is important as this is a bioregional effort, and we want to support our local economy. We will visit Ruhl Bee Supply as well as Bee Thinking. We will do our best to buy locally bred bee packages and nucs to populate our hives. We will hire local experts to consult us if we run into problems. We will continue our research and education into the practice of beekeeping. We will join existing pollinator conservation efforts and beekeeping societies, establish an official website to share news and best practices for caring for bees and pollinators as well as to sell products from the hive, and we will buy electric fencing to keep predators safely away from our beehives. (We live in a forest where bears and other honey-lovers live.) We will purchase materials needed to build a better bumblebee home and to build and utilize orchard bee houses. Finally, we will be able to afford to apply for grants to further fund our effort, and establish a nonprofit so that your future donations will be tax-deductible. Currently we are in the process of establishing ourselves as an Oregon business and have filed a DBA to that effect. 

Each donation you make will come with a perk. From $5 and under (your name on our website) on up to $1000 (stay with us at the farm for a weekend, receive many one-of-a-kind gifts, and we will name the first queen bee after you) perks include poems, artwork, a salon & cocktail reception in the historic farmhouse here at Stargazer Farms, a guided hike through the gorge and down to a black sand beach below the property, a children's day out at the farm, the chance to see your manuscript put to print and designed by a respected independent press, access to exclusive updates from Dena, a bound first year beekeeping journal, an exclusive chapbook of Dena's bee poems, one of a kind works of art and books, and a cooking lesson and dinner for four at Stargazer farm with world-renowned chef Isabel Cruz, plus of course, first-harvest honey & other products from the hive. 

Whether we make our goal or not, we plan to put your donations to use by establishing beehives here on the farm, and to begin researching new ways to attract and host wild pollinators. The more money we raise, the more bees we can help. We will reinvest the money we make from this venture into helping more bees, and will consult with organic food company executives and farm owners as well as others to make sure we grow a financially sustainable organization. 
The Impact & Possible Risks 
Bees and other pollinators are important not only to human survival and our food chain, but to the ecology of forests, deserts and everything in between. Where plants grow, pollinators are present. Most of us know that bees are in danger. This is a chance to help do something about it. 
I am an active member of my literary community. I donate time and energy, as well as money, to its well-being. My work is widely published, I live and work on a farm in the wilderness and am supported by those who also live on my family farm, which is dedicated to sustainable agriculture. I work and have valuable contacts in the organic food industry, and have worked for political leaders in all sorts of advocacy, including disability rights. My heart is set on helping my world community save the bees, and I have a track record of dedication to the causes I believe in. I live on a sustainable farm and my bees will help it thrive, as it will help my bees thrive. 
Risks are obvious. Sadly, first year and even established beehives stand a good chance of dying. So many things can and are going wrong right now. That's the reason I am taking action. While the bees I raise have a good chance of never encountering pesticides, there is the chance that it could happen as they forage. They have a lot of pristine foraging ground here, but there is no way to keep them from finding a sprayed flower. I will alert my neighbors, far off as they live from me (one mile is about the closest,) of my project and ask them to only spray at night if they must spray at all. It is common for a first year hive to produce only enough honey to sustain a colony over winter. Your honey sample perks might take more than one year to produce. The health of the bees will come first. 
Other Ways You Can Help UsIf you can't contribute financially, we are happy for other kinds of support. 
Share the link to this campaign far and wide. You can use the social media buttons here or just copy and paste the link into emails, onto your website, or your social media page. 
Contact us to sign up as a volunteer - denargbee@gmail.com
If you would like to donate beekeeping goods such as smokers, veils, native wildflower seed mix, or wood for us to use for construction of feral bee habitats, we are happy to accept such donations. At this time we are unable to give you a tax deduction form, but our aim is to become a nonprofit. 
Research best practices for helping pollinators thrive and put them to use. 
Do not use systemic pesticides.
Plant a garden of organic & native plants that flower at various times during pollinator foraging season (spring, summer and even fall)

Support your local sustainable family farms. Eat local honey. 
Support permaculture. 
Buy organic whenever possible. 
Tell your representatives to label GMOs and ban neonicotinoid pesticides. 

Tell your local hardware stores not to sell bee-harming pesticides. 
Consider interviewing us about this effort for your publication. We would love any press or promotion we can get. 
Alert us to any grants to which you think we should apply. 
Offer to donate your time in helping us apply for those grants.
Like our Facebook page.  
Visit our forthcoming website for forms and tips regarding how to care for and advocate for pollinator safety. 
With thanks, Dena Rash GuzmanFounder Lusted Road Honey Co. & Humblebee Pollinator ConservatorySandy, Oregon (Note: Not all perks are accumulative. Some of our perks will be fulfilled as soon as we have a website, some won't be fulfilled until after summer or later due to the nature of this project. The perk date listed is the approximate latest delivery date of one of the incentives in your donation bracket. Some of your rewards will come sooner than others. If there is no honey harvest the first year, honey perks will be received upon the next year's honey harvest. We cannot ship hive products outside of the United States due to laws and regulations. We will gladly ship any hive product you qualify for to someone within the United States as a gift. Our perks include shipping only within the United States. Shipping overseas may require your financial cooperation. Please email us with any questions at denargbee@gmail.com) We are grateful to all who have graciously offered these perks, their support, their art for our logo, and the filmmaking abilities of  Under Oath Productions.Thanks to many of our sponsors and supporters. You are here in no particular order. We hope to name you all.Billy Tosheff Stargazer Farms (including Jamie Farmmaiden, Farmer John, Billy, Edgar, Tim the Woodsman, Erik, Jackson and others for the support they have given or surely will give because they are my family and my people.)Ron & Joanna RashUnchaste Readers—Women Reading Their MindsKMA Sullivan, YesYes BooksCari Luna, author The Revolution of Every Day, Tin House BooksThe Portland Collage Collective (Lesley Harper, Reuben Nisenfeld, Kevin Sampsell, B Frayn Masters, Kerry Cohen, James Bernard Frost, Mark Russell and more)Jerimiah Whitlock, Under Oath Productions (maker of our video)HAL Publishing & Far Enough EastBack Fence PDXIsabel Pearl, Portland OR Various beekeepers I have befriended already so soon into this journey.Dave WrightW.M. Butler (logo design)Artistically Declined PressFinally, Francis Lutz of Fox River Farms in Illinois. He raises grass fed beef and has been of incredible inspiration to me, and Carrie Brown, my dear friend who left us far too soon. One of my queen bees will be named for Carrie.

story:
Sailing for a cause

Time slows down for no man, and the time for action is upon us right now. This fall we're making our inaugural aid trip by filling a 40 ft Chinese junk with humanitarian aid supplies and sailing it to Nicaragua, the second most impoverished country in the Western Hemisphere.  With your help, we can fill the boat to capacity and maximize the impact in the communities we visit.

 

Impact

What does it tell you when you consider that things we see as very basic, abundant supplies--like bars of soap, blankets, toiletries, clothing, school supplies, moquito netting, first aid kits--are longed for and will make huge impacts in the lives of people faced with extreme poverty?  These are just a few of the essentials from the aid packs we're delivering.

Along with aid packs, we want to have at least 10 midwifery kits in this mission's inventory.  Building a midwifery base in rural areas guarantees a significant drop in both maternal and infant mortality rates, especially the regions we're visiting in Nicaragua which are regularly ravaged by hurricanes and lack a strong medical infrastructure.

We all know that there's so much more to humanitarian work than dropping off a boatload of supplies, no matter how much they're needed.  Making a real impact requires local involvement and collaborative efforts with community leaders, thought-out approaches to creating sustainability in the face of hardship, and long-term dedication to the cause.  At Green Seas, we want to create long-term social change through that kind of involvement. 

By supporting our first-ever Nicaraguan aid delivery, you're furthering a much larger ambition.  With time and continued support, we can increase our geographic range and cargo capacity, broadening our future impact.  Most importantly, we can establish long-term partnerships with countries in need to create sustainable, thriving communities.  By supporting Green Seas, you will be an active part of our vision, and you will have joined a community for life.

"Raising sails and changing lives"--that's our credo. Help us exemplify it.

 

The Details

It's a plain fact that the purpose of this site to raise money for our cause. We're proud of this cause, and our mission as an organization, so let's put the cards on the table and spell-out exactly what we're doing

  • Money we raise is being used to pay for the aid supplies we're bringing, cover costs of operating the boat and to improve the quality of life in the communities we visit.  We are asking for $4,500 but that amount represents the bare minimum needed to pull off this mission. If we raise way more than needed it will go towards future missions.
  • Our deliveries are focusing on the East Coast of Nicaragua, mostly between the cities of Bluefields and Puerto Cabezas.  Known as both the "Forgotten Coast" in reference to treatment from the Nicaraguan government and the "Mosquito Shore" due to it's ecology, it encompasses the poorest areas of the country.
  • We're delivering midwifery kits, aid packages (which include a wide range of basic suppplies, mostly for personal hygiene, comfort and human dignity), first aid kits and school supplies. 
  • Volunteers from Green Seas will be spending time in Nicaragua to work with community leaders, especially in the rural areas we visit, to help develop sustainability projects and break the chains of poverty.
  • It will take several weeks at sea to deliver the aid supplies from where the boat is docked in Califorina to Nicaragua. The planned route stretches over 3,000 miles, two oceans, connects two continents, and passes through Panama Canal before making landfall in the Caribbean.
  • The boat's crew is made up entirely of volunteers, mostly seasoned sailors, who will bring the boat up the US east coast at the end of the mission.
  • The boat itself is a Chniese Junk which has been lovingly restored over the last two years by her captain/owner, Captain Shing, using environmentally conscious and traditional techniques.  He has graciously lent us the use of his boat for this trip and we couldn't be more thrilled! Rumor has it there's a clawfoot tub onboard.

Green Seas, you say?

Our organization boasts a proud mix of sailors, educators, philanthropists and free-thinkers. We might be small but we have diversification down to a science and we're growing. Our strength is in our uniqueness.  This mission to Nicaragua marks the beginning of our real-world trial run, a chance to prove the concept that sailing based humanitarian aid can work.  We're pretty confident. For donactions exceeding $250 please contact us on facebook for information on how to make your gift tax-deductible.  

  

No money? No problem. VOLUNTEER!

Some people just can’t contribute financially but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Our volunteers keep us going and we know it. If you have a skill that you think might be useful we can find a way to make it work.
  • Boat building skills? Always a plus!
  • Bookkeeping? Perfect, let's talk numbers.
  • Webdesign?  Yes, please!
  • We're ready to sail the seven seas, are you ready to share in our vision?

story:
Our Story

Born out of the desire to have a positive impact on the environment and the realization that composting is one of the most important things we can do, this past winter we started a business. Black Earth Hauler cuts waste removal costs for businesses by collecting organic material derived from anything that was alive (food, paper, hair, etc.) and transports them to farms for conversion to rich compost for farmers, gardeners and landscapers, rather than have it incinerated or buried in landfills. This provides an environmentally beneficial way to incorporate these valuable nutrients back into the growth cycle.

Over the first nine months, we established a program with restaurants, schools, food distributers, residents, caterers, grocery stores, a retreat center, a pet groomer, and more. Most have reported that it saved money or found it is a cost neutral activity. All of them derive satisfaction from the fact that the food they have to throw out is put to good use. 

As you can see, the star of the movie was our hydraulic lift we call the Praying Mantis, which we built from scratch last spring. The Praying Mantis is at the heart of our story because not only does it make this all possible, it symbolizes the bootstrapping, ingenuity, persevering nature that has led us to succeed thus far.

If you'd like to hear more about our story, read this article.

The Impact

More and more people are becoming aware of the precarious environmental state of our world: food prices are going up; farmers are being asked to grow more food on less land, use less water, confront harsh weather conditions and use less fertilizer to meet the rising demand. At the same time, artificial fertilizers derived from natural gas have caused massive nitrogen run-off problems by creating dead zones in our water systems. Rivaling global warming as a threat, the world is rapidly losing top-soil.

One of the most important things we can do is convert our food waste into rich composted material that will create a very nutritious soil amendment. Restaurants have found this is very easy to implement. It is working and we are growing. Every person and business concerned about our environment can make a big difference in getting this movement going. 


What We Need & What You Get

We bought the truck and built the Praying Mantis on our savings. As you can tell from the video, we don't spend our money perfecting things, we get stuff done efficiently and we do it ourselves to be frugal. But the start-up costs have been high and we need a second truck before we go into next spring because we expect to haul twice the amount we are now, or we will be in the vulnerable position of having many clients serviced by an old, ailing truck. We're not looking for the $100,000 truck every garbage company uses; a $10,000 truck will suffice. If we don't hit our goal, the money will still go towards a second truck. Composting is important. We're making a difference. We'd really appreciate your help in making a bigger difference! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell anyone and everyone. Link us to facebook and everything else! It really helps us out.
